SENTENCES AND THEIR PERPLEXITY


1. the fulton county grand jury said friday an investigation	of atlanta's recent primary election produced no evidence that	any irregularities took place.	3.0830438041974118
2. the jury further said in term-end	presentments that the city executive committee which had over-all	charge of the election deserves the praise and thanks of the	city of atlanta for the manner in which the election was conducted.	5.355374207189308
3. the september-october term jury had been charged by fulton	superior court judge durwood pye to investigate reports of possible	irregularities in the hard-fought primary which was won by	mayor-nominate ivan allen jr.	2.8314030085669293
4. only a relative handful	of such reports was received the jury said considering the	widespread interest in the election the number of voters and the size	of this city.	6.171105535847176
5. the jury said it did find that many of georgia's	registration and election laws are outmoded or inadequate	and often ambiguous.	3.6108301209151246
6. it recommended that fulton legislators	act to have these laws studied and revised to the end of modernizing	and improving them.	6.13912708191384
7. the grand jury commented on a number	of other topics among them the atlanta and fulton county purchasing	departments which it said are well operated and follow generally	accepted practices which inure to the best interest of both governments.	3.15882797776794
8. however the jury said it believes these	two offices should be combined to achieve greater efficiency and reduce	the cost of administration.	5.740436707815631
9. the city purchasing department	the jury said is lacking in experienced clerical personnel	as a result of city personnel policies.	3.809773807949439
10. it urged that the city take	steps to remedy this problem.	7.0579679958870605
11. implementation of georgia's	automobile title law was also recommended by the outgoing jury.	3.789673939348378
12. it urged that the next legislature provide enabling funds	and re-set the effective date so that an orderly implementation of	the law may be effected.	5.370131511428444
13. the grand jury took a swipe at the	state welfare department's handling of federal funds granted for	child welfare services in foster homes.	3.130345744592494
14. this is one of the	major items in the fulton county general assistance program the	jury said but the state welfare department has seen fit to distribute	these funds through the welfare departments of all the counties	in the state with the exception of fulton county which receives	none of this money.	5.362830841809441
15. the jurors said they realize a proportionate	distribution of these funds might disable this program in our less	populous counties.	3.3130426037264677
16. nevertheless we feel that in the	future fulton county should receive some portion of these available	funds the jurors said.	5.483728750879504
17. failure to do this will continue to place	a disproportionate burden on fulton taxpayers.	4.678215514421434
18. the jury	also commented on the fulton ordinary's court which has been under	fire for its practices in the appointment of appraisers guardians and	administrators and the awarding of fees and compensation.	4.593617192176741
19. the jury said it found the court has incorporated into	its operating procedures the recommendations of two previous grand	juries the atlanta bar association and an interim citizens committee.	3.3447709147886253
20. these actions should serve to protect in fact and in effect the court's wards from undue costs and its appointed and elected servants from unmeritorious criticisms the jury said.	4.851829561454344
21. regarding atlanta's new multi-million-dollar airport the jury recommended that when the new management takes charge jan 1 the airport be operated in a manner that will eliminate political influences.	3.4332642572704533
22. the jury did not elaborate but it added that there should be periodic surveillance of the pricing practices of the concessionaires for the purpose of keeping the prices reasonable.	5.329655968417609
23. fulton legislators work with city officials to pass enabling legislation that will permit the establishment of a fair and equitable pension plan for city employes.	3.5138726004158154
24. the jury praised the administration and operation of the atlanta police department the fulton tax commissioner's office the bellwood and alpharetta prison farms grady hospital and the fulton health department.	4.765471985850366
25. mayor william b hartsfield filed suit for divorce from his wife pearl williams hartsfield in fulton superior court friday.	3.3238361134754513
26. his petition charged mental cruelty.	7.113527960591263
27. the couple was married aug 2 1913.	3.8658964313185935
28. they have a son william berry jr and a daughter mrs j m cheshire of griffin.	6.186431039205
29. attorneys for the mayor said that an amicable property settlement has been agreed upon.	3.859087948905189
30. the petition listed the mayor's occupation as attorney and his age as 71.	5.126670788258843
31. it listed his wife's age as 74 and place of birth as opelika ala.	3.8381664126552293
32. the petition said that the couple has not lived together as man and wife for more than a year.	6.232981932764447
33. the hartsfield home is at 637 e pelham rd ne.	3.3419733447192717
34. henry l bowden was listed on the petition as the mayor's attorney.	6.008723654291324
35. hartsfield has been mayor of atlanta with exception of one brief interlude since 1937.	3.626286427764096
36. his political career goes back to his election to city council in 1923.	6.29499928273384
37. the mayor's present term of office expires jan 1.	3.315601241337999
38. he will be succeeded by ivan allen jr who became a candidate in the sept 13 primary after mayor hartsfield announced that he would not run for reelection.	5.928160182238463
39. georgia republicans are getting strong encouragement to enter a candidate in the 1962 governor's race a top official said wednesday.	3.8265050562217438
40. robert snodgrass state gop chairman said a meeting held tuesday night in blue ridge brought enthusiastic responses from the audience.	5.183534657985295
41. state party chairman james w dorsey added that enthusiasm was picking up for a state rally to be held sept 8 in savannah at which newly elected texas sen john tower will be the featured speaker.	3.556670926725235
42. in the blue ridge meeting the audience was warned that entering a candidate for governor would force it to take petitions out into voting precincts to obtain the signatures of registered voters.	5.157280005230118
43. despite the warning there was a unanimous vote to enter a candidate according to republicans who attended.	4.295483398704242
44. when the crowd was asked whether it wanted to wait one more term to make the race it voted no- and there were no dissents.	6.102575575182873
45. the largest hurdle the republicans would have to face is a	state law which says that before making a first race one of two alternative	courses must be taken:  five per cent of the voters	in each county must sign petitions requesting that the republicans be	allowed to place names of candidates on the general election ballot	or  the republicans must hold a primary under the county unit	system- a system which the party opposes in its platform.	3.123612834758198

56. a highway department source	said there also is a plan there to issue some $3 million to $4 million	worth of rural roads authority bonds for rural road construction work.	4.797813121661467
57. the department apparently intends to make	the rural roads authority a revolving fund under which new bonds would	be issued every time a portion of the old ones are paid off by tax	authorities.	3.5679512035395606
58. vandiver opened his race for governor in 1958 with	a battle in the legislature against the issuance of $50 million worth	of additional rural roads bonds proposed by then gov marvin	griffin.	5.01615209279361
59. the highway department source told the constitution	however that vandiver has not been consulted yet about the plans	to issue the new rural roads bonds.	3.306209285769597
60. schley county rep b d pelham will offer a resolution	monday in the house to rescind the body's action of friday in	voting itself a $10 per day increase in expense allowances.	4.915530944809486
61. pelham	said sunday night there was research being done on whether the	quickie vote on the increase can be repealed outright or whether	notice would have to first be given that reconsideration of the action	would be sought.	3.490633649732564

88. committee approval of gov price daniel's	abandoned property act seemed certain thursday despite the adamant	protests of texas bankers.	5.031549236550104
89. daniel personally led the fight	for the measure which he had watered down considerably since its	rejection by two previous legislatures in a public hearing before	the house committee on revenue and taxation.	3.3574018137110433
90. under committee	rules it went automatically to a subcommittee for one week.	6.240215654847032
91. but	questions with which committee members taunted bankers appearing as witnesses	left little doubt that they will recommend passage of it.	3.55762300834467
92. daniel termed extremely conservative his estimate that it would	produce 17 million dollars to help erase an anticipated deficit of	63 million dollars at the end of the current fiscal year next aug	31.	5.296672861245055
93. he told the committee the measure would merely provide means	of enforcing the escheat law which has been on the books since	texas was a republic.	3.784790533054774
94. it permits the state to take over bank accounts	stocks and other personal property of persons missing for seven	years or more.	5.406853062359779
95. the bill which daniel said he drafted personally	would force banks insurance firms pipeline companies and other	corporations to report such property to the state treasurer.	3.3088462742223768
96. the escheat	law cannot be enforced now because it is almost impossible to locate	such property daniel declared.	5.525389039545648
97. dewey lawrence a tyler	lawyer representing the texas bankers association sounded the opposition	keynote when he said it would force banks to violate their contractual	obligations with depositors and undermine the confidence of bank	customers.	3.3667975360874016
98. if you destroy confidence in banks you do something	to the economy he said.	6.107127190454792
99. you take out of circulation many	millions of dollars.	4.881586566628631

2760. here's an idea for a child's room that is easy to execute	and is completely charming using puppets for lamp bases.	4.912502476503571

2763. to create such a lamp order	a wired pedestal from any lamp shop.	3.8428784272157763
2764. measure the puppet to determine	the height of the light socket allowing three to four inches above the	puppet's head.	5.3966612245736245
2765. make sure that the metal tube through which the wire	passes is in the shape of an inverted l the foot of the	l about three inches long so that the puppet can hang directly	under the light.	3.931408492063292
2766. using the strings that manipulate	the puppet suspend him from the light fixture by tying the	strings to the lamp base.	5.36427848617748
2767. in this way you can arrange his legs and arms	in any desired position with feet or one foot barely resting on	the pedestal.	3.6214450850843787

3177. the pattern	here pictured is clearly not peculiar to notre dame: it is simply	that the paradox involved in this kind of control of the institution	by the organization which actually owns it becomes more obvious	where there is a larger and more distinguished outside faculty.	3.2868337975086592

3179. but	in any case one does not have to read very closely between the lines	to realize that the situation is not regarded as a particularly happy	one.	4.155500538580597
3180. outside faculty members want to be considered partners in	the academic enterprise and not merely paid employees of a family business.	6.332084568033781
3181. there are two reasons why failure to come to grips with	this demand could be fatal to the future of the catholic university.	4.217990530112556
3182. in the first place there is the obvious problem of recruiting high caliber	personnel.	7.367715355957117
3183. word spreads rapidly in the tightly knit academic profession	much given to attending meetings and conferences.	3.52971533883427
3184. expressions	of even low-key dissatisfaction by a catholic college faculty member	has the effect of confirming the already existing stereotype.	5.072111114191032
3185. in	the academic world there is seldom anything so dramatic as a strike or	a boycott: all that happens is that the better qualified teacher declines	to gamble two or three years of his life on the chance that conditions	at the catholic institution will be as good as those elsewhere.	3.714615554339046
3186. to appreciate the nature of the gamble it should be realized	that while college teaching is almost a public symbol of security	that security does not come as quickly or as automatically as it does	in an elementary school system or in the civil service.	5.613236119815163
3187. much has	been made of the fact that major catholic institutions now guarantee	firm tenure.	4.955481348423054
3188. this is a significant advance but its import should not	be exaggerated.	6.562157421560804
3189. when a man invests a block of his years at a university	without gaining the coveted promotion not only is he faced with the	problem of starting over but there is also a certain depreciation in	the market value of his services.	3.6750237288166168
3190. a man does not make that kind of	gamble if he suspects that one or more of the limited number of tenure	positions is being reserved for members of the family.	5.8905282196785365
3191. just	as it is possible to exaggerate the drawing power of the new	tenure practices it is also possible to exaggerate the significance	of the now relatively adequate salaries paid by major catholic institutions.	3.789409389105648
3192. yet adequate compensation-	and particularly merely adequate compensation is no substitute	for those intangibles which cause a man to sacrifice part of his	earning potential by taking up college teaching in the first place.	5.17005069784226
3193. broadly	speaking the total catholic atmosphere is such an intangible	but the larger demand is for a sense of creative participation and mature	responsibility in the total work of the university.	3.632091648869841
3194. religious who	derive their own sense of purpose through identification with the religious	community rather than the academic community are prone to underestimate	both the layman's reservoir of idealism and his need for this	identification.	5.036233691047721
3195. there is no need here to spell out the conditions	of creative teaching except to point out that at the college	level the sense of community and of community responsibility is even	more necessary than it is at other levels.	4.06143727962065

3199. this is a problem that goes considerably beyond questions of salary	and tenure.	4.555119660012508
3200. yet though it may seem difficult to envision any definitive	resolution of the problem of ownership and control there are nevertheless	certain suggestions which seem to be in order.	6.4502079608365435

3942. in some parts of	the country however a co-operative movement has begun to grow under	the wing of state governments whereby with the financial help of the	state libraries share their book resources on a county-wide or regional	basis.	4.807560140352265
3943. new york state has what is probably the most advanced	of these co-operative systems so well developed that it has become	a model for others to follow.	4.037239765895441

3945. at	one extreme are the systems of upper new york state where libraries	in two or more counties combine to serve a large sparsely populated	area.	3.720766199506474
3946. at the other are organizations like the newly formed nassau library	system in a high-density area with ample resources and a rapidly	growing territory to serve.	5.161838530889704
3947. both these types and those	in between are in existence by reason of a legislative interest in libraries	that began at albany as early as 1950 with the creation by the	legislature of county library systems financed by county governments	with matching funds from the state.	3.190814176149242
3948. it was a step in the right direction	but it took an additional act passed in 1958 to establish fully	the thriving systems of today.	5.7301838833308
3949. under this law annual grants are	given to systems in substantial amounts.	4.12191680581474
3950. an earlier difficulty was	overcome by making it clear that individual libraries in any area might	join or not as they saw fit.	5.883642164544013
3951. some library boards are wary of the	plan.	4.436021760467523
3952. a large well-stocked library surrounded in a county by smaller	ones may feel that the demands on its resources are likely to be too	great.	5.678819908915611

3954. within a system however	the autonomy of each member library is preserved.	6.633095457176494

3956. all	services are given without cost to members.	6.434033086420165

7152. baroque instrumental music	in italy and germany tends to be strong lively intense controlled	and quite abstract.	5.2754730906182825
7153. in france it remained always more picturesque	more dancelike more full of flavor.	3.9117836688201573
7154. couperin and rameau	gave titles to nearly everything they wrote not in the later sense	of program music but as a kind of nonmusical reference for the close	clear musical forms filled with keen wit and precise utterance.	5.000400475635259
7155. both composers turn up on new imports from france.	4.516910241345334
7156. bam	is the unlikely name of a french recording company whose full label is	editions de la boite a musique.	5.051634019666791
7157. they specialize in out-of-the-way	items and old french music naturally occupies a good deal of their attention.	3.9281384639150385
7158. of couperin le grand occupy	two disks and reveal the impeccable taste	and workmanship of this master- delicate flexible and gemlike.	5.148040285319597
7159. the concerts- nos 2 6 9 10 and 14 are represented-	are really closer to chamber suites than to concertos in the italian	sense.	3.01859540750716

7161. couperin	also turns up along with some lesser-known contemporaries on a disk	called	.	3.9081561501997273
7162. jean-marie leclair still is remembered a bit but bodin de	beismortier corrette and mondonville are hardly household words.	4.759222790795286
7163. what is interesting about these chamber works here is how they all reveal	the aspect of french music that was moving toward the rococo.	3.7579727273105368

7165. if	couperin shows the fashionable trend the others do so all the more.	3.816574115694209

7384. the performances of the comedie francaise are the	most important recent events in the new york theater.	6.017608730192569
7385. they	serve to contradict a popular notion that the comedie merely repeats	as accurately as possible the techniques of acting the classics that	prevailed in the 17th century.	3.3614822652668583
7386. on the contrary the old plays are continually	being reinterpreted and each new production of a classic has	only a brief history at the comedie.	5.326515318056286
7387. of course the well-received	revivals last longer than the others and that further reminds	us that the comedie is not insensitive to criticism.	4.068074289817411
7388. the directors of	the comedie do not respond to adverse notices in as docile and subservient	a manner as the broadway producers who in two instances this	season closed their plays after one performance.	4.4888331635487475
7389. but they are aware	of the world outside they court public approval they delight in full	houses and they occasionally dare to experiment in interpreting a dramatic	classic.	3.4280061938668562
7390. in france novel approaches to the classic french	plays are frequently attempted.	6.171845143322469
7391. the government pays a subsidy	for revival of the classics and this policy attracts experimenters who	sometimes put moliere's characters in modern dress and often achieve	interesting results.	3.1327964513123514
7392. so far as i know the comedie has never	put moliere's people in the costumes of the 20th century but	they do reinterpret plays and characters.	6.052057158350157

7394. the new	phedre was done in 17th century setting instead of ancient greek;	perhaps that is the comedie's equivalent for thrusting this	play's characters into our own time.	4.794803610095006
