8022. some	families place undue emphasis on food: conversations center on it	and rich delicacies are offered as rewards withheld as punishment.	4.645425985972415
8023. the	result says jolliffe: the child gains the feeling that food	is the purpose of life.	3.9380235456963844
8024. food may act as a sedative giving temporary	emotional solace just as for some people alcohol does.	5.402592983579119
8025. reports	dr keys: a fairly common experience for us is the wife who	finds her husband staying out more and more.	3.5082415988307023
8026. he may be interested in	another woman or just like being with the boys.	6.214958637764767
8027. so she fishes around	in the cupboard and hauls out a chocolate cake.	3.7982324214279735
8028. it's a matter of	boredom and the subconscious feeling that she is entitled to something	because she's being deprived of something else.	5.390023453989813
8029. for the	army of compulsive eaters- from the nibblers and the gobblers to	the downright gluttons- reducing is a war with the will that is rarely	won.	3.3818731396880466
8030. physiologist keys flatly dismisses such appetite depressants	as the amphetamines	as dangerous crutches	for a weak will.	4.732588091813399
8031. keys has no such objections to metrecal	quaker oats's quota and other 900-calorie milk formulas that are	currently winning favor from dieters.	3.244382210685716
8032. metrecal is a pretty complete	food he says.	6.606030529691286
8033. it contains large amounts of protein vitamins	and minerals.	4.639915965718454
8034. in the quantity of 900 calories a day anyone will lose	weight on it- 20 30 or 40 lbs.	5.376257980606294
8035. but keys worries that the	metrecal drinker will never make either the psychological or physiological	adjustment to the idea of eating smaller portions of food.	3.4389311671084664
8036. despite his personal distaste for obesity	dr keys has only an incidental interest	in how much americans eat.	5.514348161254263
8037. what concerns him much more is the relationship	of diet to the nation's no 1 killer: coronary artery disease	which accounts for more than half of all heart fatalities and kills	500000 americans a year- twice the toll from all varieties of	cancer five times the deaths from automobile accidents.	3.2504531444660367
8038. cholesterol	the cornerstone of dr keys's theory is a mysterious	yellowish	waxy substance chemically a crystalline alcohol.	4.94241778315392
8039. scientists	assume that cholesterol	is somehow necessary for the formation of	brain cells since it accounts for about 2% of the brain's total	solid weight.	3.23401176546393
8040. they know it is the chief ingredient in gallstones.	8.390385426602002
8041. they	suspect it plays a role in the production of adrenal hormones and	they believe it is essential to the transport of fats throughout the	circulatory system.	3.8811208079574233
8042. but they cannot fully explain the process of its	manufacture by the human liver.	6.951098547656428
8043. although the fatty protein molecules	carried in the blood and partly composed of cholesterol are water soluble	cholesterol itself is insoluble and cannot be destroyed by the	body.	3.6869134288995875
8044. a remarkable substance says dr keys quite apart	from its tendency to be deposited in the walls of arteries.	5.456085806768659
8045. when thus deposited keys says that cholesterol is mainly responsible	for the arterial blockages that culminate in heart attacks.	3.3940503204285455
8046. explains	keys: as the fatty protein molecules travel in the bloodstream	they are deposited in the intima or inner wall of a coronary artery.	4.920161321330167
8047. the proteins and fats are burned off and the cholesterol is left	behind.	3.550359342102879
8048. as cholesterol piles up it narrows irritates and damages the	artery encouraging formation of calcium deposits and slowing circulation.	4.898163870519535
8049. eventually says keys one of two things happens.	4.752090131867376
8050. a clot forms	at the site seals off the flow of blood to the heart and provokes	a heart attack.	5.665133621318614
8051. or the deposits themselves	get so big that they choke off the artery's flow to the point that	an infarct occurs: the heart muscle is suffocated cells supplied	by the artery die and the heart is permanently perhaps fatally injured.	3.4040053328023196
8052. ordinarily the human liver synthesizes	only enough cholesterol to satisfy the body's needs- for transportation	of fats and for production of bile.	5.112018402070625
8053. even eggs and other cholesterol-rich	foods eaten in normal amounts says dr keys do not materially	affect the amount of cholesterol in the blood.	3.901242099542557
8054. during world war 2 doctors in the netherlands	and scandinavia noted a curious fact: despite the stresses of nazi	occupation the death rate from coronary artery disease was slowly dropping.	5.24498682134911
8055. not until long after the war- 1950 in fact- did they get	a hint of the reason.	4.099461080586311
8056. that year sweden's haqvin malmros showed	that the sinking death rate neatly coincided with increasingly severe	restrictions on fatty foods.	4.932042066357232
8057. that same year the university of california's	dr laurance kinsell timing oxidation rates of blood	fats stumbled onto the discovery that many vegetable fats cause blood	cholesterol levels to drop radically while animal fats cause them to	rise.	3.3231705940501444
8058. here keys and others such as dr a e ahrens of	the rockefeller institute took over to demonstrate the chemical difference	between vegetable and animal fats- and even between different	varieties of each.	4.869792578312855
8059. all natural food fats fall into one of three	categories- saturated mono-unsaturated and poly-unsaturated.	3.8329825742530814
8060. the	degree of saturation depends on the number of hydrogen atoms on the	fat molecule.	6.300342333484217
8061. saturated fats can accommodate no more hydrogens.	4.229140685879946
8062. mono-unsaturated	fats have room for two more hydrogens on each molecule	and the poly-unsaturated fat molecule has room for at least four hydrogens.	5.054602229330385
8063. the three fats have similar caloric values	but each exerts a radically different influence on	blood cholesterol.	3.1757470886898522
8064. as a result although we still make use of this distinction there is	much confusion as to the meaning of the basic terms employed.	6.955715578225636
8065. just what	is meant by spirit and by matter?	4.81776425569247
8066.  the terms are generally	taken for granted as though they referred to direct and axiomatic	elements in the common experience of all.	4.991758549897029
8067. yet in the contemporary	context this is precisely what one must not do.	4.660749707870996
8068. for in the modern world	neither spirit nor matter refer to any generally agreed-upon	elements of experience.	5.699336069140422
8069. we are in a transitional stage in which	many of the connotations of former usage have had to be revised or rejected.	4.283745616587357
8070. when the words are used we are never sure which of the traditional	meanings the user may have in mind or to what extent his revisions	and rejections of former understandings correspond to ours.	5.192197864679186
8071. one of the most widespread features of contemporary thought is the	almost universal disbelief in the reality of spirit.	4.058691503874259
8072. just a few centuries	ago the world of spirits was as populous and real as the world of	material entities.	6.56869344617244
8073. not only in popular thought but in that of the highly	educated as well was this true.	4.887302467430757
8074. demons fairies angels and a host	of other spiritual beings were as much a part of the experiential	world of western man as were rocks and trees and stars.	5.335991415179015
8075. in such a world	the words matter and spirit both referred to directly	known realities in the common experience of all.	3.7843989447810173
8076. in it important elements	of christianity and of the biblical view of reality in general	which now cause us much difficulty could be responded to quite naturally	and spontaneously.	5.0700643433801265
8077. the progress of science over these last	few centuries and the gradual replacement of biblical by scientific	categories of reality have to a large extent emptied the spirit world	of the entities which previously populated it.	3.1844226465210923
8078. in carrying out this	program science has undoubtedly performed a very considerable service	for which it can claim due credit.	5.272765787038935
8079. the objectification of the world	of spirit in popular superstition had certainly gone far beyond what the	experience of spirit could justify or support.	3.0970800669374334
8080. science is fully competent	to deal with any element of experience which arises from an object	in space and time.	5.419144733392254
8081. when therefore it turned its attention to the	concrete entities with which popular imagination had peopled the world	of spirit these entities soon lost whatever status they had enjoyed	as actual elements of external reality.	3.1981879207794845
8082. in doing so science has unquestionably	cleared up widespread misconceptions removed extraneous	and illusory sources of fear and dispelled many undesirable popular	superstitions.	5.131267022188223
8083. there have been indeed many important and valuable gains	from the development of our present scientific view of the world	for which we may be rightly grateful.	4.0749052353457484
8084. all this has not however	been an unmixed blessing.	7.615299360131377
8085. the scientific debunking of the spirit world	has been in a way too successful and too thorough.	3.765437638281921
8086. the house has	been swept so clean that contemporary man has been left with no means	or at best with wholly inadequate means for dealing with his experience	of spirit.	4.807813103881548
8087. although the particular form of conceptualization which	popular imagination had made in response to the experience of spirit	was undoubtedly defective the raw experience itself which led to such	excesses remains with us as vividly as ever.	3.5121073225047716
8088. we simply find ourselves	in the position of having no means for inquiring into the structure	and meaning of this range of our experience.	5.693647298984658
8089. there is no framework	or structure of thought with respect to which we can organize it and	no part	of reality as we know and apprehend it with respect to which we	can refer this experience.	3.838145541534729
8090. science has simply left us helpless and powerless	in this important sector of our lives.	5.52937907204237
8091. the situation in	which we find ourselves is brought out with dramatic force in arthur	miller's play the crucible which deals with the salem witch	trials.	3.281031744993449
8092. as the play opens the audience is introduced to the community	of salem in puritan america at the end of the eighteenth century.	6.291228717434513
8093. aside from a quaint concern with witches and devils which provides	the immediate problem in the opening scene it is a quite normal community.	3.897522925006052
8094. the conversation of the characters creates an atmosphere suggesting	the usual mixture of pleasures foibles irritations and concerns	which would characterize the common life of a normal village in any	age.	4.534522686367331
8095. there is no occasion to feel uneasy or disturbed about these people.	4.213587243501296
8096. instead the audience can sit back at ease and from the perspective	of an enlightened time which no longer believes in such things	enjoy the dead seriousness with which the characters in the play take	the witches and devils which are under discussion.	5.347074729608009
8097. a teenage girl abigail	williams is being sharply questioned by her minister uncle	the reverend samuel parris about a wild night affair in the woods	in which she and some other girls had seemed to have had contact with	these evil beings.	3.1626102811278565
8098. for all involved in this discussion the devil is	a real entity who can really be confronted in the woods on a dark night	the demon world is populated with real creatures and witches actually	can be seen flying through the air.	4.908760229269284
8099. as the play unfolds however	the audience is subtly brought into the grip of an awful evil	which grows with ominously gathering power and soon engulfs the community.	3.458558694345223
8100. everyone in salem saint and sinner alike is swept up by it.	5.7055461894075625
8101. it is like a mysterious epidemic which starting first with abigail	and parris spreads inexorably with a dreadfully growing virulence through	the whole town until all have been infected by it.	3.1866161022267283
8102. it grows terribly	and unavoidably in power and leaves in its wake a trail of misery	moral disintegration and destruction.	5.17778989934542
8103. the audience leaves the play	under a spell it is the kind of spell which the exposure to spirit	in its living active manifestation always evokes.	3.656822205890266
8104. if one asks	about this play what it is that comes upon this community and works	within it with such terrible power there is no better answer to give	than spirit.	5.992197296647688
8105. this is not to attempt to say what spirit is but	only to employ a commonly used word to designate or simply identify a	common experience.	3.907684397570691
8106. in the end the good man john proctor expresses	what the audience has already come to feel when he says a fire	a fire is burning! i hear the boot of lucifer i see his filthy	face! the tragic irony of the play is that the very belief in and	concern with a devil who could be met in the woods and combatted with	formulae set out in books was the very thing that prevented them from	detecting the real devil when he came among them.	4.935916747270088
8107. we marvel at their	blindness for not seeing this.	4.433159633234214
8108. yet are not we of the mid-twentieth	century who rightly do not believe there is any such thing as the	devil just as bad off as they- only in a different way?	5.474214256240992
8109.  in our	disbelief we think that we can no longer even use the word and so are	unable to even name the elemental power which is so vividly real in	this play.	3.5795075286766447
8110. we are left helpless to cope with it because we do not dare	speak of it as anything real for fear that to do so would imply a commitment	to that which has already been discredited and proved false.	5.808095923248654
8111. even mr miller himself seems uncertain on this score.	4.495481960829373
8112. in	a long commentary which he has inserted in the published text of the	first act of the play he says at one point: however that experience	never raised a doubt in his mind as to the reality of the underworld	or the existence of lucifer's many-faced lieutenants.	5.362674790324889
8113. and his	belief is not to his discredit.	5.639969182947787
8114. better minds than hale's were-	and still are- convinced that there is a society of spirits beyond	our ken.	6.009455350537879
8115. on the other hand a little later on he says:	since 1692 a great but superficial change has wiped out god's	beard and the devil's horns but the world is still gripped between	two diametrically opposed absolutes.	3.4090694566970927
8116. the concept of unity in which	positive and negative are attributes of the same force in which good	and evil are relative ever-changing and always joined to the same phenomenon-	such a concept is still reserved to the physical sciences	and to the few who have grasped the history of ideas h.	5.082881360191762
8117. when we see	the steady and methodical inculcation into humanity of the idea of man's	worthlessness- until redeemed- the necessity of the devil may	become evident as a weapon a weapon designed and used time and time	again in every age to whip men into a surrender to a particular church	or church-state.	3.3041310722680484
8118. apparently he does not intend	that those who read or view this play should think of the devil as being	actually real.	6.111890859553436
8119. yet such is the dramatic power of his writing that	the audience is nevertheless left in the grip of the terrible power and	potency of that which came over salem.	3.752753307116163
8120. it casts a spell upon them	so that they leave with a feeling of having been in the mysterious presence	of an evil power.	6.077868434518593
8121. it is not enough in accounting for this feeling	to analyze it into the wickedness of individual people added together	to produce a cumulative effect.	3.703797191627306
8122. for this does not account for the	integral elemental power of that which grows with abounding vigor as	the play unfolds nor does it explain the strange numinous sense of presentness	which comes over those who watch the play like a spell.	5.09326783833143
8123. the	reality of spirit emerges in this play in spite of the author's convictions	to the contrary.	3.8772207567302486
8124. there is	nothing in the whole range of human experience more widely known and	universally felt than spirit.	6.465496122734785
8125. apart from spirit there could be no community	for it is spirit which draws men into community and gives to any	community its unity cohesiveness and permanence.	3.4907828884010854
8126. think for example	of the spirit of the marine corps.	7.638319602626535
8127. surely this is a reality we	all acknowledge.	5.273898564803523
8128. we cannot of course assign it any substance.	7.078715637386498
8129. it	is not material and is not a thing occupying space and time.	5.338973144645125
8130. yet	it exists and has an objective reality which can be experienced and	known.	6.139156825307791
8131. so it is too with many other spirits which we all know: the	spirit of nazism or communism school spirit the spirit of a street	corner gang or a football team the spirit of rotary or the ku klux	klan.	3.6591659920214927
8132. every community if it is alive has a spirit and that spirit	is the center of its unity and identity.	6.971121666148385
8133. in searching for clues	which might lead us to a fresh apprehension of the reality of spirit	the close connection between spirit and community is likely to prove	the most fruitful.	3.6111671533652485
8134. for it is primarily in community that we know and	experience spirit.	7.723254655544977
8135. it is spirit which gives life to a community and	causes it to cohere.	4.160000920746278
8136. it is the spirit which is the source of a community's	drawing power by means of which others are drawn into it from	the world outside so that the community grows and prospers.	6.336736261155334
8137. yet the	spirit which lives in community is not identical with the community.	4.171518901129576
8138. the idea of community and the idea of spirit are two distinct and separable	ideas.	6.830086617407346
8139. one characteristic of the spirit in community is	its givenness.	5.276997553935811
8140. the members of the community do not create the spirit	but rather find it present and waiting for them.	5.5873368431050325
8141. it is for them a given	which they and they alone possess.	4.5653734349601445
8142. the spirit of the marine corps	was present and operative before any of the present members of it came	into it.	6.159259294846341
8143. it is they of course who keep it alive and preserve it	so the same spirit will continue to be present in the corps for future	recruits to find as they come into it.	3.7262090465327122
8144. if the content of faith is to be presented today in a form that can be	understanded of the people- and this it must not be forgotten	is one of the goals of the perennial theological task- there is	no other choice but to abandon completely a mythological manner of	representation.	5.440670037774204
8145. this does not mean that mythological language as	such can no longer be used in theology and preaching.	4.430218249761361
8146. the absurd notion	that demythologization entails the expurgation of all mythological	concepts completely misrepresents bultmann's intention.	4.444901814860283
8147. his point	is not that mythology may not be used but that it may no longer be regarded	as the only or even the most appropriate conceptuality for expressing	the christian kerygma.	4.008086670794351
8148. when we say that a mythological mode	of thought must be completely abandoned we mean it must be abandoned	as the sole or proper means for presenting the christian understanding	of existence.	5.324415676716503
8149. mythological concepts may by all means still be used	but they can be used responsibly only as symbols or ciphers	that is only if they are also constantly interpreted in nonmythological	terms.	3.8156289606825196
8150. the statement is often made	that when bultmann argues in this way he overestimates the intellectual	stumbling-block which myth is supposed to put in the way of accepting	the christian faith.	5.5418134257204175
8151. but this statement is completely unconvincing.	5.685515597609642
8152. if bultmann's own definition of myth is strictly adhered	to	the evidence is overwhelming that he does	not at all exaggerate the extent to which the mythological concepts of	traditional theology have become incredible and irrelevant.	4.973761594277201
8153. nor is	it necessary to look for such evidence in the great urban centers of our	culture that are admittedly almost entirely secularized and so profoundly	estranged from the conventional forms in which the gospel has been	communicated.	3.590078423469552
8154. on the contrary even in the heart of the bible	belt itself as can be attested by any one who is called to work there	the industrial and technological revolutions have long been under	way together with the corresponding changes in man's picture of himself	and his world.	5.512215265599876
8155. in fact it is in just such a situation	that the profundity of bultmann's argument is disclosed.	4.424340796255227
8156. although	the theological forms of the past continue to exist in a way they do	not in a more secularized situation the striking thing is the rapidity	with which they are being reduced to a marginal existence.	5.982873879007442
8157. this is	especially in evidence among the present generation of the suburban middle	class.	4.0945734528264754
8158. time and again in counseling and teaching one encounters	members of this group whose attempts to bring into some kind of unity	the insubstantial mythologies of their fundamentalist heritage	and the stubborn reality of the modern world are only too painfully obvious.	5.195944053947143
8159. the same thing is also evidenced by the extreme culture-protestantism	so often observed to characterize the preaching	and teaching of the american churches.	3.767015698451363
8160. in the absence of a truly adequate	conceptuality in which the gospel can be expressed the unavoidable	need to demythologize it makes use of whatever resources are at	hand- and this usually means one or another of the various forms of	folk religion current in the situation.	5.270252279275783
8161. this is not to say that	the only explanation of the present infatuation with norman vincent	peale's cult of reassurance or the other types of a purely	cultural christianity is the ever-present need for a demythologized	gospel.	4.00998253980724
8162. but it is to say that this need is far more important for such	infatuation than most of the pundits seem to have suspected.	8.016168232903006
8163. however even if the latent demand for demythologization is not nearly	as widespread as we are claiming at least among the cultured elements	of the population there tends to be an almost complete indifference	to the church and its traditional message of sin and grace.	3.6690467874119426
8164. to be	sure when this is pointed out a common response among certain churchmen	is to fulminate about the little flock and the great crowd	and to take solace from paul's castigation of the wisdom of	the wise in the opening chapter of first corinthians.	4.933464846399291
8165. but can	we any longer afford the luxury of such smug indigation?	4.232634349966429
8166.  can the church	risk assuming that the folly of men is as dear to god as their	wisdom or as is also commonly implied that the foolishness	of god and the foolishness of men are simply two ways	of talking about the same thing?	5.177207551719618
8167.  can we continue to alienate precisely	those whose gifts we so desperately need and apart from whose co-operation	our mission in the world must become increasingly precarious?	3.625354456773906
8168. 	there is an ancient and venerable tradition in the church	derives however from the heritage of the greeks rather than from	that god is completely independent of his creation and	so has no need of men for accomplishing his work in the world.	4.941234304076872
8169. by analogy	the church also has been regarded as entirely independent of the	world in the sense of requiring nothing from it in order to be	the church.	4.003702721296239
8170. but as scripture everywhere reminds us god does	have need of his creatures and the church a fortiori can ill afford	to do without the talents with which the world by god's providence	presents it.	5.286508357864882
8171. and yet this is exactly the risk we run when	we assume as we too often do that we can continue to preach the gospel	in a form that makes it seem incredible and irrelevant to cultured	men.	3.7071489941213445
8172. until we translate this gospel into a language that enlightened	men today can understand we are depriving ourselves of the very resources	on which the continued success of our witness most certainly depends.	5.033208254749959
8173. in arguing in this way we are obviously taking for granted	that a demythologized restatement of the kerygma can be achieved;	and that we firmly believe this will presently become evident when	we set forth reasons to justify such a conviction.	3.216523274401279
8174. but the main point	here is that even if such a restatement were not possible the	demand to demythologize the kerygma would still be unavoidable.	5.43497263762223
8175. this is what we mean when we say this demand must be accepted without	condition.	4.802942645150291
8176. if to be a christian means to say yes where i otherwise	say no or where i do not have the right to say anything at all then	my only choice is to refuse to be a christian.	6.721923896138535
8177. expressed differently:	if the price for becoming a faithful follower of jesus christ	is some form of self-destruction whether of the body or of the mind-	sacrificium corporis sacrificium intellectus- then there is	no alternative but that the price remain unpaid.	3.3502065739743756
8178. this must be	stressed because it is absolutely essential to the argument of this concluding	chapter.	6.98076672566372
8179. modern man as dietrich bonhoeffer has told us has	come of age; and though this process by no means represents	an unambiguous gain and is in fact marked by the estrangement from	the depths that seems to be the cost of human maturation it is still	a positive step forward; and those of us who so richly benefit from	it should be the last to despise it.	3.608540552351136
8180. in any event it is an irreversible	step and if we are at all honest with ourselves we will know we	have no other alternative than to live in the world in which god has	seen fit to place us.	6.459544757333374
8181. to say this of course is to take up a	position on one side of a controversy going on now for some two hundred	years or at any rate since the beginning of the distinctively modern	period in theological thought.	4.202111828948231
8182. we have aligned ourselves with that	liberal tradition in protestant christianity that counts among	the great names in its history those of schleiermacher ritschl	herrmann harnack and troeltsch and more recently schweitzer and	the early barth and in part at least bultmann.	4.611724063323505
8183. it is to this same	tradition that most of the creative figures in the last century and	a half of american theology also belong.	4.452081760393405
8184. for we must number here not	only the names of bushnell clarke and rauschenbusch not to mention	those of the chicago school and macintosh but those of	the brothers niebuhr and tillich as	well.	5.011751542787661
8185. finally we may also mention the several members of the self-consciously	neoliberal movement that developed at the university	of chicago and is heavily indebted philosophically to the creative work	of alfred north whitehead.	3.728351261600141
8186. what makes this long and diverse	tradition essentially one is that those who have belonged to it	have been profoundly in earnest about being modern men in a distinctively	modern world.	5.557481621290925
8187. although they have also been concerned to stand squarely	within the tradition of the apostolic church they have exhibited	no willingness whatever to sacrifice their modernity to their christianity.	3.598338487361833
8188. they have insisted rather on living fully and completely	within modern culture and so far from considering this treason to god	have looked upon it as the only way they could be faithful to him.	5.519925104759371
8189. when we say then that today in our situation the demand for	demythologization must be accepted without condition we are simply	saying that at least this much of the liberal tradition is an enduring	achievement.	3.926894871779476
8190. however much we may have to criticize liberal theology's	constructive formulations the theology we ourselves must strive	to formulate can only go beyond liberalism not behind it.	5.310670150385484
8191. in affirming this we have already taken the decisive step in breaking	the deadlock into which bultmann's attempt to formulate such a	theology has led.	3.408749048128274
8192. for we have said in effect that of the two alternatives	to his position variously represented by the other participants	in the demythologizing discussion only one is really an alternative.	6.096540244879174
8193. if the demand for demythologization is unavoidable and so must be	accepted	by theology unconditionally the position of the right is	clearly untenable.	4.086301289664318
8194. whereas bultmann's center position is structurally	inconsistent and is therefore indefensible on formal grounds	alone the general position of the right as represented say	by karl barth involves the rejection or at least qualification of	the demand for demythologization and so is invalidated on the material	grounds we have just considered.	5.036811364573823
8195. it follows then provided	the possibilities have been exhausted that the only real alternative	is the general viewpoint of the left which has been represented	on the continent by fritz buri and to some extent at least	is found in much that is significant in american and english theology.	3.4913377365388607
8196. in order to make the implications of our position as clear	as possible we may develop this argument at greater length.	6.306218779631675
8197. we	may show first that there cannot possibly be an alternative other	than the three typically represented by bultmann barth and buri.	3.5777564787477085
8198. to do this it is sufficient to point out that if the principle in terms	of which alternatives are to be conceived is such as to exclude more	than two then the question of a third possibility is a meaningless	question.	6.065872908963967
8199. thus if what is at issue is whether all s	is p it is indifferent whether some s is not p	or no s is p since in either case the judgment in question	is false.	3.4253179536910796
8200. hence if what is in question is whether in a given theology	myth is or is not completely rejected it is unimportant whether	only a little bit of myth or a considerable quantity is accepted;	for in either event the first possibility is excluded.	5.313349685220281
8201. therefore	the only conceivable alternatives are those represented on the one hand	by the two at least apparently self-consistent but mutually exclusive	positions of buri and barth and on the other hand by the third	but really pseudo position of bultmann.	3.442657803386906
8202. a second point requires more extended comment.	6.719325690920467
8203. it will be recalled	from the discussion in section 7 that the position of the right	as represented by barth rests on the following thesis: the	only tenable alternative to bultmann's position is a theology that	rejects or at least qualifies his unconditioned demand for demythologization	and existential interpretation; accepts instead a	special biblical hermeneutics or method of interpretation; and	in so doing frees itself to give appropriate emphasis to the event jesus	christ by means of statements that from bultmann's point of	view are mythological.	3.026180473297082
8204. one hundred years ago there existed in england the association	for the promotion of the unity of christendom.	6.02454822388303
8205. representing	as it did the efforts of only unauthorized individuals of the roman	and anglican churches and urging a communion of prayer unacceptable	to rome this association produced little fruit and in fact was	condemned by the holy office in 1864.	3.2297992127599313
8206. now again in 1961 in	england there is perhaps nothing in the religious sphere so popularly	discussed as christian unity.	5.497200538466723
8207. the church unity octave january	18-25 was enthusiastically devoted to prayer and discussion by the various	churches.	3.5182773778003265
8208. many people seem hopeful yet it is difficult to predict	whether or not there will be any more real attainment of christian	unity in 1961 than there was in 1861.	6.192004342063505
8209. but it must be readily seen	that the religious picture in england has so greatly changed during these	hundred years as to engender hope at least on the catholic side.	3.6919631691987562
8210. for the tide is well on the turn as the london catholic weekly	universe has written.	5.89540723169572
8211. i came to england last summer to	do research on the unpublished letters of cardinal newman.	4.11855048872668
8212. as an	american catholic of irish ancestry i came with certain preconceptions	and expectations; being intellectually influenced by newman	and the general 19th-century literature of england i knew only a	protestant-dominated	country.	4.714541601295105
8213. since arriving here however i have formed	a far different religious picture of present-day england.	3.789726644388646
8214. in representing	part of this new picture i will be recounting some of my	own personal experiences reactions and judgments; but my primary aim	is to transcribe what englishmen themselves are saying and writing	and implying about the roman and anglican churches and about the	present religious	state of england.	4.514293984947672
8215. since the protestant clergy for the	most part wear gray or some variant from the wholly black suit my roman	collar and black garb usually identify me in england as a roman	catholic cleric.	3.243283498163242
8216. in any case i have always been treated with the	utmost courtesy by englishmen even in devonshire and cornwall where	anti-catholic feeling has supposedly existed the strongest and longest.	5.070648995415523
8217. nowhere have i seen public expression of anti-catholicism.	4.451963187537693
8218. on my first guy fawkes day here i found catholics as well	as non-catholics celebrating with the traditional fireworks and bonfires	and was told that most englishmen either do not know or are not	concerned with the historical significance of the day.	5.264834872925978
8219. a birmingham	newspaper printed in a column for children an article entitled the	true story of guy fawkes which began:   when you	pile your	guy on the bonfire tomorrow night i wonder how much of the	true story of guy fawkes you will remember?	3.0284808563640615
8220.  in the 355 years since	the first guy fawkes night much of the story has been forgotten	so here is a reminder.	6.068468681904607
8221. the article proceeded to give an inaccurate	account of a catholic plot to kill king james 1.	3.3855137026552944
8222. in	spite of the increase in numbers and prestige brought about by the	conversions of newman and other tractarians of the 1840's and 1850's	the catholic segment of england one hundred years ago was a very	small one which did not enjoy a gracious	hearing from the general public.	4.8129926782692705
8223. the return of the catholic hierarchy	in 1850 was looked upon with indignant disapprobation and in fact	was charged with being a gesture of disloyalty.	3.2807120389771387
8224. in 1864 newman professedly	had to write his apologia with his keenest feelings in	order to be believed and to command a fair hearing from english readers.	4.918422929052227
8225. now in 1961 the catholic population of england is still	quite small; yet it represents a very	considerable percentage of the churchgoing population.	3.7716244478737524
8226. a protestant	woman marveled to me over the large crowds going in and out of the birmingham	oratory church on sunday mornings.	5.54081855933555
8227. she found	this a marvel because as she said only six per cent of english people	are churchgoers.	4.234923273259685
8228. she may not have been exact on this number but	others here feel quite certain that the percentage would be less than	ten.	6.228771359585714
8229. from many sides come remarks that protestant churches are badly	attended and the large medieval cathedrals look all but empty during	services.	3.648001780896767
8230. a catholic priest recently recounted how in the chapel of	a large city university following anglican evensong at which there	was a congregation of twelve he celebrated mass before more than a	hundred.	4.609519103832224
8231. the protestants themselves are the first to admit the	great falling off in effective membership in their churches.	3.511893549658629
8232. according	to a newspaper report of the 1961 statistics of the church of england	the total of confirmed members is 9748000 but only 2887671	are registered on the parochial church rolls and over 27 million	people in england are baptized into the church of england but	roughly only a tenth of them continue.	5.21963695327131
8233. an amazing article in the	manchester guardian of last november entitled fate of redundant	churches states than an archbishops' commission reported	last month that in the church of england alone there are 790	churches which are redundant now or will be in 20 years' time.	3.5366960897309143
8234. a further	260 anglican churches have been demolished since 1948.	5.7634996553823
8235. and	in the last five years the methodist chapel committee has	authorized	the demolition or more often the sale of 764 chapels.	3.8117970369425014
8236. most of	these former churches are now used as warehouses but neither anglicans	nor	nonconformists object to selling churches to roman catholics	and have done so.	5.177642425434288
8237. while it must be said that these same	protestants have built some new churches during this period and that	religious population shifts have emptied churches a principal reason	for this phenomenon of redundancy is that fewer protestants are	going to church.	3.4290361917163734
8238. it should be admitted too that there is a good	percentage of lapsed or nonchurchgoing catholics	.	7.006740847839243
8239. still it is clear from such reports and apparently clear	from the remarks of many people that protestants are decreasing and	catholics increasing.	3.7333439604165135
8240. an anglican clergyman in oxford sadly	but frankly acknowledged to me that this is true.	6.633057083654928
8241. a century ago	newman saw that liberalism would	gradually but definitely make its mark on english protestantism and	that even high anglicanism would someday no longer be a serviceable	breakwater against doctrinal errors more fundamental than its own.	3.0295770985516803
8242. that day is perhaps today 1961 and it seems no longer very meaningful	to call england a protestant country.	5.542659266849166
8243. one of the ironies	of the present crusade for christian unity is that there are not relatively	speaking many real christians to unite.	4.090059865202238
8244. many english	catholics are proud of their catholicism and know that they are	in a new ascendancy.	6.10383347095067
8245. the london universe devoted its centenary	issue	last december 8 to mapping out various aspects of catholic progress	during the last one hundred years.	3.0904651903760496
8246. with traditional nationalistic spirit	some englishmen claim that english catholicism is catholicism	at its best.	5.380980285930441
8247. i have found myself saying with other foreigners here	that english catholics are good catholics.	4.2017199352674695
8248. it has been my experience	to find as many men as women in church and to hear almost everyone	in church congregations reciting the latin prayers and responses	at mass.	5.273593845425918
8249. they hope of course to reclaim the non-catholic	population to the catholic faith and at every sunday benediction	they recite by heart the prayer for england:   o blessed	virgin mary mother of god and our most gentle queen and mother	look down in mercy upon england thy dowry and upon us	all who greatly hope and trust in thee h.	3.0262441016640587
8250. intercede for our separated	brethren that with us in the one true fold they may be united to the	chief shepherd the vicar of thy son h.	4.988571704288201
8251. a hymn often to be	heard in catholic churches is faith of our fathers which glories	in england's ancient faith that endured persecution and which	proclaims: faith of our fathers: mary's prayersshall win	our country back to thee.	2.9650377659578986
8252. the english saints are widely venerated	quite naturally and now there is great hope that the forty martyrs	and cardinal newman will soon be canonized.	5.20187723041949
8253. because they	have kept the faith of their medieval fathers english catholics have	always strongly resented the charge of being un-english.	3.8206458632882248
8254. i	have not seen this charge made during my stay here but apparently it	is still in the air.	5.492544892111676
8255. for example a writer in a recent number of the	queen hyperbolically states that of the myriad imprecations the	only one which the english catholics really resent is the suggestion	that they are 'un-english'.	3.7151114303996464
8256. in this connection it has been	observed that the increasing number of irish catholics priests and	laity in england while certainly seen as good for catholicism	is nevertheless a source of embarrassment for some of the more nationalistic	english catholics especially when these irishmen offer to remind	their christian brethren of this good.	4.988354587617201
8257. one of the	more noteworthy changes that have taken place since the mid-19th century	is the situation of catholics at oxford and cambridge universities.	3.706069854832126
8258. at oxford one hundred years ago there were very few catholics	partly because religious tests were removed only in 1854.	5.832608538041076
8259. moreover	for those few there was almost no ecclesiastical representation in the	city to care for their religious needs.	3.6119838552348535
8260. now not only are there considerably	more laity as students and professors at oxford but there	are also numerous houses of religious orders existing in respectable	and friendly relations with the non-catholic members of the university.	5.07465808363429
8261. some catholic priests lecture there; catholic seminarians attend	tutorials and row on the cherwell with non-catholic students.	3.370558041974044
8262. further evidence that roman catholicism enjoys a more favorable	position today than in 1861 is the respectful attention given to it	in the mass media of england.	5.154334243842565
8263. the general tone of articles appearing	in such important newspapers as the manchester guardian and the	sunday observer implies a kindly recognition that the catholic	church is now at least of equal stature in england with the protestant	churches.	3.114357943888293
8264. on successive sundays during october 1960 paul ferris	wrote articles in the observer depicting	clergymen of the church of england the church of rome and the nonconformist	church.	6.2505284206585605
8265. the catholic priest though somewhat superficially	drawn easily came out the best.	3.42575785417977
8266. there were many letters of strong	protest against the portrait of the anglican clergyman who was indeed	portrayed as a man not particularly concerned with religious matters	and without really very much to do as clergyman.	5.457768147956681
8267. such a series of	articles was certainly never printed in the public press of mid-victorian	england.	4.305157981857474
8268. there was so much interest shown in this present-day	venture that it was continued on bbc where comments were	equally made by an anglican parson a free church minister and a catholic	priest.	5.356245724400427
8269. catholic priests have frequently appeared on	television programs sometimes discussing the christian faith on an equal	footing with protestant clergymen.	3.4620640292427383
8270. a notable example of this was	the discussion of christian unity by the catholic archbishop of liverpool	dr heenan and the anglican archbishop of york dr	ramsey recently appointed archbishop of canterbury.	4.843480097897399
8271. the good	feeling which exists between these two important church figures is now	well known in england.	3.2152370865407938
8272. the holy sacrifice of the mass with commentary	has been televised several times in recent months.	4.852092498841711
8273. and it was	interesting to observe that bbc's television film on christmas	eve was the bells of st mary's.	3.7982601325477643
8274. of course	the crowning event that has dramatically upset the traditional pattern	of english religious history was the friendly visit paid by dr	fisher then anglican archbishop of canterbury to the vatican	last december.	4.937448836637945
8275. it was the first time an english primate has done	this since the 14th century.	4.723386085426696
8276. english catholics reacted to this event	with moderate but real hope.	5.705999550725924
8277. almost daily something is reported	which feeds this catholic hope in england: statistics of the increasing	numbers of converts and irish catholic immigrants; news of	a protestant minister in leamington who has offered to allow a catholic	priest to preach from his pulpit; a report that a catholic nun	had been requested to teach in a non-catholic secondary school during	the sickness of one of its masters; the startling statement in a	respectable periodical that catholics if the present system is still	in operation will constitute almost one-third of the house of lords	in the next generation; a report that 200 protestant clergymen	and laity attended a votive mass offered for christian unity at	a catholic church in slough during the church unity octave.	3.0172864634142296
8278. the death of a man is unique and yet it is universal.	8.218591088745924
8279. the straight	line would symbolize its uniqueness the circle its universality.	3.231121432866412
8280. but	how can one figure symbolize both?	6.341633976502356
8281.    christianity declares that	in the life and death of jesus christ the unique and the universal	concur.	4.43467298643805
8282. perhaps no church father saw this concurrence of the unique	and the universal as clearly or formulated it as precisely as irenaeus.	5.144553454432952
8283. to be the savior and the lord jesus christ has to be a historical	individual with a biography all his own; he dare not be a cosmic	aeon that swoops to earth for a while but never identifies itself	with man's history.	3.97274891990583
8284. yet this utterly individual historical person	must also contain within himself the common history of mankind.	5.629399713093427
8285. his	history is his alone yet each man must recognize his own history in	it.	3.720949788416813
8286. his death is his alone yet each man can see his own death in the	crucifixion of jesus.	5.65813533812995
8287. each man can identify himself with the history	and the death of jesus christ because jesus christ has identified	himself with human history and human death coming as the head of a	new humanity.	3.878207382447329
8288. not a circle then nor a straight line but a spiral	represents the shape of death as irenaeus sees it; for a spiral has	motion as well as recurrence.	5.933996444243517
8289. as represented by a spiral history may	in some sense be said to repeat itself; yet each historical event	remains unique.	3.8247107100639415
8290. christ is both unique and universal.	6.962256383113929
8291. the first	turn of the spiral is the primeval history of humanity in adam.	3.397624346323783
8292. as	origen interprets the end of history on the basis of its beginning	so irenaeus portrays the story of adam on the basis of the story of	christ.	6.756130370076014
8293. whence then comes the substance of the first man?	4.82949128355497
8294.  from	god's will and wisdom and from virgin earth.	6.3284508121654826
8295. for 'god had	not rained' says the scripture before man was made 'and there	was no man to till the earth'.	3.4264176013264627
8296. from this earth then while it was	still virgin god took dust and fashioned the man the beginning of humanity.	6.05098819892144
8297. irenaeus does not regard adam and eve merely as private	individuals but as universal human beings who were and are all of humanity.	3.626789496709123
8298. adam and eve were perfect not in the sense that they possessed	perfection but in the sense that they were capable of development	toward perfection.	7.086014215619438
8299. they were in fact children.	6.797347156866292
8300. irenaeus does not	claim pre-existence for the human soul; therefore there is no need for	him as there is for origen to identify existence itself with the	fall.	5.553042943882776
8301. existence is created and willed by god and is not the consequence	of a pre-existent rebellion or of a cosmic descent from eternity	into history.	3.754147403742143
8302. historical existence is a created good.	6.810997799768428
8303. the biblical	symbol for this affirmation is expressed in the words: so	god created man in his own image; in the similitude of god he created	him.	3.4258609314832613
8304. there are some passages in the writings of irenaeus where	the image of god and the similitude are sharply distinguished so	most notably in the statement: if the holy spirit is absent	from the soul such a man is indeed of an animal nature; and being	left carnal he will be an imperfect being possessing the image	of	god in his formation but not receiving the similitude of god	through the spirit.	5.083239911411595
8305. thus the image of god is that which makes	a man a man and not an oyster; the similitude of god by contrast	is that which makes a man a child of god and not merely a rational creature.	4.115568163732218
8306. recent research on irenaeus however makes it evident that	he does not consistently maintain this distinction.	5.270983442128048
8307. he does not mean	to say that adam lost the similitude of god and his immortality through	the fall; for he was created not exactly immortal nor yet exactly	mortal but capable of immortality as well as of mortality.	3.7603254033301563
8308. therefore irenaeus describes man's creation as follows:	so that the man should not have thoughts of grandeur and become lifted	up as if he had no lord because of the dominion that had been	given to him and the freedom fall into sin against god his creator	overstepping his bounds and take up an attitude of self-conceited arrogance	towards god a law was given him by god that he might know	that he had for lord the lord of all.	5.07909112322317
8309. and he laid down for him certain	conditions: so that if he kept the command of god then he would	always remain as he was that is immortal; but if he did not he	would become mortal melting into earth whence his frame had been taken.	3.681820086694886
8310. these conditions man did not keep and thus he became mortal;	yet he did not stop being human as a result.	5.842094821803883
8311. there is no justification	for systematizing the random statements of irenaeus about the image	of god beyond this nor for reading into his imprecise usage the	later theological distinction between the image of god and	the similitude of god.	3.366243195726864
8312. man was created with the	capacity for immortality but the devil's promise of immortality	in exchange for disobedience cost adam his immortality.	5.166070294298856
8313. he was in the	words of irenaeus beguiled by another under the pretext of immortality.	4.0354700152923915
8314. the true way to immortality lay through obedience but man	did not believe this.	4.847999854399326
8315. eve was disobedient; for she did	not obey when as yet she was a virgin.	3.798041858972891
8316. and even as she having indeed	a husband adam but being nevertheless as yet a virgin h having	become disobedient was made the cause of death both to herself and	to the entire human race; so also did mary having a man betrothed	to her and being nevertheless a virgin by yielding obedience become	the cause of salvation both to herself and the whole human race.	4.761509381884758
8317. because he interprets the primitive state of man as one of mere	potentiality or capacity and believes that adam and eve were created	as children irenaeus often seems inclined to extenuate their disobedience	as being due no doubt to carelessness but still wicked.	3.3898428042292923
8318. his interpretation of the beginning on the basis of the end prompts	him to draw these parallels between the virgin eve and the virgin	mary.	5.925366250929268
8319. that parallelism affects his picture of man's disobedience too;	for as it was christ the word of god who came to rescue man	so it was disobedience to the word of god in the beginning that brought	death into the world and all our woe.	4.246498571172371
8320. with this act of disobedience	and not with the inception of his individual existence man	began the downward circuit on the spiral of history descending from	the created capacity for immortality to an inescapable mortality.	4.8859984189912895
8321. at	the nadir of that circuit is death.	4.734367793699178
8322. along with the fruit they did	also fall under the power of death because they did eat in disobedience;	and disobedience to god entails death.	5.739789800739551
8323. wherefore as they became	forfeit to death from that moment they were handed over to it.	3.8499394668626157
8324. this leads irenaeus to the somewhat startling notion that adam	and eve died on the same day that they disobeyed namely on a friday	as a parallel to the death of christ on good friday; he sees	a parallel also to the jewish day of preparation for the sabbath.	4.980859923313252
8325. in	any case though they had been promised immortality if they ate of	the tree they obtained mortality instead.	3.7071499768775062
8326. the wages of sin is death.	6.251477478237253
8327. man's life originally shaped for immortality and for communion with	god must now be conformed to the shape of death.	3.470169739057462
8328. nevertheless	even at the nadir of the circuit the spiral of history belongs	to god and he still rules.	5.377130890722941
8329. even death therefore has a providential	as well as a punitive function.	4.609653802777423
8330. wherefore also he god	drove him man out of paradise and removed him far from the tree	of life not because he envied him the tree of life as some venture	to assert but because he pitied him and did not desire that	he should continue a sinner for ever nor that the sin which surrounded	him should be immortal and evil interminable and irremediable.	4.563319869960713
8331. but	he set a bound to his state of sin by interposing death and thus	causing sin to cease putting an end to it by the dissolution of the	flesh which should take place in the earth so that man ceasing at	length to live in sin and dying to it might live to god.	3.6342999568042305
8332. this	idea which occurs in both tatian and cyprian fits especially well	into the scheme of irenaeus' theology; for it prepares the way for	the passage from life through death to life that is achieved in christ.	4.628792249401666
8333. as man can live only by dying so it was only by his dying that	christ could bring many to life.	3.9616709353284922
8334. it is probably fair to say	that the idea of death is more profound in irenaeus than the idea of	sin is.	5.9959361745965944
8335. this applies to his picture of adam.	4.93682649808767
8336. it is borne out also	by the absence of any developed theory about how sin passes from one generation	to the next.	5.264071234164937
8337. it becomes most evident in his description of	christ as the second adam who does indeed come to destroy sin but	whose work culminates in the achievement of immortality.	3.4311294198157154
8338. this emphasis	upon death rather than sin as man's fundamental problem irenaeus	shares with many early theologians especially the greek-speaking ones.	4.761637175865806
8339. they speak of the work of christ as the bestowal of incorruptibility	which can mean deliverance from	time and history.	4.177877770397274
8340. death reminds man of his sin but it reminds	him also of his transience.	5.786199427901247
8341. it represents a punishment that he knows	he deserves but it also symbolizes most dramatically that he lives	his life within the process of time.	3.8283154294341615
8342. these two aspects of death cannot	be successfully separated but they dare not be confused or identified.	5.929405143969236
8343. the repeated efforts in christian history to describe death as	altogether the consequence of human sin show that these two aspects of	death cannot be separated.	3.269682195792774
8344. such efforts almost always find themselves	compelled to ask whether adam was created capable of growing old and	then older and then still older in short whether adam's life was	intended to be part of the process of time.	5.176131490968619
8345. if it was then it must	have been god's intention to translate him at a certain point from	time to eternity.	4.313839688223683
8346. one night so some of these theories run adam would	have fallen asleep much as he fell asleep for the creation of eve;	and thus he would have been carried over into the life eternal.	6.04636241588565
8347. the	embarrassment of these theories over the naturalness of death is an	illustration of the thesis that death cannot be only a punishment for	some termination seems necessary in a life that is lived within the	natural order of time and change.	3.4547764592500863
8348. on the other hand christian	faith knows that death is more than the natural termination of temporal	existence.	7.50190134706111
8349. it is the wages of sin and its sting is the law.	4.686543995963939
8350. if	this aspect of death as punishment is not distinguished from the idea	of death as natural termination the conclusion seems inevitable that	temporal existence itself is a form of punishment rather than the state	into which man is put by the will of the creator.	5.297026626162503
8351. this seems to have	been the conclusion to which origen was forced.	4.3565682643636805
8352. if death receives	more than its share of attention from the theologian and if sin receives	less than its share the gift of the life eternal through christ	begins to look like the divinely appointed means of rescue from temporal	ie created existence.	5.193788875788862
8353. such an interpretation of death radically	alters the christian view of creation; for it teaches salvation	from not salvation in time and history.	3.7058999640276453
8354. because christianity	teaches not only salvation in history but salvation by the history of	christ such an interpretation of death would require a drastic revision	of the christian understanding of the work of christ.	5.768583940038669

8356. the unitarian clergy were	an exclusive club of cultivated gentlemen- as the term was then understood	in the back bay- and parker was definitely not a gentleman	either in theology or in manners.	4.334547928676315

8591. thus while it remains possible that the babylonians andor	the pythagoreans may perhaps have had the magic square of three before	the chinese did more definite evidence will have to turn up from	the middle east or the classical world before china can lose her	claim to the earliest known magic square by more than a thousand years.	3.390564842834179
8592. the	concept of the middle kingdom at peace strong and united under a	forceful ruler which had been only a longed-for ideal in the time of	the	warring states was finally realized by the establishment of a chinese	empire under the ch'in dynasty.	5.126619940166021
8593. but this	was only accomplished by excessive cruelty and extremes of totalitarian	despotism.	3.8126636758931545
8594. among the many severe measures taken by the first emperor	shih huang-ti in his efforts to insure the continuation of	this hard-won national unity was the burning of the books in 213 bc	with the expressed intention of removing possible sources for	divergent thinking; but as he had a special fondness for magic and	divination he ordered that books on these subjects should be spared.	4.767577334979239
8595. many of the latter were destroyed in their turn during the burning	of the vast ch'in palace some ten years later; yet some must have	survived because the old interest in number symbolism divination	and magic persisted on into the han dynasty which succeeded in reuniting	china and keeping it together for a longer period	.	3.189367165473345
8596. in fact during	the first century bc an extensive literature sprang up devoted	to these subjects finding its typical expression in the so-called	wei books a number of which were specifically devoted to	the lo shu and related numerical diagrams especially in connection	with divination.	4.917973242323508
8597. however the wei books were also destroyed	in a series of orthodox confucian purges which culminated in a final	proscription in 605.	3.67090209416397
8598. after all this destruction of old literature	it should be obvious why we have so little information about the	early history and development of the lo shu which was already	semisecret anyhow.	5.744135694986914
8599. but in spite of all this enough evidence remains	to show that the magic square of three must indeed have been the object	of a rather extensive cult- or series of cults- reaching fullest	expression in the han period.	3.748108702864552
8600. although modern scholars have	expressed surprise that the simple magic square of three a mere	mathematical puzzle was able to exert a considerable influence	on the minds and imaginations of the cultured chinese for so many centuries	they could have found most of the answers right within the square	itself.	5.124701363244342
8601. but up to now no one has attempted to analyze its inherent	mathematical properties or the numerical significance of its numbers-	singly or in combination- and then tried to consider these in	the light of old chinese cosmological concepts.	3.2719387001303395
8602. such an analysis	speedily reveals why the middle number of the lo shu 5	was so vitally significant for the chinese ever since the earliest hints	that they had a knowledge of this diagram.	5.880746835400831
8603. the importance of this	5 can largely be explained by the natural mathematical properties of	the middle number and its special relationship to all the rest of the	numbers- quite apart from any numerological considerations which is	to say any symbolic meaning arbitrarily assigned to it.	3.1945116988135998
8604. indeed mathematically	speaking it was both functionally and symbolically the most	important number in the entire diagram.	5.716019820085671
8605. if one takes the middle	number 5 and multiplies it by 3	the result is 15 which is also the constant sum of	all the rows columns and two main diagonals.	3.59043368440121
8606. then if the middle number	is activated to its greatest potential in terms of this square through	multiplying it by the highest number 9	the result is 45; and the latter is the total sum	of all the numbers in the square by which all the other numbers are	overshadowed and in which they may be said to be absorbed.	6.020610775741119
8607. furthermore	the middle number of the lo shu is not only the physical	mean between every opposing pair of the other numbers by reason of	its central position; it is also their mathematical mean since it	is equal to half the sum of every opposing pair all of which equal 10.	3.7429478346254883
8608. in fact the neat balance of these pairs and their subtle equilibrium	would have had special meaning in the minds of the old chinese.	6.066873712547195
8609. for they considered the odd numbers as male and the even ones as female	equating the two groups with the yang and yin principles in nature;	and in this square the respective pairs made up of large and	small odd numbers and those composed of large and small even	numbers were all equal to each other.	3.2123601663963575
8610. thus all differences were	leveled and all contrasts erased in a realm of no distinction and	the harmonious balance of the lo shu square could effectively	symbolize the world in balanced harmony around a powerful central axis.	5.275508590845725
8611. the tremendous emphasis on the 5 in the lo shu square-	for purely mathematical reasons- and the fact that this number so	neatly symbolized the heart and center of the universe could well explain	why the old chinese seem to have so revered the number 5 and	why they put so much stress on the concept of centrality.	3.746464545865706
8612. these twin	tendencies seem to have reached their height in the han dynasty.	6.8090070896844725
8613. the existing reverence for centrality must have been still further	stimulated toward the close of the second century bc when	the han emperor wu ti ordered the dynastic color changed to yellow-	which symbolized the center among the traditional five directions-	and took 5 as the dynastic number believing that he would thus	place himself his imperial family and the nation under the most auspicious	influences.	3.1078109147962807
8614. his immediate motive for doing this may not have	been directly inspired by the lo shu but this measure must inevitably	have increased the existing beliefs in the latter's efficacy.	5.215406476624809
8615. after this time inscriptions on the han bronze mirrors as well	as other writings emphasized the desirability of keeping one's	self at the center of the universe where cosmic forces were strongest.	3.7976329322496243
8616. later we shall see what happened when an emperor took this idea too	literally.	6.751525281022383
8617. all this emphasis on centrality and on the number	5 as a symbolic expression of the center which seems to have begun	as far back as 400 bc also may conceivably have led to the development	of the five-elements school and the subsequent efforts to	fit everything into numerical categories of five.	3.568987383268517
8618. we find for example	such groupings as the five ancient rulers the five sacred mountains	the five directions the five metals five	colors five tastes five odors five musical notes five	bodily functions five viscera and many others.	4.606808967283235
8619. this trend has	often been ascribed to the cult of the five elements itself as though	they had served as the base for all the rest; but why did the old	chinese postulate five elements when the ancient near east-	which may have initiated the idea that natural elements exerted influence	in human life and activities- recognized only four?	3.2555930214496986
8620.  and why	did the chinese suddenly begin to talk about the five directions	when the animals they used as symbols of the directions designated only	the usual four?	5.179116082811465
8621.  obviously something suddenly caused them to start	thinking in terms of fives and that may have been the workings of	the lo shu.	4.2776860748640635
8622. this whole tendency had an unfortunate effect	on chinese thinking.	6.136348627892933
8623. whereas the primary meanings of the lo shu	diagram seemed to have been based on its inner mathematical properties-	and we shall see that even its secondary meanings rested on	some mathematical bases- the urgent desire to place everything into	categories of fives led to other groupings based on other numbers until	an exaggerated emphasis on mere numerology pervaded chinese thought.	3.170734928657784
8624. scholars made numbered sets of as many things as possible in nature	or assigned arbitrary numbers to individual things in a fashion that	seems to the modern scientific mind as downright nonsensical and	philosophical ideas based upon all this tended to stifle speculative thought	in china for many centuries.	4.51511312886481
8625. square	although the primary mathematical properties of the middle	number at the center of the lo shu and the interrelation	of all the other numbers to it might seem enough to account for the deep	fascination which the lo shu held for the old chinese philosophers	this was actually only a beginning of wonders.	3.91682508490039
8626. for the lo	shu square was a remarkably complete compendium of most of the chief	religious and philosophical ideas of its time.	5.966464566199301
8627. as such one cannot	fully understand the thought of the pre-han and han periods without	knowing the meanings inherent in the lo shu; but conversely	one cannot begin to understand the lo shu without knowing something	about the world view of the old chinese which they felt they	saw expressed in it.	3.6252210131144285
8628. the chinese world view during the han dynasty	when the lo shu seems to have been at the height of its	popularity was based in large part on the teachings of the yin-yang	and five-elements school which was traditionally founded by tsou	yen.	5.182662757701921
8629. according to this doctrine the universe was ruled by heaven	t'ien- as a natural force or in the personification of a supreme	sky-god- governing all things by means of a process called the	tao	which can be roughly interpreted as the order of the universe	or the universal way.	3.6019551197328727
8630. heaven acting through the tao	expressed itself by means of the workings of two basic principles	the yin and the yang.	5.373695257694681
8631. the yang or male principle was the source	of light heat and dynamic vitality associated with the sun; while	the yin or female principle flourished in darkness cold and quiet	inactivity and was associated with the moon.	3.0942252193977122
8632. together these two	principles influenced all things and in varying combinations they were	present in everything.	5.660509785022628
8633. we have already seen that odd numbers	were considered as being yang while the even numbers were yin so	that the eight outer numbers of the lo shu represented these two	principles in balanced equilibrium around the axial center.	3.355941318270059
8634. during	the han dynasty another yin-yang conception was applied to the lo	shu considering the latter as a plan of ancient china.	5.626517734363266
8635. instead	of linking the nine numbers of this diagram with the traditional nine	provinces as was usually	done this equated the odd yang numbers	with mountains and the even numbers	with rivers; taking the former	from the five sacred mountains of the han period and the latter from	the principal river systems of old china.	3.2431814888722994
8636. thus the middle	number 5 represented sung-shan in honan central china; the	3 t'ai-shan in shantung east china; the 7 hwa-shan in shensi	west china; the 1 heng-shan in hopei north china	; and the	9 huo-shan in anhwei which was then the south sacred mountain.	4.340195063134371
8637. for the rivers the 4 represented the huai to the southeast;	the 2 the san kiang southwest;	the 8 the chi in the northeast; and the 6 the yellow river	in the northwest.	3.2535610345970336
8638. note that by western standards this	plan was upside down as it put north at the bottom and south	at the top with the other directions correspondingly altered; but in	this respect it was merely following the accepted chinese convention	for all maps.	4.886174697804212

8716. a study	of major denominational membership statistics over a twenty-year period	revealed the appalling fact that nearly 40 per cent of those who	joined the church were lost to the church within seven years.	5.04217920290785

8743. institutions require structure form and definition	and these in turn entail differentiation and exclusion.	3.486213068171733
8744. a completely	amorphous institution would be a contradiction in terms; to escape	this fate it must rule some things out.	5.193592720874966
8745. for every criterion which	defines what something is at the same time proclaims- implicitly if	not openly- what that something is not.	3.873975947820837

8760. 	i shall touch on three areas: personal national and theological.	5.433193905713204

8795. i turn finally to several theological developments.	4.530342211830119

8812. my	father went as a missionary to china in a generation that responded	to student volunteer movement speakers who held watches in their hands	and announced to the students in their audiences how many chinese	souls were going to hell each second because these students were not	over there saving them.	4.436991055195387

8817. the roman catholic church has excommunicated one of	its priests father feeney for insisting that there is no salvation	outside the visible church.	3.4979798686391765
