8819. when they say that under no circumstances would it ever be right to permit	the termination of the human race by human action because	there could not possibly be any proportionate grave reason to justify	such a thing they know exactly what they mean.	3.5612591131771603
8820. of course in prudential	calculation in balancing the good directly intended and done against	the evil unintended and indirectly done no greater precision can	be forthcoming than the subject allows.	5.014212235563569
8821. yet it seems clear that there	can be no good sufficiently great or evil repelled sufficiently grave	to warrant the destruction of mankind by man's own action.	3.5503861798593124
8822. i mean however that the moral theologian knows what he means by permit.	6.5511804521597155
8823. he is not talking in the main about probabilities risks	and danger in general.	4.30941513982152
8824. he is talking about an action which just as efficaciously	does an evil thing	as it efficaciously does some good.	5.597036637602382
8825. he	is talking about double effects of which the specific action causes	directly the one and indirectly the other but causes both;	of which one is deliberately willed or intended and the other not intended	or not directly intended but still both are done while the	evil effect is with equal consciousness on the part of the agent foreknown	to be among the consequences.	3.2807316177655834
8826. this is what in a technical sense	to only permit an evil result means.	6.393070605987803
8827. it means to do it	and to know one is doing it but as only a secondary if certain effect	of the good one primarily does and intends.	3.7224483283591994
8828. of course grave guiltiness	may be imputed to the military action of any nation or to the action	of any leader or leaders which for any supposed good permits	in this sense the termination of the human race by human action.	5.137557627857296
8829. certainly in analyzing an action which truly faced such alternatives	it is never possible that no world would be preferable to	some worlds and there are in truth no circumstances in which the	destruction of human life presents itself as a reasonable alternative.	3.450707466617066
8830. naturally where one or the other of the effects of an action	is uncertain this has to be taken into account.	7.24409497609562
8831. especially is this	true when because the good effect is remote and speculative while	the evil is certain and grave the action is prohibited.	3.547159999996778
8832. presumably	if the reverse is the case and the good effect is more certain than the	evil result that may be forthcoming not only must the good and the	evil be prudentially weighed and found proportionate but also calculation	of the probabilities and of the degree of certainty or uncertainty	in the good or evil effect must be taken into account.	5.065907783721863
8833. there must	not only be greater good than evil objectively in view but also greater	probability of actually doing more good than harm.	3.5329028044174717
8834. if an evil which	is certain and extensive and immediate may rarely be compensated for	by a problematic speculative future good by the same token not every	present certain and immediate good that may have	to be done will be outweighed by a problematic speculative and future	evil.	4.6759537448410455
8835. nevertheless according to the traditional theory a man begins	in the midst of action and he analyzes its nature and immediate cosequences	before or while putting it forth and causing these consequences.	3.647447032740881
8836. he does not expect to be able to trammel up all the future consequences	of his action.	6.8113466820181765
8837. above all he does not debate mere contingencies	and therefore if these are possibly dreadful find himself forced	into inaction.	3.9131476282023216
8838. he does what he can and may and must without regarding	himself as lord of the future or on the other hand as covered with	guilt by accident or unforeseen consequences or by results he did not	permit in the sense explained.	5.566630151038549
8839. by contrast a good deal of nuclear	pacifism begins with the contingencies and the probabilities and	not with the moral nature of the action to be done; and by deriving	legitimate decision backward from whatever may conceivably or possibly	or probably result whether by anyone's doing or by accident	it finds itself driven to inaction to non-political action in politics	and non-military action in military affairs and to the not very surprising	discovery that there are now no distinctions on which the defense	of justice can possibly be based.	3.263306065481751
8840. mr philip toynbee	writes for example that in terms of probability it is surely as	likely as not that mutual fear will lead to accidental war in the near	future if the present situation continues.	5.500045648032347
8841. if it continues indefinitely	it is nearly a statistical certainty that a mistake will	be made and that the devastation will begin.	4.124018771691099
8842. against such a termination	of human life on earth by human action he then proposes as an	alternative that we negotiate at once with the russians and get the	best terms which are available that we deliberately negotiate	from comparative weakness.	5.111006578503266
8843. he bravely attempts to face this alternative	realistically ie by considering the worst possible outcome	namely the total domination of the world by russia within a few	years.	3.5971459523264637
8844. this would be by far the better choice when it is a question	of allowing the human race to survive possibly under the domination	of a regime which most of us detest or of allowing it to	destroy itself in appalling and prolonged anguish.	5.597730616548977
8845. nevertheless the	consequence of the policy proposed is everywhere subtly qualified:	it is a possible result however improbable; the worst and	least probable result; if it didn't prevail mankind would	still be given the opportunity of prevailing; for surely	anything is better than a policy which allows for the possibility	of nuclear war.	3.1974676726793816
8846. if we have not thought and made a decision entirely	in these terms then we need to submit ourselves to the following	simple test: have we decided how we are to kill the other	members of our household in the event of our being less injured than	they are?	5.426986740972607
8847.  thus moral decision must be entirely deduced backward	from the likely eventuality; it is no longer to be formulated in terms	of the nature of present action itself its intention and proximate	effect or the thing to be done.	3.7197121621291487
8848. several of the replies	to mr toynbee without conscious resort to the traditional terminology	with regard to the permission of evil succeed in restoring the	actual context in which present moral and political decisions must be	made by distinguishing between choosing a great evil and choosing in	danger of this evil.	4.693961092463189
8849. it is worse for a nation to give in to evil	h than to run the risk of annihilation.	4.096987987335875

8853. if	asked to choose between a terrible probability and a more terrible possibility	most men will choose the latter.	3.609148297075407
8854. if h philip toynbee	is claiming that the choice lies between capitulation and the risk	of nuclear war i think he is right.	5.3940019814661815
8855. i do not accept that the choice	is between capitulation and the certainty of nuclear war.	4.153523496590174
8856. even	professor arnold toynbee agreeing with his son does so in these	terms: compared to continuing to incur a constant risk of	the destruction of the human race all other evils are lesser evils h.	4.985453938697355

8858. mr	philip toynbee affirms at one point that if he shared the	anticipations of orwell in nineteen eighty-four if he believed	communism was not only evil but also irredeemably evil then	he might think it right to do anything rather than to take the	risk of a communist world.	5.065490811758516

8860. no political order or economic system is	so clearly contrary to nature.	5.89027920378574
8861. but one does not have to affirm the existence	of an evil order irredeemable in that sense or a static order	in which no changes will take place in time to be able truthfully to	affirm the following fact: there has never been justitia imprinted	in social institutions and social relationships except in the context	of some pax-ordo preserved by clothed or naked force.	3.451305234033413

8954. you know that i could hold right here in my	hand the little chunk of uranium metal that was the heart of the bomb	that dropped on hiroshima.	6.258875016141192
8955. it was only about the size of a baseball;	but packed in that metallic ball there was the explosive force of	20000 tons of tnt.	4.096123954844501

8960. we know that we have hydrogen in water; water is	f and the h stands for hydrogen; there is also hydrogen in wood	and hydrogen in our bodies.	5.559119899374723

8973. to grasp our new view of the atom we have to appreciate	first of all how small the atom is.	4.363709846017639
8974. i have been trying to make this	clear to my own class in chemistry.	6.756806607773916
8975. one night there were some dried	peas lying on our kitchen table and these peas looked to me like a little	group of atoms; and i asked myself a question: suppose i	had the same number of peas as there are atoms in my body how large an	area would they cover?	3.312600557560231
8976.    i calculated first that there are	about an octillion atoms in the average human body; that is a figure	one with 27 ciphers quite a large number.	5.368524663042383
8977. then i calculated that a	million peas would just about fill a household refrigerator; a billion	peas would fill a small house from cellar to attic; a trillion peas	would fill all the houses in a town of about ten thousand people;	and a quadrillion peas would fill all the buildings in the city of philadelphia.	3.3899085787550405
8978. i saw that i would soon run out of buildings at	this rate so i decided to take another measure- the whole state of	pennsylvania.	5.657357604983391
8979. imagine that there is a blizzard over pennsylvania	but instead of snowing snow it snows peas; so we get the whole state	covered with peas about four feet deep.	3.6748191927758773
8980. you can imagine what it would	look like going out on the turnpike with the peas banked up against	the houses and covering the cars; pennsylvania thus blanketed would	contain about a quintillion peas.	5.071160721183453
8981. but we still have a long	way to go.	5.223165614842378

8983. next we freeze over the oceans and cover the whole	earth with peas then we go out among the neighboring stars collect	250 planets each the size of the earth and also cover each of these	with peas four feet deep; and then we have septillion.	3.5681039431271784
8984. finally we	go into the farthest reaches of the milky way; we get 250000 planets;	we cover each of these with our blanket of peas and then at last	we have octillion peas corresponding in number to the atoms in the body.	4.836945602707771
8985. so you see how small an atom is and how complicated you are.	4.5510373075499855
8986. speck- and space	now although an atom is small we can still in	imagination have a look at it.	5.5150435725147995
8987. let us focus on an atom of calcium from	the tip of the bone of my finger and let us suppose that i swallow	a magic alice in wonderland growing pill.	3.5770063095030658

8990. then this atom of calcium will swell to something	like a great balloon a hundred yards across a balloon big enough	to put a football field inside.	5.146361031279346
8991. and if you should step inside of such	a magnified atom according to the physics of forty years ago you	would see circulating over your head down at the sides and under your	feet some twenty luminous balls about the size of footballs.	3.6377609690474015
8992. these	balls are moving in great circles and ellipses and are of course the	electrons the particles of negative electricity which by their action	create the forces that tie this atom of calcium to the neighboring	atoms of oxygen and make up the solid structure of my finger bone.	4.664763033977466
8993. since these electrons are moving like planets you may wonder whether	there is an atomic sun at the center of the atom.	4.05946472227831
8994. so you look down	there and you see a tiny whirling point about the size of the head	of a pin.	6.682420406028676
8995. this is the atomic sun the atomic nucleus.	5.005368701538828
8996. even if the	atom were big enough to hold a football field this nucleus is still	only about the size of a pinhead.	6.393131527370121
8997. it is this atomic nucleus that contains	the positive charge of electricity holding these negatively charged	electrons in their orbits; it also contains nearly all the mass	and the atomic energy.	3.3226326053495465
8998. you may ask what else there is and the	answer is nothing- nothing but empty space.	6.097697215660795
8999. and since you are made	of atoms you are nothing much but empty space too.	3.9393891070901406
9000. if i could put	your body in an imaginary atomic press and squeeze you down squeeze	these holes out of you in the way we squeeze the holes out of a sponge	you would get smaller and smaller until finally when the last hole	was gone you would be smaller than the smallest speck of dust that you	could see on this piece of paper.	5.214026530083212
9001. someone has remarked that this is	certainly the ultimate in reducing.	4.243034002932259
9002. at any rate it shows us how immaterial	we are.	7.18395234884346
9003. now this 1920 view of the	atom was on the whole a discouraging picture.	4.58218209373365
9004. for we believed that the	electrons	obeyed the law of mechanics and electrodynamics; and therefore	the atom was really just a little machine; and in mechanics the	whole is no more than the sum of the parts.	5.593217334319528
9005. so if you are made of	atoms you are just a big machine; and since the universe is also made	of atoms it is just a supermachine.	4.236858926724296
9006. and this would mean that we	live in a mechanistic universe governed by the laws of cause and effect	bound in chains of determinism that hold the universe on a completely	predetermined course in which there is not room for soul or spirit	or human freedom.	5.276686349010678

9010. and to see the meaning of this new picture imagine	that you can put on more powerful glasses and go back inside the atom	and have a look at it in the way we view it today.	6.722878808394863
9011. now as you step	inside instead of seeing particles orbiting around like planets you	see waves and ripples very much like the ripples that you get on the surface	of a pond when you drop a stone into it.	3.338550648586956
9012. these ripples spread	out in symmetrical patterns like the rose windows of a great cathedral.	5.733217260092315
9013. and as the waves flow back and forth and merge with the waves from	the neighboring atoms you can put on a magic hearing aid and you hear	music.	3.936421989383851
9014. it is a music like the music from a great organ or a vast orchestra	playing a symphony.	5.836234596249479
9015. harmony melody counterpoint symphonic structure	are there; and as this music ebbs and flows there is an antiphonal	chorus from all the atoms outside in fact from the atoms of	the entire universe.	3.349163965516239
9016. and so today when we examine the structure of our	knowledge of the atom and of the universe we are forced to conclude	that the best word to describe our universe is music.	6.056564604750608
9017. the island of nantucket part of the state of massachusetts	lies about thirty-one miles southeast of its mother state.	4.24054817115986

9024.  how far	and in what fashion did it modify the new nation which was emerging	in the midst of the forces shaping the revolutionary age?	5.542781983188159
9025.  to what	extent did it mould the morals and the social economic and political	life and institutions of the country?	3.912844509033446
9026.    a complete picture is	impossible- partly because of the limitations of space partly because	for millions of individuals who professed allegiance to the christian	faith data are unobtainable.	5.221698887257819
9027. even more of an obstacle is the difficulty	of separating the influence of christianity from other factors.	4.273872406560835
9028. although a complete picture cannot be given we can indicate	some aspects of life into which the christian faith entered as at	least one creative factor.	5.810298826770492
9029. at times we can say that it was the major	factor.	6.668766486511722
9030. what in some ways was the most important aspect was the	impact individually on the millions who constituted the nation.	6.3211785382123455
9031. as	we have seen a growing proportion although in 1914 still a minority	were members of churches.	3.6636289996537243
9032. presumably those who did not have a formal	church connexion had also felt the influence of christianity to a greater	or less extent.	5.896898079024392
9033. many of them had once been members of a church	or at least had been given instruction in christianity but for one or	another reason had allowed the connexion to lapse.	3.8262401408073274
9034. the form of christianity	to which they were exposed was for some the protestantism of	the older stock for others the protestantism of the nineteenth-century	immigration; for still others mostly of the nineteenth-century	immigration it was roman catholicism and for a small minority it was	eastern orthodoxy.	4.980204538299815
9035. upon all of them played the intellectual social	political and economic attitudes institutions and customs of the	nation.	4.0568078253667625
9036. upon most of these christianity had left an impress and through	them had had a share in making the individual what he was.	5.937394397700776
9037. yet	to determine precisely to what extent and exactly in what ways any individual	showed the effects of christianity would be impossible.	3.712056976292074
9038. at	best only an approximation could be arrived at.	5.990913012755567
9039. to generalize for the	entire nation would be absurd.	4.5970872637003115
9040. for instance we cannot know whether	even for church members the degree of conformity to christian standards	of morality increased or declined as the proportion of church members	in the population rose.	5.1394705820425015
9041. the temptation is to say that as the percentage	of church members mounted the degree of discipline exercised	by the churches lessened and the trend was towards conformity to the general	level.	3.4661072401742796
9042. yet this cannot be proved.	8.794206041909641
9043. we know that in the early part	of the century many protestant congregations took positive action	against members who transgressed the ethical codes to which the majority	subscribed.	4.1158299482336504
9044. thus baptist churches on the frontier took cognizance	of charges against their members of drunkenness fighting malicious	gossip lying cheating sexual irregularities gambling horse racing	and failure to pay just debts.	4.634312066244135
9045. if guilty the offender might be excluded	from membership.	4.413175576135157
9046. as church membership burgeoned such measures	faded into desuetude.	6.532619759430031
9047. but whether this was accompanied by a general	lowering of the moral life of the membership we do not know.	4.690980920349905
9048. what	we can attempt with some hope of dependable conclusions is to point	out the manner in which christianity entered into particular aspects	of the life of the nation.	5.192655627076794
9049. we have already hinted at the fashion in	which christianity contributed to education and so to intellectual life.	4.094014137141277
9050. we will now speak of the ways in which it helped shape the ideals	of the country and of the manner in which it stimulated efforts to attain	those ideals through reform movements through programmes for bringing	the collective life to the nation to conformity to christian standards	and through leaders in the government.	5.644504246658879
9051. throughout the	nineteenth century christianity exerted its influence on american	society as a whole primarily through the protestantism of the older stock.	3.864343313877749
9052. by the end of the century the roman catholic church was beginning	to make itself felt mainly through such institutions as hospitals	but also through its attitude towards organized labour.	5.6681062341997155
9053. in the twentieth	century its influence grew as did that of the protestantism of	the nineteenth-century immigration.	4.190767005662243
9054. the ideals	of the country were deeply indebted to the protestantism of the	older stock.	5.392326526371498
9055. thus america the most widely sung of the patriotic	songs was written by a new england baptist clergyman samuel francis	smith while a student in andover theological	seminary.	3.6154497873378486
9056. with its zeal for liberty and its dependence on god it	breathed the spirit which had been nourished on the evangelical revivals.	5.773803636911873
9057. the great seal of the united states was obviously inspired by	the christian faith.	4.5762399334717765
9058. here was what was called the american dream namely	the effort to build a structure which would be something new in	history and to do so in such fashion that god could bless it.	6.107870271848775
9059. later	in the century the dream again found expression in the lines of katherine	lee bates daughter and granddaughter of new england	congregational ministers in her widely sung hymn written in	1893 america the beautiful with the words o beautiful	for pilgrim feet whose stern impassioned stress a thoroughfare for freedom	beat across the wilderness.	2.9413188487135455
9060. america america god mend	thy every flaw confirm thy soul in self control thy liberty in law	h.	5.165961192160646
9061. o beautiful for patriot dream that sees beyond the years thine	alabaster cities gleam undimmed by human tears.	3.5995426633056025
9062. america america	god shed his grace on thee and crown thy good with brotherhood from	sea to shining sea.	5.051781093731932
9063. the american dream was compounded of	many strains.	4.5335697526019025
9064. some were clearly of christian origin among them the	great awakening and other revivals which helped to make christian	liberty christian equality and christian fraternity the passion of	the land.	4.737063947800106
9065. some have seen revivalism and the search for christian perfection	as the fountain-head of the american hope.	4.426909832019815
9066. here too must	be placed unitarianism and less obviously from christian inspiration	emerson transcendentalism and the idealism of walt whitman.	5.186711270952466
9067. we	must also remember those who reacted against the dream as a kind of	myth- among them melville hawthorne and henry james the elder	all of them out of a christian background.	3.65894205224539
9068. with	such a dream arising at least in part from the protestant heritage	of the united states and built into the foundations of the nation	it is not surprising that many efforts were made to give it concrete	expression.	5.526494538161941
9069. a number were in the nature of movements to relieve or	remove social ills.	4.812908360781094
9070. significantly the initiation and leadership	of a major proportion of the reform movements especially those in	the first half of the nineteenth century came from men and women of	new england birth or parentage and from either trinitarian or unitarian	congregationalism.	5.110470454816246
9071. several of the movements were given a marked	impetus by revivalism.	4.600949183253204
9072. quakers some from new england had a larger	share than their proportionate numerical strength would have warranted.	5.16102864858669
9073. we do well to remind ourselves that from men and women of new england	ancestry also issued the church of jesus christ of latter	day saints the seventh day adventists christian science the	american board of commissioners for foreign missions the american	home missionary society the american bible society and new	england theology.	3.5021811592874097
9074. the atmosphere was one of optimism of confidence	in human progress and of a determination to rid the world of its ills.	5.663311846816423
9075. the hopkinsian universal disinterested benevolence although holding	to original sin and the doctrine of election inspired its adherents	to heroic endeavours for others looked for the early coming of the	millennium and was paralleled by the confidence in man's ability	cherished by the unitarians emerson and the transcendentalists.	2.8872597182831754
9076. we should recall the number of movements for the service of mankind	which arose from the kindred evangelicalism of the british isles	and the pietism of the continent of europe- among them prison	reform anti-slavery measures legislation for the alleviation of conditions	of labour the inner mission and the red cross.	4.989608457286198
9077. we	cannot take the space to record all the efforts for the removal or alleviation	of collective ills.	3.7844059446659277
9078. a few of the more prominent must serve	as examples of what a complete listing and description would disclose.	6.1334331776707485
9079. several were born in the early decades and persisted throughout the	century.	5.048708099522321
9080. some disappeared with the attainment	of their purpose.	6.802867475258417
9081. still others sprang up late in the century to meet	conditions which arose from fresh stages of the revolutionary age.	3.8513794506074817
9082. anti-slavery movement	the movement to end negro slavery began	before 1815 and mounted after that year until as a result of the civil	war emancipation was achieved.	5.282725635788271
9083. long before 1815 the christian	conscience was leading some to declare slavery wrong and to act	accordingly.	3.737799652415107
9084. for example in 1693 the philadelphia yearly meeting	of friends declared that its members should emancipate their slaves	and in 1776 it determined to exclude from membership all who did not	comply.	4.885584950055791
9085. in the latter year samuel hopkins from whom the hopkinsian	strain of new england theology took its name asked the continental	congress to abolish slavery.	3.542858999649633
9086. as we have seen methodism early took	a stand against slavery.	7.002702045774841
9087. beginning at least as far back as 1789 various	baptist bodies condemned slavery.	4.205222563678785
9088. after 1815 anti-slavery	sentiment mounted chiefly among protestants and those of protestant	background of the older stock.	6.065893259457422
9089. the nineteenth-century immigration	whether protestant or roman catholic was not so much concerned	for very few if any among them held slaves: they were mostly in the	northern states where slavery had disappeared or was on the way out	or were too poverty-stricken to own slaves.	3.2867230755040975
9090. the anti-slavery movement	took many forms.	5.509976713481443
9091. benjamin lundy a quaker was	a pioneer in preparing the way for anti-slavery societies.	3.9354948536472
9092. it was	he who turned the attention of william lloyd garrison	to the subject.	6.1618260034931165
9093. garrison massachusetts born of nova scotian parentage	was by temperament and conviction a reformer.	3.3917148076699317
9094. chiefly remembered	because of his incessant advocacy of immediate and unconditional	abolition he also espoused a great variety of other causes- among	them women's rights prohibition and justice to the indians.	4.604888505592632
9095. incurably	optimistic dogmatic and utterly fearless in his youth a devout	baptist in spite of his friendship for the quaker poet john	greenleaf whittier he eventually attacked the orthodox	churches for what he deemed their cowardly compromising on the slavery	issue and in his invariably ardent manner was emphatically unorthodox	and denied the plenary inspiration of the bible.	2.8860124330006482
9096. a marked	impulse came to the anti-slavery movement through the finney revivals.	6.270221259726968
9097. finney himself while opposed to slavery placed his chief emphasis	on evangelism but from his converts issued much of the leadership of	the anti-slavery campaign.	3.498688884480572
9098. theodore dwight weld was	especially active.	6.6423823285011645
9099. weld was the son and grandson of new england congregational	ministers.	4.531813603607614
9100. as a youth he became one of finney's band	of evangelists and gave himself to winning young men.	5.63916941301196
9101. a strong temperance	advocate through the influence of a favorite teacher charles	stewart another finney convert he devoted himself to the anti-slavery	cause.	3.580540754536752
9102. a group of young men influenced by him enrolled in lane theological	seminary and had to leave because of their open anti-slavery	position.	6.041142430135846
9103. the majority then went to the infant oberlin.	4.244385730858102
9104. they and	others employed some of finney's techniques as they sought to win	adherents to the cause.	5.375337757755938
9105. weld contributed to the anti-slavery convictions	of such men as joshua r giddings and edwin m stanton	enlisted john quincy adams and helped provide ideas which underlay	harriet beecher stowe's uncle tom's cabin.	3.014519318852914
9106. he shunned	publicity for himself and sought to avoid fame.	6.539538405204793
9107. wendell phillips	from a prominent massachusetts family in his teens	was converted under the preaching of lyman beecher.	3.3473553651414933
9108. although he	later broke with the churches because he believed that they were insufficiently	outspoken against social evils he remained a devout christian.	5.718745860067193
9109. he was remembered chiefly for his fearless advocacy of abolition	but he also stood for equal rights for women for opportunity for the	freedmen and for prohibition.	3.349613060594039
9110. the anti-slavery movement and	other contemporary reforms and philanthropies were given leadership	and financial undergirding by arthur tappan and his younger	brother lewis tappan.	4.2142950488235495
9111. individuals possessing unusual gifts and great personal power	were transmuted at death into awesome spirits; they were almost immediately	worshipped for these newer even more terrible abilities.	3.0634269936708303
9112. their	direct descendants inherited not only their worldly fortunes but also	the mandate of their newfound power as spirits in the other half of	the universe.	5.2743362017269
9113. royal lineages could be based on extraordinary worldly	achievements translated into eternal otherworldly power.	3.474580153873458
9114. thus	the emperor could draw on sources not available to those with less	puissant ancestors.	5.29555279932627
9115. but this eminence was not without its weighty	responsibilities.	5.030582382418328
9116. since he possessed more power in an interdependent universe	of living beings and dead spirits the emperor had to use it for	the benefit of the living.	5.796951201800653
9117. the royal ritual generated power into the	other world: it also provided the living with a way to control the	spirits and bring their powers directly to bear on the everyday affairs	of the world.	3.2791391596967125
9118. proper ritual observance at any level of society was	capable of generating power for use in the spirit world; but naturally	the royal ritual which provided unusual control over already supremely	powerful divine spirits was held responsible for regulating the	universe and insuring the welfare of the kingdom.	4.681565033721146
9119. this is the	familiar system of cosmic government.	5.043118322102606
9120. the chinese emperor by	proper observance of ritual manifested divine powers.	5.126213144767318
9121. he regulated	the dualities of light and darkness yang and yin which are	locked in eternal struggle.	3.555294727400845
9122. by swaying the balance between them he	effected the alternation of the seasons.	6.1332435530236085
9123. his power was so great that	he even promoted and demoted gods according to whether they had given	ear or been deaf to petitions.	3.3540427092171705
9124. in this system no man is exempt	from obligations.	7.239854911549436
9125. failure in daily moral and ethical duties to one's	family outrages to community propriety any departure from rigid	standards of moral excellence were offenses against the dead.	3.137228868698504
9126. and to	offend the dead meant to incur their wrath and thus provoke the unleashing	of countrywide disasters.	5.1233747312847955
9127. the family home was in fact a temple;	and the daily duties of individuals were basically religious in	nature.	3.8529295600251783
9128. the dead spirits occupied a prominent place in every hope and	in every fear.	5.548470934104797
9129. the common belief was that there existed one	moral order which included everything.	3.6032953969796773
9130. the dead controlled the material	prosperity of the living and the living adhered to strict codes of	conduct in order not to weaken that control.	5.021976504353511
9131. men believed they could	control nature by obeying a moral code.	3.9422729026777628
9132. if the moral code were flouted	the proper balance of the universe would be upset and the disastrous	result could be floods plague or famine.	5.495779504801484
9133. modern westerners	have difficulty comprehending this fusion of moral and material	largely because in the west the historical trend has been to deny the	connection.	3.748359669218019
9134. living in urban conditions away from the deadweight of	village constraint and the constrictions of a thatched-roof world view	the individual may find it possible say to commit adultery not only	without personal misgivings but also without suffering any adverse	effects in his worldly fortunes.	4.590532718703612
9135. basing action on the empirical determination	of cause and effect provides a toughness and bravado that no	powerful otherworldly ancestor could ever impart- plus the added liberation	from the constraint of silent burial urns.	3.0076133533810068
9136. in china	the magical system par excellence was taoism.	6.016951197696949
9137. the taoists were quietist	mystics who saw an unchanging unity- the tao- underlying	all phenomena.	2.9868979856335747
9138. it was this timeless unity that was all-important and	not its temporary manifestations in the world of reality.	6.354519634686674
9139. the taoists	believed the unity could be influenced by proper magical manipulation;	in other words they were actually an organization of magicians.	3.2104656219710166
9140. mahayana buddhism was no exception to these prevailing magical	concepts.	6.294711597510789
9141. after this form of indian buddhism had been introduced	into china it underwent extensive changes.	3.988503146092208
9142. during its flowering in	the sixth to the eighth centuries mahayana offered a supernatural package	to the chinese which bears no resemblance to the highly digested	philosophical zen morsels offered to the modern western reader.	5.165220113507127
9143. mahayana	had gods and magic a pantheon heavens and hells and gorgeously	appareled priests monks and nuns all of whom wielded power over	souls in the other world.	3.2218627655246337
9144. the self-realized mahayana saint possessed	superhuman powers and magic.	5.029811453147388
9145. the mahayana that developed in the	north was a religion of idolatry and coarse magic that made the world	into a huge magical garden.	3.0287184024504676
9146. in its monastic form mahayana was merely	an organization of magic-practicing monks who catered	to the chinese faith in the supernatural.	5.2701988766824295
9147. nonmagical confucianism	was a secular rational philosophy but even with this different	orientation it could not escape from the ethos of a cosmic government.	3.4546661345476317
9148. confucianism had its own magic in the idea that virtue had power.	6.313195192103957
9149. if a man lived a classical life he need not fear the spirits- for	only lack of virtue gave the spirits power over him.	3.6018106768083435
9150. but let us not be	mistaken about confucian virtue; this was not virtue as we	understand the word today and it did not mean an abandonment of the belief	in magic manipulation.	5.290689192386159
9151. to the confucian virtue simply meant	mastery and correct observance of three hundred major rules of ritual	and three thousand minor ones.	3.616145732160408
9152. propriety was synonymous with ritual	observance the mark of a true gentleman.	5.6279124928512365
9153. to live correctly in an	interdependent moral and material universe of living and dead was decisive	for man's fate.	3.7294558628639427
9154. this in brief was the historical background	out of which zen emerged.	6.2725713127660185
9155. promoters of zen to the west record	its ancestry and recognize that zen grew out of a combination of	taoism and indian mahayana buddhism.	3.9463509989967003
9156. but the marvelous person	that is supposed to result from zen exhibits more chinese practicality	than indian speculation- he possesses magical powers and can	use them to order nature and to redeem souls.	4.784648652716778
9157. proponents of zen to	the west emphasize disproportionately the amount of mahayana buddhism	in zen probably in order to dignify the indisputably magical taoist	ideas with more respectable buddhist metaphysic.	3.3398122932597194
9158. but in the chinese	mind there was little difference between the two- the bonzes	were no more metaphysical than a magician has to be.	5.721588813477856
9159. actually	zen owes more to chinese quietism than it does to mahayana buddhism.	3.9217553064526594
9160. the ch'an sect may have derived its metaphysic from	mahayana but its psychology was pure early taoist.	4.465885718086515
9161. this is well	evidenced	by the quietist doctrines carried over in zen: the idea of	the inward turning of thought the enjoinder to put aside desires and	perturbations so that a return to purity peace and stillness- a	union with the infinite with the tao- could be effected.	3.1781779728019606
9162. in fact	the antipathy to outward ceremonies hailed by modern exponents as so	uniquely characteristic of the direct thinking zennist was a feature	of taoism.	4.826037445132931
9163. so too was the insistence on the relativity of the	external world and the ideas that language and things perceived by	consciousness were poor substitutes indeed for immediate perception by	pure indwelling spirit: the opposition of pure consciousness to ratiocinating	consciousness.	3.1459061302959372
9164. zen maintains that cognitive things	are only the surface of experience.	6.085136454512673
9165. one of its features attractive	to the west is its irreverence for tradition and dogma and for sacred	texts.	4.1612718423039885
9166. one patriarch is supposed to have relegated sacred scriptures	for use in an outhouse.	6.465936737136281
9167. but this is not the spirit of self-reliant freedom	of action for which the westerner mistakes it.	5.442482950852702
9168. it is simply that	in taoist tradition- as in all good mysticisms- books words	or any other manifestations that belong to the normal state of consciousness	are considered only the surface of experience.	5.165414170003359
9169. the truth- the	eternal truth- is not transmittable by words.	3.2882637095245957
9170. reality is considered	not only irrelevant to the acquisition of higher knowledge but	a positive handicap.	5.505663305628732
9171. the technique of reality confusion- the use of	paradox and riddles to shake the mind's grip on reality- originated	with fourth and third century bc chinese quietism: the	koan is not basically a new device.	2.9198939961692325
9172. it is important for an	understanding of zen to realize that the esoteric preoccupations of	the select few cannot be the doctrine of the common man.	6.089890869936941
9173. in the supernatural	atmosphere of cosmic government only the ruling elite was ever	concerned with a kingdom-wide ordering of nature: popular religion	aimed at more personal benefits from magical powers.	3.1044337843279908
9174. and this is only	natural- witness the haste with which modern man gobbles the latest	wonder drug.	5.7328636131695925
9175. early chinese anchoritism was theoretically aimed	at a mystic pantheist union with the divine personal salvation being	achieved when the mystical recluse united with divine essence.	3.268395488610077
9176. but	this esoteric doctrine was lost in the shuffle to acquire special powers.	5.808642006526823
9177. the anchorite strove in fact to magically influence the world	of spirits in the same way that the divine emperor manifested his power.	3.604170366870117
9178. thus the mahayana metaphysic of mystical union for salvation was	distilled down to a bare self-seeking and for this reason the mystic	in asia did not long remain in isolated contemplation.	5.2549073273330755
9179. as the zen	literature reveals as soon as an early zen master attained fame in	seclusion he was called out into the world to exercise his powers.	4.193088690730573
9180. the early anchorite masters attracted disciples because of their presumed	ability to perform miracles.	5.552126982950668
9181. exponents of zen often insist	that very early zen doctrine opposed the rampant supernaturalism	of china and proposed instead a more mature less credulous view of	the universe.	3.0720298928174707
9182. in support of this stories from the early literature are	cited to show that zen attacks the idea of supernatural power.	6.4239331238116355
9183. but	actually these accounts reveal the supernatural powers that the masters	were in fact supposed to possess as well as the extreme degree of	popular credulity: hwang pah one day going up mount	tien tai h which was believed to have been inhabited by arhats	with supernatural powers met with a monk whose eyes emitted strange light.	3.192043279808382
9184. they went along the pass talking with each other for a short while	until they came to a river roaring with torrent.	6.0747502809011795
9185. there being no bridge	the master had to stop at the shore; but his companion crossed	the river walking on the water and beckoned to hwang pah to follow	him.	3.625632459680671
9186. thereupon hwang pah said: if i knew thou art an arhat	i would have doubled you up before thou got over there! the monk	then understood the spiritual attainment of hwang pah and praised	him as a true mahayanist.	4.501945261163185
9187. a second tale shows still	more clearly the kind of powers a truly spiritual monk could possess:	on one occasion yang shan saw a stranger monk flying	through the air.	3.2999388635193476
9188. when that monk came down and approached him with a	respectful salutation he asked: where art thou from?	5.442961663081946
9189.  early	this morning replied the other i set out from india.	4.04813603068762
9190. why said the teacher art thou so late?	7.169436673888457
9191.  i stopped	responded the man several times to look at beautiful sceneries.	4.54432179308934
9192. thou mayst have supernatural powers exclaimed yang shan	yet thou must give back the spirit of buddha to me.	5.282700193451651
9193. then	the monk praised yang shan saying: i have come over to china	in order to worship manjucri and met unexpectedly with minor shakya	and after giving the master some palm leaves he brought from india	went back through the air.	2.9846179157309467
9194. in the popular chinese	mind ch'an was no exception to the ideas of coarse magic that	dominated.	5.7433431520012
9195. a closer look at modern zen reveals many magical	carryovers that are still part of popular zen attitudes.	3.523839707650874
9196. to the	zen monk the universe is still populated with spiritual beings	who have to be appeased.	6.384160360274963
9197. part of the mealtime ritual in the zendo consists	in offerings of rice to the spiritual beings.	3.9451110600796
9198. modern zen presentation	to the west insists on the anti-authoritarian highly pragmatic	nature of the zen belief- scriptures are burned to make fire	action is based on direct self-confidence and so on.	4.903549983280586
9199. this picture	of extreme self-reliant individuation is difficult to reconcile with such	zendo formulas as: o you demons and other spiritual beings	i now offer this to you and may this food fill up the ten quarters	of the world and all the demons and other spiritual beings be fed therewith.	3.33544890389448
9200. pope leo 13 on the 13th day of december 1898 granted	the following indulgences: an indulgence of three hundred days is	granted to all the faithful who read the holy gospels at least a	quarter of an hour.	5.049293540521412
9201. a plenary indulgence under the usual conditions	is granted once a month for the daily reading.	3.9126514449419645
9202. pope pius the sixth	at rome in april 1778 wrote the following: the faithful	should be excited to the reading of the holy scriptures: for these	are the most abundant sources which ought to be left open to everyone	to draw from them purity of morals and of doctrine to eradicate	errors which are so widely disseminated in these corrupt times.	4.495914012033198

9941. the design of a mechanical interlocking frame is much like a mechanical	puzzle but once understood the principles can be applied to	any track and signal arrangement.	3.4258799358908045
9942. in the frame are two sets of bars	which interact with each other to prevent the operator from making dangerous	moves.	6.379566444632489
9943. the main set of bars are the tappets and one tappet	is connected to each lever.	3.5994627049254366
9944. if the lever is pulled to clear a signal	or move a switch the tappet moves a short distance lengthwise at	the same time.	5.399100364044488
9945. close behind the plane of the tappets are the locking	bars.	4.825191990273804
9946. these can also move a short distance but at right angles	to the tappets.	6.218601009496681
9947. the number of locking bars required depends on how many	false moves must be prevented.	3.7760658224169266
9948. in the sides of the tappets	are notches with sloping sides and connection between the tappets and	locking bars consist of cams called dogs.	5.172285778096313
9949. two or more dogs are	mounted on each locking bar.	4.957231445390076
9950. these slide into and out of the notches	in the tappets as the tappets are moved locking and unlocking them.	5.897696081110739
9951. here's how the scheme works: suppose the operator pulls	the lever to clear a particular signal.	3.6313178079511106
9952. this also pulls the tappet connected	to the particular lever and forces any dogs seated in the notches	to the side thus moving one or more locking bars.	4.848669896450577
9953. the dogs on the	other ends of these locking bars are thus forced into notches in other	tappets.	3.539712756504727
9954. by this scheme pulling one signal to clear locks all the	other switch and signal levers in safe positions until the first signal	is again restored to normal.	4.946490421020902
9955. interlocking signals are normally	at stop or red position and a lever must be pulled to clear	the signal.	3.4219686563719556
9956. this is not necessarily to green however for in	some situations only a yellow indication is given to a train to let it	into the plant.	5.581807252761555
9957. there are other basic rules.	6.065173517246865
9958. a turnout	may have two levers one to actually move the switch points the other	to lock the points.	5.005215853824241
9959. a signal cannot be cleared until all the related	turnouts are properly thrown and locked.	3.57546915951343
9960. such locks are nearly	always used where the switch points face oncoming traffic.	6.012518529739621
9961. the	lock insures that the points are thrown all the way with no chance that	a wheel flange will snag on a partly thrown point.	3.5605223787853117
9962. if the points aren't	thrown all the way the turnout cannot be locked and in turn	the signal cannot be cleared.	6.215384753005358
9963. generally these locks on turnouts are	called facing point locks.	4.096357378235583
9964. figs 1-6 show typical arrangements	of track and signals.	6.008557251303244
9965. each diagram is accompanied by a dog	chart a list of the levers that show which other levers any particular	lever will lock if pulled.	3.6095994326073937
9966. the lines connecting the wedge-shaped	dogs represent the locking bars at right angles to the tappet bars.	4.931986487543452
9967. by studying the track-signal diagrams you'll note several	other details.	4.073992928258149
9968. derails- mechanical track devices that actually guide	the wheels off the rails if a train passes a stop signal- are	used in many instances.	4.705715237345916
9969. home signals have two blades.	5.495552499131051
9970. the blacked-in	blades indicate a fixed aspect- the blade does not move.	4.882746025682841
9971. as	an engineer approaches the plant the position of the home signal	is seen in advance when he passes the distant signal located	beyond the limits of the interlocking plant.	3.6295781142876486
9972. in some low-speed situations	the distant signal is fixed at caution.	6.351073364492857
9973. in other instances where	there is no automatic block signaling the distant has only green	and yellow aspects.	3.6923264167966665
9974. so much for the prototype.	8.79867585942491
9975. the interlocking	frame we built at the model railroader workshop and then	installed on paul larson's railroad follows the fig 1 scheme	and is shown beginning in fig 7 page 65 and in the photos.	3.1944417220508967
9976. here's	how it can be built.	8.637018234329686
9977. the sizes of pieces needed	for the interlocking frame are shown in the notes within fig 7 most	of the bars being 18'' brass in 14'' and 12'' widths.	2.9765195732254526
9978. you may change the dimensions to suit a frame for more or fewer levers	and locks as you wish.	5.543242971107556
9979. our instructions assume you are building	this particular frame which is for a junction.	4.0625682026566565
9980. when cutting	the pieces dress the ends smooth and square with a smooth file or sanding	disk.	5.749090694572204
9981. start with the right-hand piece b f soldering	it to the lower piece a of the same material but 12''	long.	4.099428111571981
9982. let exactly 1'' of a extend beyond b and	use a square to check your angle to exactly 90 degrees.	5.256336938863235
9983. now	lay 12 pieces of f cut 5-34'' long side by side but separated	by 12 pieces of the same material 12'' sq.	3.9625937049287523
9984. this gives you the	spacing for locating the left-hand piece b.	6.24244390878833
9985. compress the assembly	when you make the mark to show the location for b.	3.8924127846658716
9986. solder	this second b to a at right angles.	6.227157046387671
9987. there	should be 10'' between the two parallel members and each should be	1'' from an end of the long piece.	4.2126821911143875
9988. cap this assembly	with a f bar.	7.046672655308522
9989. tack-solder all the 12''	sq pieces to the 10'' and 12'' members.	3.6231623423744717
9990. these will be drilled	and tapped later on.	6.906328934783833
9991. now cut five f locking bar spacers	.	5.042605791260875
9992. position these using six intermediate temporary	f spacers and locate the upper 12'' bar a.	5.126168127897273
9993. solder	it and the five locking bar spacers to the frame.	4.221799204463741

10035. fitting	the locking bars and making the locking pieces is a rather tedious job	since stop screws tappets and locking bars must be removed and replaced	many times.	3.5108125026969303

10069. scientists say that the world and everything in it are based on	mathematics.	5.425154283159347
10070. without math the men who are continually seeking the causes	of and the reasons for the many things that make the world go 'round	would not have any means of analyzing standardizing and communicating	the things they discover and learn.	5.515057196843181
10071. math and the formulas that	allow it to be applied to different problems are therefore essential	to any scientific endeavor.	3.8593457249669014
10072. hot rodding is a science.	7.166579203865631
10073. it's	not a science as involved as determining what makes the earth rotate	on its axis or building a rocket or putting a satellite into orbit	but it is nevertheless a science.	3.1029207358098727
10074. but because science is based on mathematics	doesn't mean that a hot rodder must necessarily be a mathematician.	6.189251373195125
10075. a guy can be an active and successful hot rodder for years	without becoming even remotely involved with mathematical problems;	however he will have a clearer understanding of what he is doing and	the chances are he will be more successful if he understands the few	formulas that apply to rodding.	3.320561328965858
10076. a mathematical formula is nothing	more than a pattern for solving a specific problem.	5.475364143796647
10077. it places the	various factors involved in the problem in their correct order in relation	to each other so that the influence of factors on each other can	be computed.	4.285267911713653
10078. the first step in using a formula is to insert the	numerical values of the factors involved in their correct positions	in the formula.	5.792974561394018
10079. this changes the formula to an equation.	4.6705380169541675
10080. the	equation is used for the mathematical process of solving the problem.	6.39130775026028
10081. equations for rodding formulas are not complicated.	4.313811528742339
10082. they involve	only simple mathematics that are taught in grammar school arithmetic	classes.	5.702264644537193
10083. however it is essential that the various mathematical symbols	used in the equations be understood so that the mathematical processes	can be done properly and in their correct order.	3.9744167513718054
10084. they indicate	simple division multiplication subtraction and addition.	6.635544993656807
10085. the	symbol for division is a straight line that separates two numbers	placed one above the other.	3.606965646340503
10086. the lower number is always divided into the	upper number: f   the symbol for multiplication is .	4.9186514216793835
10087. it is used to separate two or more numbers in a row.	4.904613396049134
10088. for example:	f numbers to be multiplied together may be multiplied in any	order.	5.9229267553785805
10089. the result will be the same regardless of the order used.	5.389989690546635
10090. the symbol for subtraction is the standard minus sign.	5.784977393651941
10091. this is	nothing more than a dash.	5.569919830889029
10092. it separates two or more numbers.	9.044544647119109
10093. the number	on the right of the symbol is always subtracted from the number on	the left of the symbol.	3.8338533898255824
10094. for example: f when more than two figures	are separated by subtraction symbols the subtraction must be carried	out from the left to right if the result is to be correct.	5.725414391610655
10095. for example	for the problem f 10 from 25 equals 15 then 6 from 15 equals	9.	3.5418242171436263
10096. addition is indicated by the + symbol.	6.730902223911635
10097. the symbol is	used to separate two or more numbers.	4.026119770001907
10098. for example: f numbers separated	by addition symbols may be placed in any order.	5.91549502647824
10099. when solving	an equation that involves division as well as other steps do all	the division steps first	to reduce those parts of the equation to their	numerical value.	3.8455770506222993
10100. multiplication subtraction and addition can then	be accomplished as they appear in the equation by starting at the left	end of the equation and working toward the right.	5.181223313888579
10101. completing the	division first also includes those division parts that require multiplication	subtraction or addition steps: f this would be reduced	by multiplying 8 times 6 and then dividing the product by 12.	3.191023823296559
10102. this part	of the equation would then become 4.	6.640641490302372
10103. for use in formulas fractions	should be converted to their decimal equivalents.	4.614631192048091
10104. the easiest	way to do this is with a conversion chart.	6.001538288067875
10105. charts for this purpose	are available from many sources.	4.2091389592099615
10106. they are included in all types of mathematical	handbooks and they are stamped on some types of precision	measuring instruments.	5.8941571875289736
10107. the various mathematical processes can	be simplified by carrying the results to only two or three decimal places.	3.5436835906063586
10108. shortening the results in this manner will not have any detrimental	effect on the accuracy of the final result.	6.1723963414537675
10109. a constant is a number that remains the same	regardless of the other numbers used in the formula and the resultant	equation.	4.469195550447031
10110. it is a number without which the equation cannot be solved	correctly.	6.878333700506504
10111. rodding formulas apply to many phases of the sport.	4.499089344947154
10112. the answers they give can often pave the way to performance increases	and	quite often are necessary for completing entry blanks for different	events.	5.079680914587171
10113. when it is needed one formula is as important as another.	5.8412807068018475
10114. however some formulas are used more than others.	7.078259463808916
10115. we'll take	them in the general order of their popularity.	4.777901799013696
10116. a rodder should be able to compute the displacement of his engine.	6.41104328772496
10117. displacement is sometimes referred to as swept volume.	4.382310621477346
10118. most	entry blanks for competitive events require engine displacement information	because of class restrictions.	5.140047013898787
10119. it is good to be able to compute	displacement so that changes in it resulting from boring and stroking	can be computed.	3.87441038422978
10120. factors involved in the displacement formula	are the bore diameter of the engine's cylinders the length of the	piston stroke the number of cylinders in the engine and a constant.	5.620490887733781
10121. 7854 which is one-quarter of 3.	4.403285903274782
10122. 1416 another constant	known as pi.	6.655014167372593
10123. pi is used in formulas concerned with the dimensions	of circles.	4.858327449958538
10124. actually the engine displacement formula is	the standard formula for computing the volume of a cylinder of any type	with an added factor that represents the number of cylinders in the	engine.	5.56165516715858
10125. the cross-sectional area of the cylinders is determined and	then the volume of the individual cylinders is computed by multiplying	the area by the stroke length which is the equivalent of the length	of the cylinders.	3.581533100938461
10126. multiplying the result by the number of cylinders	in the engine gives the engine's total displacement.	5.901146182642978
10127. dimensions in inches and fractions of inches will give	the displacement in cubic inches.	3.6749807179499734
10128. dimensions in centimeters and fractions	of centimeters will give the displacement in cubic centimeters	.	5.817511797321628
10129. 54 centimeters: one cubic inch equals 16.	4.090616115878263
10130. for example let's consider a standard	283 cubic inch chevy v8.	6.3294258612753485
10131. these engines have a cylinder diameter	of 3-78 inches and a stroke length of 3 inches.	3.862026638802685
10132. the formula with	the fractions converted to decimals becomes f.	5.062572354287626
10133. to arrive	at the answer multiply the numbers together by starting at the left of	the group and working to the right.	3.9097972743102867
10134. the different steps will look like	this: f	a cylinder's compression ratio	is computed by comparing the cylinder's volume or its displacement	with the total volume of the cylinder and its combustion chamber.	4.579647943135898
10135. cylinder volume can be determined mathematically but combustion chamber	volume must be measured with a liquid.	3.7385883079636315
10136. cylinder volume is	determined in exactly the same manner as for the displacement formula:	f.	6.60201870025875
10137. to measure the volume of one of the combustion chambers	in the cylinder head install the valves and spark plug in the chamber	and support the head so that its gasket surface is level.	3.8690259881610123
10138. then pour	water or light oil from a graduated beaker into the chamber to fill	the chamber to its gasket surface.	5.362796058582343
10139. do not overfill the chamber.	5.917258111695485
10140. this	is possible with water and other liquids that have a high surface tension.	6.579700261380987
10141. such liquids will rise to a considerable height above the surface	around the chamber before they will flow out of the chamber.	4.2067059805969755
10142. the amount of liquid poured into the chamber is determined by subtracting	the quantity still in the beaker when the chamber is full from	the original quantity.	5.487434592978936
10143. most beakers are graduated in cubic centimeters	making it necessary to convert the result to cubic inches.	4.010631528745277
10144. however the displacement of the cylinder can be converted to cubic	centimeters.	8.063113707786616
10145. the compression ratio arrived at with the formula will	be the same regardless of whether cubic inches or cubic centimeters are	used.	3.2912271181026567
10146. the only precaution is that all volumes used in the formula be	quoted in the same terms.	6.580409451159957
10147. the volume of the cylinder opening	in the head gasket must be computed by multiplying its area in square	inches by the gasket's thickness in thousandths of an inch.	3.215000927069197
10148. sometimes	it is necessary to roughly calculate the square inch area of the opening	but the calculation can usually be made with sufficient accuracy	that it won't affect the final computation.	4.890214073411128
10149. the volume of the opening	is added to the combustion chamber volume.	4.33186516586123
10150. another thing	that must be taken into consideration is the volume of the area between	the top of the piston and the top of the cylinder block when the piston	is in top dead center position.	6.528592829659478
10151. compute this volume by measuring	the distance from the top of the block to the piston head as accurately	as possible with a depth micrometer or some other precision measuring	device and then multiply the area of the cylinder by the depth.	3.5901409206609167
10152. the	formula for this step is: f this volume is added to the total volume	of the combustion chamber and head gasket opening.	5.549587518312857
10153. the total of	these three volumes is the final combustion chamber volume.	3.69557302223915
10154. after the factors just described have been computed they are applied	to the following formula: f   for an example let's dream	up an engine that has a final combustion chamber volume of 5 cubic	inches and a cylinder volume of 45 cubic inches.	4.845288537159598
10155. applying these figures	to the formula we get the equation: f the compression ratio is	10 to 1.	3.561919715413097
10156. this method of computing compression ratio cannot be	used accurately for engines that have pistons with either domed or irregularly	shaped heads.	4.756087881797941
10157. any irregularity on the piston heads will make	it impossible with normal means to determine the final combustion	chamber volume because the volume displaced by the piston heads cannot	be readily computed.	3.410461648217662
10158. the only way to determine the final combustion	chamber volume when such pistons are used is by measuring it with liquid	while the cylinder head is bolted to the cylinder block and the piston	is in top dead center position.	5.01429172530433
10159. there are four versions of the formula that involves the relationships	of car speed engine speed rear axle gear ratio and rear tire	size.	3.7745980625059077
10160. by using the appropriate version any one of these factors can	be determined for any combination of the other three.	7.086845738421068

10292. bill ruger's long-awaited deerstalker	is a new rifle action in a caliber that upsets all the	modern theory of high-velocity fans; it's a short light quick-handling	fast-firing little timber gun designed to push a heavy slug	at modest velocity but with lots of killing power and ample range for	our most popular big game- whitetail.	4.290503191029256

10393. livery stable- j vernon prop coaching had declined	considerably by 1905 but the sign was still there near the old	wells fargo building in san francisco creaking in the fog as it	had for thirty years.	2.9949922515541254

10395. coaching	was in his blood.	5.172605279822952

10399. the southward route	was the classic run in california and the most fashionable.	3.558181857289914

10419. in the 1890's the	palace hotel began serving an oyster dish named after its manager john	c kirkpatrick.	3.337812845184076
10420. this dish much resembles the oysters rockefeller	made famous by antoine's in new orleans though the palace	chef announced it as a variant of manning's roast oysters.	5.15422211655278
10421. have long argued about which came first the palace's or antoine's.	4.411412062680549
10422. antoine's held as mandatory a splash of absinthe or pernod	on the parsley or spinach which was used for the underbedding.	5.079521098412318
10423. the	vernon however	held out for plain oyster roast and plenty of it unadorned by herbs	or any seasoning but salt though he did fancy a bit of lemon.	3.3698398588799625
10424. after the meal he and his guests went out to inspect the rig; this	was merely a ritual to please all hands concerned.	5.654251067052229
10425. the tallyho had	cost vernon $2300.	3.8170972122676265
10426. a replica of two coaches made in england for the	belmont club in the east and matchless west of the rockies it	was the despair of whips on the santa cruz run.	5.250852500245947
10427. one could shave in	the reflection of its french-polished panels and its axles were greased	like those of roulette wheels.	3.5733387586709
10428. the horses were groomed to a high	gloss; departing they stepped solemnly with knees lifted to the jaw	for they had been trained to drag at important funerals.	4.757916422244965
10429. but	for the start of the santa cruz run the whip fell.	4.713260864436088
10430. the clients boarded	the tallyho at the palace promptly at seven.	5.345303825081403
10431. they had been fed	a hunting breakfast so called because a kedgeree the dish identified	with fox hunting was on the bill.	3.913255059175561
10432. there are many ways of making a	kedgeree every one of which is right.	7.552923152147943
10433. here is an original kedgeree	recipe from the family club's kitchen:	flake	a cupful of cold boiled haddock mix with a cupful of cooked	rice two minced hard-boiled eggs some buttery white sauce done	with cream cayenne pepper salt a pinch of curry a tablespoonful of	minced onion fried and a bit of anchovy.	3.0593701456901403
10434. heat and serve hot on toast.	6.911932297068484
10435. the omelet named for ernest arbogast the palace's chef	was even more in demand.	3.13714953892483
10436. for decades it was the most popular dish	served in the ladies' grill at breakfast and it is one of the few	old palace dishes that still survive.	6.392192555799656
10437. native california oysters	salty and piquant as coppery as delawares and not much larger than a	five-cent piece went into it.	3.222634172026661
10438. the original formula goes thus:	arbogast	fry in butter a small minced onion rub with a tablespoonful	of flour add half a cup of cream six beaten eggs pepper	celery salt a teaspoonful of minced chives a dash of cayenne and a	pinch of nutmeg.	4.240111235413421
10439. a jigger of dry sherry follows and as the mixture	stiffens in go a hundred of the little oysters.	3.791934470025345
10440. louis sherry	once stayed a fortnight at the palace and he was so pleased with omelet	arbogast that he introduced it at his restaurant in new york.	5.636255909858056
10441. j pierpont morgan had come in his private train to san francisco	to attend an episcopal convention and brought the restaurateur	with him.	3.3476733010926503
10442. as things happened morgan was installed in the nob hill	residence of a magnate friend whose kitchen swarmed with cooks of approved	talent.	5.10070377029851
10443. sherry remained in his hotel suite where he amused himself	as best he could.	3.6406691625066676
10444. twice he left everything to his entourage and	fled to make the santa cruz tour under vernon's guidance.	6.160672623829866
10445. in the grand court of the palace notable for its tiers of moorish	galleries that looked down on the maelstrom of vehicles below vernon's	station was at the entrance.	3.6646184582921264
10446. it was a post of honor held inviolate	for him; he had the primacy among the coachmen.	5.994423122566147
10447. of majestic build	rubicund and slash-mouthed he resembled the late general winfield	scott who was said to be the most imposing general of his century	if not of all centuries.	3.8528497052933295
10448. vernon wore a gray tall hat a gardenia	and maroon wellington boots that glistened like currant jelly.	5.0171671349564075
10449. promptly at seven he would clatter out of the court with twelve in	the tallyho.	4.3570088245157
10450. he had style: he held his reins in a loose bunch at the	third button of his checked epsom surtout and when the horses leaned	at a curve as if bent by the force of a gale he leaned with them.	4.859848949989373
10451. they cantered down the peninsula not slackening until the coach reached	woodside where the santa cruz uplands begin.	3.60191696880924
10452. the road	maps of the region have changed since 1905; inns have burned down moved	elsewhere or taken other names.	4.445850174533575
10453. once on the road	the schedule meant	nothing.	5.322975089593356
10454. an agreeable ease suffused vernon and the passengers of	the tallyho from which there issued clouds of smoke.	5.373198953805034
10455. vernon would tilt	his hat over one ear as he lounged with his feet on the dashboard	indulging in a huge cigar.	3.500966484573425
10456. the horses moved at a clump; they were no	more on parade than was their driver; one fork of the road was as	good as another.	4.660375994940601
10457. the santa cruz mountains sprawl over three counties	and the roads twist through sky-tapping redwoods down whose furrowed	columns ripple streams of rain even when heat bakes the santa clara	valley below at the left.	2.8550858264455106
10458. the water splashes into shoulder-high tracts	of fernery.	5.20776592974974
10459. you arrive there in seersucker and feel you were half-witted	not to bring a mackintosh.	4.158834385978319
10460. vernon kept an account book	with a list of all the establishments that he thought worthy of patronage.	6.3806843801164925
10461. a number of them must have fallen into disfavor; they were	struck out with remarks in red ink denouncing both the cooks and the	management.	3.521526938283411
10462. he was copious in his praise of those that served food that	was good to eat.	5.89783968328417
10463. the horses seemed to know these by instinct he used	to say: such places invariably had stables with superior feed bins.	3.0969259457932297
10464. there was wright's for one lost amongst trees its wide	verandas strewn with rockers.	5.780687276729929
10465. many of its sojourners were devoted	to seclusion and quiet and lived there to the end of their days.	4.427171899823991
10466. it	was	the haunt of writer ambrose bierce who admired its redwoods.	5.208349849219301
10467. acorns	from the great oaks fed the small black pigs	whose carcass sweepstakes were renowned.	3.4603084715130303
10468. their ham butts cured	in oak-log smoke were also esteemed when roasted or boiled and served	with this original sauce:	put into	a saucepan a cupful of the baked ham gravy or of the boiled ham liquor	with a half stick of butter three teaspoonfuls of made mustard	and two mashed garlic cloves.	4.217792513899501
10469. contribute also an onion a peeled tomato	and two pickled gherkins and a mashed lime.	3.4134220492785294
10470. after this has simmered	an hour add two tablespoons each of worcestershire catsup and	chutney two pickled walnuts and a pint of sherry.	5.206431118038053
10471. then simmer fifteen	minutes longer.	5.529701649917654
10472. every winter a kegful of this sauce was made	and placed at the end of a row of four other kegs in the cellar so	that when its turn came it was properly mellowed.	5.442986908897529
10473. vineyards	and orchards also grew around wright's and deer were rather a nuisance;	they leaped six-foot fences with the agility of panthers.	3.0639186036858623
10474. but	no one complained when they wound up regardless of season in venison	pies.	5.721497113448343
10475. no one complained of the white wine either: at this altitude	of two thousand feet grapes acquire a dryness and the tang of gunflint.	3.7164460617411974
10476. apple	trees grew there also.	7.364568438617048
10477. though creeks in the santa cruz mountains	flow brimful the year round and it is forever spring the apples that	grow there have a wintry crackle.	3.9539347120479
10478. dwellers thereabouts preferred	to get their apple pies at the local bakery which had a brick oven	fired with redwood billets.	4.909218416548744
10479. the merit of the pie vernon believed	was due more to its making than to the waning heat of the oven.	3.3126590339388113
10480. the recipe	which he got from the baker and wrote down in his ledger is basically	this:	peel core and slice across	enough apples to make a dome in the pie tin and set aside.	4.621054734696278
10481. in a	saucepan put sufficient water to cover them an equal amount of sugar	a sliced lemon a tablespoonful of apricot preserve or jam a pinch each	of clove and nutmeg and a large bay leaf.	3.0217833901099334
10482. let this boil gently for	twenty minutes then strain.	6.851000650603343
10483. poach the apples in this syrup for twelve	minutes drain them and cool.	3.7519151783510365
10484. set the apples in the pastry-lined	tin spread over them three tablespoonfuls of softened butter	with as much brown sugar a sprinkling of nutmeg and a fresh bay leaf	then lay on a cover of pastry and gild it with beaten yolk of egg.	4.570426529570048

10601. i got	off there crossed the street walked ahead with st sophia on my	left the blue mosque on my right and in a moment came to the entrance	of st sophia.	3.9012693844594333
10602. erected on the site of pagan temples and	three previous st sophias the first of which was begun by constantine	this fourth church was started by justinian in 532 and completed	twenty years later.	5.047891104887044
10603. on his first trip to the finished structure	he boasted that he had built a temple grander than solomon's in jerusalem.	4.171809383287783
10604. a few years later the dome fell in.	8.211701518657085
10605. nevertheless it remained	one of the most splendid churches of the eastern empire where	the byzantine emperors were crowned.	4.619333786326451
10606. after the turks conquered the	city in 1453 they converted it to a mosque adding the stubby minarets.	5.631537110119625
10607. in the second half of the sixteenth century sinan the great architect	who is the michelangelo of the east designed the massive buttresses	that now help support the dome.	3.9268597680347197
10608. with the birth of the turkish	republic after the first world war st sophia became a museum	and the ancient mosaics which were plastered over by the moslems	whose religion forbids pictures in holy places have been restored.	5.0926887680046455
10609. inside over the first door i saw one of these which shows	constantine offering the city to the virgin mary and justinian offering	the temple.	3.8790974560226643
10610. on the columns around the immense dome are round plaques	with arabic writing.	5.895873579577171
10611. the eight green columns i learned came	from the temple of artemis at ephesus the others red from the temple	of the sun at heliopolis.	3.1030059348006604
10612. beneath the dome i saw the	spot where the byzantine emperors were crowned a bit of floor protected	now by a wooden fence.	5.4232137456573355
10613. behind this is a minber or moslem pulpit	and near it a raised platform with golden grillwork where the emperors	and after them the sultans sat.	3.4291251845649477
10614. directly opposite is the emperor's	door through which they entered the building.	6.302941708527558
10615. outside	st sophia i walked through the flower garden in front of it with	the blue mosque ahead on my left.	3.7655918627401093
10616. across the street on my right i	saw the hippodrome now a park.	6.502830703950749
10617. it was laid out in 196 for chariot	races and other public games.	4.149258730109672
10618. statues and other monuments that stood	there were stolen mostly by the waves of crusaders.	5.307075146925962

10620. just before coming to the mosque entrance i crossed	the street entered the hippodrome and walked ahead to the obelisk	of theodosius originally erected in heliopolis in egypt about 1600	bc by thutmose who also built those now in new york	london and rome at the lateran.	4.604033424118071

10622. beyond	it i noted a small green column about twelve feet below the present	ground level- the serpentine column three entwined serpents	which once stood at the temple of apollo at delphi greece.	4.690709864086032

10635. taking the streetcar back	to kaiser's fountain i walked ahead then left down the street	opposite st sophia and just beyond the corner came to a small	one-story building with a red-tile roof which is the entrance to the	sunken palace.	3.5613724261663617

10652. do start fires one or two hours ahead of time to obtain	a	lasting bed of glowing coals.	6.527199545631928

10768. directions are written for those who have had previous	experience in making pottery.	7.181142927798267
10769. instructions for preparing clay drying	glazing and firing are not given.	3.816564745587949
