10771. ceramic modeling clay: red white or buff.	4.042849435501767
10772. glazes one-stroke ceramic colors stains cones as indicated	in the individual instructions.	5.269157864635549
10773. use	well-wedged clay	free of air bubbles and pliable enough to bend without	cracking.	3.7066628307289022
10774. clean wooden molds and presses thoroughly; they must be	free of oil wax and dust.	5.276776642192348
10775. the size of wooden	mold will determine the amount of clay needed.	4.425471399119498
10776. roll clay to thickness	indicated in individual instructions.	6.636453458023528
10777. whenever possible use the	wooden mold as a pattern for cutting clay.	4.240709805631569
10778. when mold has more than one	design cavity make individual paper patterns.	6.217752529152728
10779. place mold or paper	pattern on rolled clay and cut clay by holding knife in vertical position	defects; experiment with defects for decoration techniques of glazes	.	3.3509268622076616
10780. place the cut clay piece loosely over the carved cavity	design side of wooden mold.	6.013509644617985
10781. to obtain clear impression of mold press	clay gently but firmly into mold cavity starting at center and working	to outer edges.	3.543950286794401
10782. trim excess clay away from outer edges.	6.868136884825196
10783. check thickness	of clay and build up thin areas by moistening surface with a little	water and adding small pieces of clay.	3.432315752162048
10784. be sure to press the additional	clay firmly into place without locking in air bubbles.	5.932328677183537
10785. allow	project to stand for about five minutes	antique do not leave clay in too long as the dampness may cause mold	.	3.882481411663322
10786. to release clay from mold place hands in a cupped	position around project; gently lift the edge on far side then continue	to release edge completely around mold.	4.860179970155757
10787. slight tapping on the	underside of mold will help release the clay but too much agitation will	cause the clay to become soft and will interfere with removal of clay	from mold.	3.214198741117949
10788. place a piece of plaster wall board or plaster bat on	clay and reverse bat clay and mold in one action.	5.557820228862339
10789. this will prevent	the clay from twisting or bending causing warping when fired.	3.8825724581358814
10790. place	project on table and carefully lift the mold off.	5.969051864722997
10791. study surface of clay	for defects or desired corrections.	3.987562737002329
10792. if clay is slightly out of shape	square straight sides with guide sticks or rulers pressed against	opposite sides or smooth round pieces with damp fingers.	4.732934181485333
10793. if the background	of design is too smooth or you wish to create a wood-grained effect	it may be added at this time with a dull tool such as the handle	of a fine paintbrush.	3.9164877184176246
10794. make slight smooth grooves rather than cuts	for the texture	.	6.397044178830959
10795. leave the clay on	plaster board to dry slowly covered lightly with a loose piece of plastic	or cloth to prevent warping.	3.451341027395251

10928. all framing	in hotei is one-inch mahogany which in the dressed state you	buy it is about the 1316-inch thickness specified in the drawings.	5.431141629512352
10929. therefore	the lumber is bought in planks and ripped to size for battens	etc on a table saw.	3.469674694220395
10930. besides flathead bronze screws silicon bronze	stronghold nails	are used extensively in assembly and weldwood	resorcinal glue is used in all the joints.	5.558432278362442
10931. follows a thorough study of the drawings.	5.3325219017371595
10932. start by laying out the six	frames and the transom on a level floor.	6.258317440703999
10933. draw each outline in a different-color	chalk one on top of the other.	4.36657703516789
10934. in this way you will be	able to detect any obvious mistakes.	6.758262209813842
10935. the transom frame is made	first with the joints lapped glued and fastened with one-inch no	12 stronghold nails.	3.0765806963462357
10936. after notching it for the keelson chines and	battens the half-inch plywood transom is secured to it with glue	and the same type	nails.	5.47687968283442
10937. all frames are butted at the joints and 38-inch plywood gussets	are glued and nailed on each side of each joint again using the one-inch	no 12 nails.	3.4775207091752036
10938. the frames are notched only for the keelson	and the chines.	5.633195274087382
10939. if notched for the battens they would require more work	be weakened and limber holes would have to be bored so that bilge	water could flow through.	3.8417626029695087
10940. nowhere in the boat do the frames come in	contact with the plywood planking.	5.857287868920382
10941. the jig is erected after the	frames and transom are complete.	3.342191488637774
10942. this is an important step because	any misalignment would cause progressively worse misalignment in the hull	as you advance in construction.	5.29367707585643
10943. be sure all members are parallel	vertical and level as required.	4.39929638215849
10944. after the frames and transom	are set up on the jig and temporarily braced a piece of three-inch-wide	mahogany	is butted between frames one and two below the line	of the keelson.	5.704683200241422

10961. all bottom battens are two inches wide.	4.909850832916334

10963. the battens are carefully fastened in place after some	necessary fairing on all frames.	3.269939766571228

11049. close to a large	city they might even specify the size of the nails used; in a remote	section there might be no restrictions at all.	3.732123309882121
11050. this can usually	be found out at the nearest town hall.	6.592045533207063
11051. at the same time check the electrical	plumbing and sanitary requirements as well as possible zoning	regulations.	4.656226263181744
11052. whether electricity and public water and sewers are available	or not check the local customs in the use of bottled or l-p	gas.	5.899973917739456
11053. be sure that this information	is reasonably official and not just an unfounded opinion.	4.302753832459845
11054. if there	are any major restrictions they usually can be obtained in printed	form.	6.629166396663817
11055. where a building permit is required find out what you must	present when applying for one.	4.1864132643154806
11056. in many cases you must file a complete	set of plans with the local building inspector.	6.178360000312093
11057. these will be available	at cost from our plans department.	4.47429641128312
11058. some general	things to look for in a site if you haven't already bought one are	accessibility water drainage and orientation.	5.703097330527947
11059. how are the roads	and how will they stand up?	4.523963209317992
11060.  is there evidence of wash-outs on the property;	swampy areas or intermittent springs?	6.266867010400903
11061.  a visit in the early	spring after a thaw will be very informative.	3.9898024440332316
11062. note where the sun rises	and sets and ask which direction the prevailing winds and storms	come from.	5.439021444278341
11063. will the view be something you can live with?	5.010682619656021
11064.  don't	worry too much about rocky or sloping terrain; we will take up alternative	foundations later on.	5.345664565199054
11065. with this first issue	we give you a list of the materials needed to build the basic	and the expandable.	4.208439175508481
11066. this will be for the	shell of the house only and does not include	the carport or balcony.	7.096900579017598
11067. this will permit you to get a rough	estimate of how much the materials for the shell will cost.	4.512190159343801
11068. bear in mind	that this does not include interior panels for partitions fancy	flooring appliances and fixtures electrical wiring and plumbing	all of which will be taken up in detail in later issues.	5.088123189770371
11069. the	wall panels are constructed of a framework of standard f and f of	a good grade free from structural faults.	3.414489313397753

11085. with modern techniques of woodworking and the multitude of cutting	tools fixtures and attachments available the drill press has become	a basic home workshop tool.	3.4073933868917794
11086. the drill press consists of a vertical	shaft which is tapered or threaded on one end to hold a	drill chuck a tubular housing in which the spindle is mounted	a head in which the quill is mounted a feed lever which moves the	quill up or down a power source and a movable table upon which the work	is placed.	4.842975684012557
11087. there is often a means of locking the quill and on larger	presses the table can be tilted.	4.329575270274009
11088. the size of the press is	usually expressed in terms of chuck capacity	or distance between the spindle center and the	column.	5.889065311213642
11089. a press with an 11 inch capacity lets you drill to the center	of a 22 inch board or circle.	3.36220669671213
11090. a new radial drill press with	a 16 inch capacity has a tilting head that allows drilling to be done	at any angle.	5.01193029943645
11091. the head is mounted on a horizontal arm that swivels on	the supporting column to position the drill bit instead of the work.	3.4142128069110673
11092. the drill press should be leveled and depending	on whether it is a bench or floor model bolted securely to a	sturdy bench or stand or screwed to the floor with lag or expansion screws.	5.1062889047090705
11093. this will reduce vibration and increase accuracy.	4.846192505178084
11094. a coat	of paste wax or a rubdown with a piece of wax paper will protect the	polished surface of the table; wiping with a slightly oiled cloth	will discourage rusting of the column and quill.	4.642834525774158
11095. presses not fitted	with sealed spindle bearings will need a drop of oil now and then in	the lubrication holes in the quill.	3.7358994149300444
11096. the rest of the press should be kept	clean by dusting with a clean rag or brush.	5.61958728454761
11097. be careful to	keep the drive belt free of oil and grease.	4.376228309363814
11098. belt tension is adjusted	by manipulation of two locking bolts and a movable motor mount.	5.270603055811012
11099. keep	the belt just tight enough so the pulleys won't slip when pulled by	hand; excess tension will only cause undue wear on the motor and spindle	bearings.	3.183059165610205
11100. most drill presses have a quill return spring that raises	the spindle automatically when the feed lever is released and holds	the quill in the raised position.	5.010816385297442
11101. the return spring tension may be	adjusted to suit individual requirements by gripping the spring housing	with a pair of pliers	loosening the lock nut or screw and rotating the housing	until the desired tension is achieved.	2.955661597337829
11102. turning the housing clockwise	will reduce tension counter-clockwise will increase it.	5.948951689113441
11103. lose the chuck key	some manufacturers have had the foresight to provide	a socket for the chuck key; otherwise you'll have to spend	a few minutes to either attach a suitable spring clip somewhere on the	press head or fit the key to a length of light chain and fasten to the	bottom of the motor mount so that the key is out of the way when not	in use.	3.3509913978668053
11104. drill speeds are important if you want	a good job.	6.700710916940436
11105. each cutting tool will operate best at a given speed	depending on the material worked.	3.9588390605472275
11106. on most drill presses it is impossible	to get the exact speed but you can come close by adjusting the	drive belt on the step-cone pulleys.	5.352329298365661
11107. you will find a chart giving the	various speed ratios available with your particular drill press somewhere	in the instruction booklet that came with the tool.	3.553604066619104
11108. see the table	on page 34 for exact recommended speeds.	6.358118340326363
11109. generally the larger the	tool and the harder the material the slower the speed.	4.08787538349659
11110. feed pressure	is also of major importance.	7.44244539826987
11111. too much pressure will force the	tool beyond its cutting capacity and result in rough cuts and jammed	or broken tools.	3.527681594824984
11112. too light a feed particularly with metal or other hard	material causes overheating of the tool and burning of the cutting	edge.	5.469359214186214
11113. the best results will be obtained by matching the correct speed	with a steady feed pressure that lets the tool cut easily at an even	rate.	3.320211343478202
11114. there are numerous types and styles	of tools to drill holes.	6.216825749371702
11115. the most common are the twist drill the	solid center shaft with interchangeable cutting blades the double spur	bit and the power wood bit.	3.3042759669581767
11116. all will do a good job if sharp but the	twist drills don't cut quite as smoothly as the others since they	do not have the outlining spurs that sever the fibers before actual	boring starts.	4.911983287331282
11117. the adjustable fly cutter is very useful for cutting	large diameter holes and can be used to cut exact-size discs by	reversing the cutter blade.	3.2554609055062413
11118. since fly cutters are one sided and not	balanced they should be used at the slowest speed available and fed	very slowly to avoid binding.	5.440063034438718
11119. fly cutters can fool you into putting	your hand too close to the tool so if you want to avoid nicked fingers	keep your hands well out of the way.	3.8458097595678
11120. when drilling all the way through a workpiece always place a	piece of scrap wood underneath.	6.299070706377062
11121. this will not only protect the work	table but also assure a clean breakthrough.	4.226553888901228
11122. another method of assuring	a clean hole is to first drill a small pilot hole all the way through	then drill half way with the dimensional bit turn the piece over	and finish from the other side.	5.215239323263794
11123. in soft woods with pronounced grain	there is sometimes a tendency for the hole to wander due to the varying	hardness of the wood.	3.5575218590834825
11124. in this case drilling a small pilot hole or	clamping the work will do much to improve accuracy.	6.042568468285552
11125. when a hole	is to be bored to a predetermined depth mark the depth on the side	of the stock then run the bit down so that it is even with the mark.	4.065110243706536
11126. the depth gauge rod can now be set and any number of holes bored to	exact and identical depth.	4.922163614430849
11127. the old-time bridges over the merrimac river in massachusetts	are of unusual interest in many respects.	3.268364677203706
11128. for their length their	types of construction their picturesque settings and their literary	associations they should be known and remembered.	5.545692608423835
11129. in this sequence	i shall write about them in the order of their erection.	5.14871520097483
11130. the	first bridge known to have been covered wholly or in part- and perhaps	the most interesting one connected newbury with	salisbury point.	5.468135537496531
11131. its building was first proposed in 1791 when a	group of citizens mostly newburyport men petitioned the general court	no	1 newbury port may 30th 1791 a bridge over	merrimack river from the land of hon'ble jonathan greenleaf	esquire in newbery to deer island and from said island to salisbury	would be of very extensive utility by affording a safe conveyance	to carriages teams	and travellers at all seasons of the year	and at all times of tide.	2.91435781978022
11132. we the subscribers do agree	that as soon as a convenient number of persons have subscribed to	this or a similar writing we will present a petition to the hon'ble	general court of the commonwealth of massachusetts praying	for an act incorporating into a body politic the subscribers to such	writing with liberty to build such a bridge and a right to demand	a toll equal to that received at malden bridge and on like terms	and if such an act shall be obtained then we severally agree each	with the others that we will hold in the said bridge the several shares	set against our respective names the whole into two hundred shares	being divided and that we will pay such sums of money at such times	and in such manners as by the said proposed corporation shall	be directed and required.	4.495872527681229
11133. this paper was signed by forty-five	persons subscribing a total of two hundred shares.	4.039241637385289
11134. a month	later the general court served notice to the town of newbury that	the bridge was to be built.	5.766662108091199
11135. the matter was considered and reconsidered	and finally opposed but in spite of many objections the court	granted a charter on january 9 1792.	3.3245700797451336
11136. on november 26 of that year the	bridge was completed and opened.	7.187564309899807
11137. timothy palmer who invented	and later patented the arch type of construction for wooden bridges	was the genius who planned and supervised the building of the essex	or deer island bridge although the actual work was carried	out under the direction of william coombs who received  300 as	recompense.	3.063990105268176
11138. this two-part bridge is best described by rev timothy	dwight president of yale college in his travels in new-england	and new-york published in new haven in 1821.	4.892876411936514
11139. he says	of it:   it consists of two divisions separated by an island	at a small distance from the southern shore.	3.670348767948899
11140. the division between	the island and this shore consists principally of an arch; whose	chord is one hundred and sixty feet and whose vortex is forty feet	above the high-water mark.	4.52785519790094
11141. in appearance and	construction it resembles the pascataqua bridge.	4.1045892243531545
11142. the whole length of	essex bridge is one thousand and thirty feet and its breadth thirty-four.	5.188965165155482
11143. i have already mentioned that mr timothy palmer of newburyport	was the inventor of the arched bridges in this country.	3.812296648754182
11144. as mr	palmer was educated to house-building only and had never seen a	structure of this nature; he certainly deserves not a little credit	for the invention.	5.1078294171059015
11145. it is hardly necessary to remind students	of covered bridges that timothy palmer was born in 1751 in nearby	rowley; that he moved with his parents to west boxford when he was	sixteen years old; and was there apprenticed to a builder and architect	moody spofford.	3.270474003014015
11146. it was indeed a remarkable feat that a man	who had had no experience of bridge building should have applied the	principle of the arch which appears in his famous bridges at portsmouth	haverhill and philadelphia.	5.023130476378267
11147. the essex merrimack bridge	when first built was not covered.	3.608280098848529
11148. as far as we know no american	bridge had been thus protected in 1792.	6.6484969180441045
11149. richard s allen is the	authority for the statement that the northern section was probably roofed	by 1810.	3.8050158471852225
11150. its original appearance is shown in an engraving published	in the massachusetts magazine in may 1793 which is reproduced	herewith.	5.662362590364904
11151. a brief description accompanying the picture	says that the bridge contained more than 6000 tons of timber.	3.612804474437807
11152. between	the abutments on the newbury shore and the south bank of deer island	there was one span or arch measuring 160 feet; between the north	shore of deer island and the salisbury side there was an arch of	113 feet and a series of piers with a draw forty feet long.	4.802077273929658
11153. a	dinner and celebration in honor of this piece of engineering took place	july 4 1793 in a tavern erected by the corporation on the island.	3.5481777293700363
11154. it is said that the eccentric timothy dexter who was one of the	first share-holders stood on the table and made a speech worthy of the	occasion.	6.531506976137268

11157. the north portion of the essex bridge	was well worth the cost of construction although it proved to be twice	what was estimated in the beginning.	3.793454507097764

11164. it reads:    information	is hereby given that mr timothy palmer of newburyport mass	has agreed to take charge of the concerns of the patentees of the	chain bridge in the states of massachusetts new hampshire vermont	rhode island and connecticut so far as relates to the sale	of patent rights and the construction of chain bridges.	4.8933560002050855

11167. it fell	february 6 1827 carrying with it a horse and wagon two men and four	oxen.	4.117220268679569
11168. the horse and men were saved but the oxen drowned.	5.781323393427086

11170. this second chain bridge was 570 feet long	had two thirty-foot towers and a draw and a double roadway.	5.036336882803749
11171. the essex bridge was a toll crossing until 1868 when the county	commissioners laid out all the merrimack bridges as highways.	3.3127040045197202
11172. sturdy and strong after more than a century of continuous	use the old covered wooden bridge that spans the tygartis valley river	at philippi will have a distinctive part in the week-long observance	of the first land battle of the civil war at its home site may	28th to june 3rd.	5.181953546960866
11173. colonel frederick w lander impersonated	will again make his break-neck ride down the steep declivity of talbott's	hill and thunder across the bridge to join colonel	benjamin f kelley's virginia infantry then swarming	through the streets in pursuit of the retreating confederates.	2.977226752437159
11174. he was closely followed by the ohio and indiana troops- thus the	old bridge has another distinction; that of being the first such structure	secured by force of arms in the war of the '60s.	5.586672083758172
11175. the	bridge has survived the natural hazards of the elements war fire	and floods as well as injuries incident to heavy traffic for more than	a hundred years.	3.467575767701572
11176. twice during the civil war it was saved from destruction	by the opposing armies by the pleas and prayers of a local minister.	5.452462744008862
11177. it still stands as a monument to the engineering skills of the	last century and still serves in the gasoline age to carry heavy traffic	on us route 250- the old beverly and fairmont turnpike.	3.320379539613047
11178. it is one of the very few if not the only surviving bridge of	its type to serve a main artery of the us highway system thus	it is far more than a relic of the horse and buggy days.	6.462562404147666
11179. this	covered wooden bridge is so closely identified with the first action	in the early morning of june 3 1861 and with subsequent troop movements	of both armies in the philippi area that it has become a part	and parcel of the war story.	3.5336795225237445
11180. so frequently has pictures of the bridge	appeared in books and in national publications that it vies with the	old john brown fort at harpers ferry as the two nationally best known	structures in west virginia.	4.756040284781779
11181. completed and opened for traffic	in 1852 the bridge was designed and built by lemuel chenoweth	and his brother eli of beverly.	3.476666832644777
11182. the chenoweth brothers were experienced	bridge builders and against the competition of other and better	known bridge designers and builders they had constructed nine of	the covered wooden bridges on the parkersburg and staunton turnpike	a dozen years before as well as many other bridges for several counties.	4.573379752117493
11183. the philippi bridge however was the chenoweth master piece	with its 139-foot dual lane span- and it stands today as a monument	to its builders.	2.998344930520428
11184. never rebuilt the bridge was strengtened in 1938	by two extra piers a concrete floor and a walk-way along the upper	side in order to care for modern traffic.	5.367743840582104
11185. during the war it	was in constant use by the wagon trains transporting supplies from the	railhead at grafton to the troops operating in the interior.	3.450559951158788

11194. it is a good eight years now since each of us acquired a swimming	pool- eight enlightening vigorous rigorous not wholly unrewarding	years.	5.497770881183405
11195. we have learned a lot- a dash of hydrochemistry here a	bit about plumbing and pump-priming there.	3.728659176305175
11196. we have had sound grounding	in the principles of the mailed-fist-in-velvet-glove school of diplomacy.	6.502190365145118
11197. we have become amateur insurance experts and fine-feathered yard	birds.	4.7370442934500785
11198. true our problems have lessened a bit as more and more of	our neighbors have built their own pools thereby diluting our spectacular	attractions.	5.3018593296913785
11199. but problems cling to pools as any pool owner knows.	4.025960811478483
11200. so our innate generosity of spirit prompts us to share our trials	errors and solutions with any who are taking the pool plunge for the	first time- in the pious hope that some may profit from our experience.	4.713036054987196
11201. position may not be everything but in the	case of a pool it can certainly contribute difficulties social andor	physical.	3.952426509057245
11202. we speak from varying viewpoints.	7.884808361158568
11203. one of us has a pool set	in a wooded area very near the house.	4.516445252130287
11204. the other has his pool far away	from the house in a field high on a hill.	5.719199952931659
11205. if you are dreaming	of a blue shimmering pool right outside your living room windows	close your eyes firmly and fill in the picture with lots and lots of	children damp towels squashed tubes of suntan oil and semi-inflated	plastic toys.	3.2032409351900757
11206. you are likely to be nearer the truth.	9.165745755475555
11207. you can	also see that the greater the proximity of the pool to your main living	quarters the greater the chance for violation of family privacy annoying	noise and the let's-make-your-house-our-club attitude.	3.7709826753766937
11208. on the	other hand out-of-sight does not lead to out-of-mind when children	cannot be easily observed and you have to make a long trek to reach the	pool.	5.94572607863937
11209. another dilemma: as picturesque as a sylvan pond in	the forest may be trees offer a leaf and root hazard to the well-being	of a pool.	3.2063694800156806
11210. yet a grassy approach can turn a pool into a floating	lawn every time the grass is mowed.	5.784305319351103
11211. as in choosing a wife it	is only sensible to consider also how appealing a pool is likely to be	in bad weather as well as in good.	4.180451172785072
11212. in the colder climes for instance	you will have to live through the many unglamorous winter months when	your pool will hardly look its best.	5.255936140707038
11213. it may be a big hole in the ground	filled with salt hay or an ice floe studded with logs.	4.022404184225289
11214. even a	neat plastic-covered plunge is not exactly a joy to behold.	6.372911921791624

11218. and a good several feet around the pool should be neither	greensward nor woods but good hard pavement.	5.691488657387366
11219. the placement	of your pool however will not of itself solve the two major problems	of pool owning- those that involve your social life and those pertaining	to safety.	3.1120117691501474
11220. coping with them demands stern discipline- of yourself	as well as of your family neighbors friends and anyone you ever	talked to on a transoceanic jet.	4.8427466562479236
11221. eight years ago while we were	going through the mud-sweat-and-tears construction period we were	each solaced by the vision of early morning dips and evening home-comings	to a cool family collected around the pool with a buffet table laid	out nearby for the lord and master's delectation.	3.1614981225752836

11442. water interest	is one of the most valuable factors you can find for a recreation	site.	7.283857943723395
11443. most park planners look to water frontage for basic park areas.	4.0499692575070485
11444. this follows naturally since frontage on an ocean stream or lake	provides scenic values and opportunities for the very popular recreation	activities of bathing fishing boating and other water sports.	4.838947107903655
11445. a body of water is usually the center of interest at parks which attract	the greatest picnic and camping use.	4.034000075325862
11446. it also cools the air in summer	and nourishes the trees and wild life.	6.086874029107295
11447. the amount of water	frontage the quantity and quality of the water and the recreation	afforded by it are important.	4.306987094142437
11448. a restricted frontage may be too crowded	an area for public use.	5.733997206991216
11449. the quantity of water flow may be critical;	a stream or pond which is attractive in the springtime may become stagnant	or dry in late summer.	3.21884123572399
11450. if the site is on a reservoir the level	of the water at various seasons as it affects recreation should be	studied.	5.472277083589367
11451. check the quality of the water.	6.55678841273624
11452. a stream which has all of	its watershed within a national forest or other lands under good conservation	practices is less likely to be affected by pollution than one	passing through unrestricted logging or past an industrial area.	4.611466623373875
11453. other	factors such as water temperature depth of water the fish life it	supports wave action flooding etcetera will affect its recreation	value.	3.41599869369883
11454. other natural features which can be of high interest	are the forests canyons mountains deserts seacoast beaches sand	dunes waterfalls springs etcetera with which the area is blessed.	5.415153976763903
11455. just as the national and state parks place emphasis on features which	are of national or state significance counties should seek out these	features which are distinctive of their area.	3.5017926058787396
11456. although the site may	not contain the features themselves there are often opportunities	to include them as additional interest to the site.	5.672518070435058
11457. the route to the	park may lead people past them or display views of them.	3.42636792765533
11458. a group of	native trees or plants which are outstanding in a particular county can	be featured at the site.	5.577398230114591
11459. the fish animals and birds which	may be found at the site are another interest.	3.6403050731383253
11460. fishing interest calls	for a check of the species found quantity and size the season they	are available and the stocking program of the fish commission.	5.087899848356659
11461. animals	may be present at the site or provide hunting in nearby areas.	4.2112368265633995
11462. the	site may be on one of the major flyways of migratory birds or have its	own resident bird life.	6.005289424045509
11463. clams crabs and other marine life may add	interest at coastal areas.	3.5626371760028452
11464. each area has its own historical	interests with which much can be done.	6.191757373233729
11465. park visitors are always	eager to learn more about the area they are in.	3.9153609489713177
11466. the historical sign	tells its story but nothing gets interest across as well as some of the	original historical items or places themselves which still have the	character of the period covered.	4.864407498237629
11467. notice should be taken of unusual rock	formations deposits or shapes of the earth's crust in your region.	3.554513731536685
11468. those which tell a story of the earth's formation in each area	can add geological interest to the recreation sites.	5.943389537228582
11469. an old shipwreck	a high dam an old covered bridge a place to find agates or other	semi-precious stones or a place to pan gold etcetera may be of interest.	3.584922336402231
11470. some areas may provide archeological values such as ancient indian	village sites or hunting areas caves artifacts etcetera.	5.0935163606595815
11471. how well can the site be developed?	5.037874742010233
11472.  look at the physical features	of the land to determine how desirable it is for use what can be done	to correct the faults and what it will cost to make the area meet your	needs in comparison to other sites.	5.546327760176478
11473. many things need to be checked:	- the size of the area alone can be a determining	factor.	5.361014897421453
11474. an area may be too small for the needs of the project.	7.588873432692527
11475. areas should be large enough to include the attractions have ample	space for the use of facilities needed and have room around the edges	to protect the values of the area from encroachment by private developments.	3.5652222269028466
11476. acreage in excess of the minimum is good practice as recreation	areas are never too large for the future and it is often more economical	to operate one large area than several small ones.	5.401561042855932
11477. shape	of the area is also related to the use attractions and needs of the	development.	4.564943395953778
11478. a large picnic area or camping development is most efficient	in shape as a square or rectangle several hundred feet in width	in preference to a long narrow area less than one hundred feet wide.	5.006199780497819
11479. this	is true because of savings in utility lines and the fact that your	buildings have a useful radius equal in all directions.	3.994277407651539
11480. however a	narrow strip may be very practical for small developments or to provide	additional stream frontage for a fisherman's trail or include	scenic strips within the park unit.	4.94258732615486
11481. the values	of the site may be affected by the appearance of the adjoining lands	ownership and use of the land and the utilities available there.	3.984425806947302
11482. for	instance a site adjoining other publicly owned lands such as a national	forest or a public road may be desirable whereas a site next	to an industrial plant might not.	4.805456001395397
11483. the utilities available nearby may	provide a savings in the cost of extending electricity or water to the	site.	3.587789918041113
11484. check the	elevation of the ground degree and direction of slopes drainage rock	outcrops topsoil types and quality as well as subsoil.	6.041076581092471
11485. nearly level	areas are required for parking areas beaches camp areas ballfields	etcetera.	4.083870155326892
11486. determine how much topography limits useful area or what	the costs of earth moving or grading might be.	5.115221726780045
11487. in addition	to its recreation interests water is needed for drinking sanitation	and irrigation.	4.070568565251256
11488. the quantity and quality of water sources is	often a big factor in site selection.	5.288955981663066
11489. the area may provide good springs	or opportunities for a well or be near to municipal water lines.	3.3922889684116098
11490. figure	the cost of providing water to the use areas.	7.258239024182245
11491. the	existing plant growth calls for thorough checking.	4.1675032371497505
11492. look at the trees	as to size and interest the amount of shade they provide how healthy	they are the problems of maintenance fire hazards wind throw	etcetera.	5.775432305458088
11493. an area may have been partially logged and requires	removal of stumps or clean up.	4.147661435293754
11494. some shrubs may be of good landscaping	value other areas of brush may need to be cleared.	6.60884284416478
11495. the extent and location	of open areas is noted.	3.633504655909654
11496. how much will wind	rain sun and temperature affect the use?	6.636490951859644
11497.  an area sheltered from	strong winds may be highly desirable for recreation use.	4.210272921693851
11498. the direction	velocity and season of these winds should be noted as to just how	they will affect the recreation use and your maintenance and operation	of the area.	4.636574116981034
11499. lack of rainfall and extreme temperatures may call for	the development of shade and irrigation of a site to make it useable.	3.6247183255392166
11500. sometimes you have a choice of exposure for sites where the topography	or trees of the area will provide afternoon shade morning sun or	whatever may be most desirable for the use intended.	5.748258191959254
11501. some areas may already have been improved and contain buildings	roads utilities cleared land etcetera which may raise the cost of	the site.	3.5156996421632023
11502. your invitation to write about serge prokofieff to honor his	70th anniversary for the april issue of sovietskaya muzyka is	accepted with pleasure because i admire the music of prokofieff;	and with sober purpose because the development of prokofieff personifies	in many ways the course of music in the union of soviet socialist	republics.	5.2080121205960035
11503. the serge prokofieff whom we knew in the	united states of america was gay witty mercurial full of pranks	and bonheur- and very capable as a professional musician.	3.2407490613082888
11504. these	qualities endeared him to both the musicians and the social-economic	haute monde which supported the concert world of the post-world	war 1 era.	5.346498722684491
11505. prokofieff's outlook as a composer-pianist-conductor	in america was indeed brilliant.	3.9682346544670066
11506. prokofieff's classical	symphony was hailed as an ingenious work from a naturally gifted	and well-trained musician still in his twenties.	4.902890455612469
11507. to the traditionalists	it was a brilliant satire on modernism; to the neo-classicists	it was a challenge to the pre-war world.	3.7732789925047427
11508. what was it to prokofieff?	9.688449441965926
11509. 	a tongue-in-cheek stylization of 18th-century ideas; a trial	balloon to test the aesthetic climate of the times; a brilliant piece	de resistance?	3.156174121620124
11510.  certainly its composer was an ascending star	on a new world horizon.	6.368266477132003
11511. i heard the classical symphony	for the first time when koussevitzky conducted it in paris in 1927.	4.330083102546601
11512. all musical paris was there.	7.895719206590346
11513. some musicians were enthusiastic some	skeptical.	5.17500969367352
11514. i myself was one of the skeptics.	8.854331533553474
11515. i remember	ernest bloch in the foyer shouting in his high-pitched voice:	h it may be a tour de force mais mon dieu can anyone take	this music seriously?	3.377801757162659
11516.    the answer is yes! certainly	america took prokofieff and his classical symphony seriously	and with a good deal of pleasure.	5.6354695468849085
11517. his life-long friend serge	koussevitzky gave unreservedly of his praise and brilliant performances	in boston new york and washington d c to which	he added broadcastings and recordings for the whole nation.	3.3075765026836343
11518. chicago was	also a welcome host: there in 1921 prokofieff conducted the world	premiere of the love for three oranges and played the first	performance of his third piano concerto.	4.942329094911171
11519. uncle sam was indeed	a rich uncle to prokofieff in those opulent post-war victory	years of peace and prosperity bold speculations and extravaganzas enjoyment	and pleasure: the golden twenties.	3.1510607730015887
11520. we attended the	premieres of his concertos symphonies and suites; we studied taught	and performed his piano sonatas chamber music gavottes and marches;	we bought his records and played them in our schools and universities.	4.583681987737128
11521. we unanimously agreed that prokofieff had won his rights as	a world citizen to the first ranks of twentieth-century composers.	3.7175908737328487
11522. nevertheless prokofieff was much influenced by paris during	the twenties: the paris which was the artistic center of the western	world- the social paris to which russian aristocracy migrated-	the chic paris which attracted the tourist dollars of rich	america- the avant-garde paris of diaghileff stravinsky koussevitzky	cocteau picasso- the laissez-faire paris of dadaism	and ultramodern art- the paris sympathique which took young	composers to her bosom with such quick and easy enthusiasms.	4.329070700104896
11523. so young prokofieff was the darling of success: in his motherland;	in the spacious hunting grounds of uncle sam; in the exciting	salons of his lovely brilliant paris- mistress of gaiety-	excess and abandon- world theatre of new-found freedoms in tone color	dance design and thought.	2.921572162542409
11524. meanwhile three great terrible	forces were coagulating and crystallizing.	6.2335520241978815
11525. in this world-wide conscription	of men minds and machines prokofieff was recalled to his	native land.	3.7233501469902857
11526. the world exploded when fascism challenged all concepts	of peace and liberty and the outraged freedom-loving peoples of the	capitalist and socialist worlds combined forces to stamp fascist	tyranny into cringing submission.	4.481722447914333
11527. after this holocaust a changing world	occupied the minds of men; a world beset with new boundaries new	treaties and governments new goals and methods and the age-old fears	of aggression	and subjugation- hunger and exposure.	3.2184819653791976
11528. in this	changed world prokofieff settled to find himself and to create	for	large national purpose.	5.674350155987765
11529. here this happy roving son of good fortune	proved that he could accept the disciplines of a new social-economic	order fighting for its very existence and ideals in a truculent world.	3.68633660348238
11530. here prokofieff became a workman in the vineyards of socialism-	producing music for the masses.	5.734794681764294
11531. it is at this point in his life	that the mature prokofieff emerges.	4.734974686143604
11532. one might have expected that	such a violent epoch of transition would have destroyed the creative	flair of a composer especially one whose works were so fluent and spontaneous.	4.95533135744275
11533. he accepted the environment	of his destiny- took root and grew to fulfill the stature of his	early promise.	3.4137983977822213
11534. by 1937 he had clarified his intentions to serve his	people: i have striven for clarity and melodious idiom but at	the same time i have by no means attempted to restrict myself to the	accepted methods of harmony and melody.	4.8129368090091385
11535. this is precisely what makes	lucid straightforward music so difficult to compose- the clarity must	be new not old.	3.7218349153316597
11536. how right he was; how clearly he saw the cultural	defection of experimentation as an escape for those who dare not	or prefer not to face the discipline of modern traditionalism.	5.379402568920872
11537. and	with what resource did prokofieff back up his credo of words- with	torrents of powerful music.	3.327234360399283
11538. compare the vast difference in scope and	beauty between his neat and witty little classical symphony and	his big muscular passionate and eloquent fifth symphony; or the	love for three oranges with the wonderful imaginative	colorful and subtle tenderness of the magnificent ballet	the stone flower.	4.345837468677601
11539. this masterpiece has gaiety too but it is	the gaiety of dancing people: earthy salty and humorous.	3.3102835638319195
11540. of	course these works are not comparable even though the same brain conceived	them.	6.453929606099607
11541. the early works were conceived for a sophisticated international	audience; the later works were conceived to affirm a way	of life for fellow citizens.	3.2705413849711467
11542. however in all of prokofieff's music	young or mature we find his profile- his signature- his	craftsman's attitude.	6.017756125496875
11543. prokofieff never forsakes his medium for the	cause of experimentation per se.	3.9173261247212428
11544. in orchestration he stretches	the limits of instrumentation with good judgment and a fine imagination	for color.	5.305588532153253
11545. his sense for rhythmic variety and timing is impeccable.	4.241020176737957
11546. his creative development of melodic designs of slavic dance tunes and	love songs is captivating: witty clever adroit and subtle.	4.703702642864079
11547. his	counterpoint is pertinent skillful and rarely thick.	4.012163890500985
11548. also	it should be noted that the polytonal freedom of his melodies and harmonic	modulations the brilliant orchestrations the adroitness for evading	the heaviness of figured bass the skill in florid counterpoint	were not lost in his mature output even in the spectacular historical	dramas of the stage and cinema where a large dramatic canvas of sound	was required.	4.522748661492142
11549. that prokofieff's harmonies and forms sometimes	seem professionally routine to our ears may or may not indicate that	he was less of an original than we prefer to believe.	3.4260651792665717
11550. need for	novelty may be a symptom of cultural fatigue and instability.	6.404463056359236
11551. prokofieff might well emerge as a cultural hero who by the force of	his creative life helped preserve the main stream of tradition to which	the surviving idioms of current experimentalism may be eventually	added and integrated.	3.158887787288821
11552. at this date it seems probable that the	name of serge prokofieff will appear in the archives of history	as an effective traditionalist who was fully aware of the lure and danger	of experimentation and used it as it served his purpose; yet	was never caught up in it- never a slave to its academic dialectics.	4.800358740827255
11553. certainly it is the traditional clarity of his music which has endeared	him to the western world- not his experimentations.	4.29614307982724
11554. so	prokofieff was able to cultivate his musical talents and harvest a	rich reward from them.	5.624468496997419
11555. nor can anyone be certain that prokofieff would	have done better or even as well under different circumstances.	4.05413123038694
11556. his fellow-countryman igor stravinsky certainly did not.	6.1678817213160535
11557. why did	prokofieff expand in stature and fecundity while stravinsky	dwindled in stature and fruitfulness?	3.9051942242591116
11558. 	i think the answer is to be found in prokofieff's own words:	the clarity must be new not old.	6.141998045184704
11559. when prokofieff forged his	new clarity of lucid straightforward music so difficult to compose	he shaped his talents to his purpose.	3.404182721201386
11560. when stravinsky	shaped his purpose to the shifting scenes of many cultures many salons	many dialectics many personalities he tried to refashion himself	into a stylist of many styles determined by many disparate cultures.	4.7627471025978965
11561. prokofieff was guided in a consistent direction by the life of his own	people- by the compass of their national ideas.	3.9232583191157175
11562. but stravinsky	was swayed by the attitudes of whatever culture he was reflecting.	6.032322685389527
11563. in	all his miscalculations stravinsky made the fatal historical blunder	of presuming that he could transform other composers' inspirations-	representing many peoples time periods and styles- into his own	music by warping the harmony melody or form to verify his own experiments.	2.9592826966779606
11564. because of the authentic homogeneity of his early nationalistic	materials and his flair for orchestrations- his brilliant petruchka	his savage sacre du printemps his incisive les noces-	the world kept hoping that he could recapture the historical	direction for which his native talents were predisposed.	4.652467491953458
11565. but	time is running out and many of stravinsky's admirers begin to fear	that he will never find terra firma.	3.6457786795886618
11566. his various aesthetic postulates	remain as landmarks of a house divided against itself: supra-expressionism	neo-paganism neo-classicism neo-romanticism	neo-jazz neo-ecclesiasticism neo-popularism and most recently	post-serialism- all competing with each other within one composer!	what a patchwork of proclamations and renunciations! meager	and shabby by-products linger to haunt our memories of a once mighty	protagonist;	a maladroit reharmonization of our national anthem	; a poor attempt to write an idiomatic	jazz concerto; a circus polka for elephants; his hopes that the tunes	from his old music might be used for popular american commercial	songs! stravinsky nearing the age of eighty is like a lost and frantic	bird flitting from one abandoned nest to another searching for	a home.	4.127868233486378
11567. how differently prokofieff's life unfolded.	5.412416034667604
11568. prokofieff	was able to adjust his creative personality to a swiftly changing	world without losing his particular force and direction.	4.936954277324127
11569. in the process	his native endowments were stretched strengthened and disciplined	to serve their human purpose.	3.4161545912627638
11570. with a large and circumspect	20th-century technique he wove the materials of national heroes and	events national folklore and children's fairy tales- slavic dances	and love songs- into a solid musical literature which served his	people well and is providing much enjoyment to the world at large.	4.798114751434314
11571. of course it must not be forgotten that in achieving this historical	feat prokofieff had the vast resources of his people behind	him; time and economic security; symphony orchestras opera and ballet	companies; choruses chamber music ensembles; soloists; recordings;	broadcastings; television; large and eager audiences.	3.2982608381259433
11572. it	must be conceded that his native land provided prokofieff with many	of the necessary conditions for great creative incentive: economic	security and cultural opportunities incisive idioms social fermentations	for a new national ideology- a sympathetic public and a large	body of performers especially trained to fulfill his purpose.	4.354979120086813
11573. thus	in prokofieff the union of soviet socialist republics produced	one of the great composers of the twentieth century.	4.054993212972768
11574. that his moods	even in his early years are those of his people does him honor	as his music honors those who inspired it.	6.007492873310647
11575. that he mastered every aspect	of his medium according to his own great talents and contemporary	judgments is a good and solid symbol of his people under the tremendous	pressures of proclaiming and practising the rigors of a new culture;	and perhaps of even greater significance- his music is strong 20th-century	evidence of the effectiveness of evolution based on a broad	traditionalism for the creative art of music.	3.464889858695219
11576. april 10 marked a memorable date in new york's musical history-	indeed in the musical history of the entire eastern united states.	5.671490371047875
11577. on that date the musicians emergency fund organized to furnish	employment for musicians unable to obtain engagements during the	depression and to provide relief for older musicians who lost their fortunes	in the stock market crash observed its 30th anniversary.	3.2152327004893926
11578. roy mason is essentially a landscape painter whose style and direction	has a kinship with the english watercolorists of the early nineteenth	century especially the beautifully patterned art of john sell	cotman.	4.839001403568633
11579. and like this english master mason realizes his subjects	in large simplified masses which though they seem effortless are	in reality the result of skilled design born of hard work and a thorough	distillation of the natural form that inspired them.	3.2700454630159284
11580. as a	boy roy mason began the long process of extracting the goodness of the	out-of-doors its tang of weather its change of seasons its variable	moods.	4.875926087983063
11581. his father a professional engraver and an amateur landscape	painter took his sons on numerous hunting expeditions and imparted	to them his knowledge and love of nature.	3.26386999973838
11582. out of this background of	hunting and fishing it was only natural that roy first painted subjects	he knew best: hunters in the field fishermen in the stream ducks	and geese on the wing- almost always against a vast backdrop of	weather landscape.	5.070248350815092
11583. it is this subject matter that has brought mason	a large and enthusiastic following among sportsmen but it is his exceptional	performance with this motif that commends him to artists and	discerning collectors.	3.663396272898459
11584. mason had to earn the privilege of devoting	himself exclusively to painting.	6.006462845581244
11585. like many others he had to work	hard long hours in a struggling family business which though it was	allied to art of a kind- the design and production of engraved seals-	bore no relation to the painting of pictures.	3.5287012480361666
11586. but it did teach	roy the basic techniques of commercial art and later for twelve years	he and his sister nina conducted an advertising art studio in philadelphia.	5.2361576941248815
11587. on the death of their father they returned to their home	in batavia new york.	4.738922432231116
11588. after more years of concentrated effort roy	and his brother max finally established a thriving family business	at the old stand.	5.168133912974866
11589. during all this time roy continued to paint	first only on weekends and then as the family business permitted	for longer periods.	3.9933786838958025
11590. gradually he withdrew from the shop altogether	and for the past thirty years he has worked independently as a painter	except for his continued hunting and fishing expeditions.	5.265297010719746
11591. but even	on these the palette often takes over while the shotgun cools off!	except for a rich friendship with the painter chauncey ryder	who gave him the only professional instruction he ever had- and	this was limited to a few lessons though the two artists often went on	painting trips together- roy developed his art by himself.	3.092258449728255
11592. in the	best tradition he first taught himself to see then to draw with accuracy	and assurance and then to paint.	5.374135656158965
11593. he worked in oil for years before	beginning his work in watercolor and his first public recognition	and early honors including his election to the academy were for	his essays in the heavier medium.	3.3554030560050374
11594. gradually watercolor claimed his greater	affection until today it has become his major if not exclusive	technique.	5.798622416620919
11595. it has been my privilege to paint with roy mason	on numerous occasions mostly in the vicinity of batavia.	3.819966555185419
11596. more often	than not i have found easy excuse to leave my own work and stand at	a respectable distance where i could watch this man transform raw nature	into a composed not imitative painting.	4.971357843340944
11597. what i have observed	time and time again is a process of integration integration that begins	as abstract design and gradually takes on recognizable form; color	patterns that are made to weave throughout the whole composition;	and that over-all amazing control of large washes which is the mason	stylemark.	3.3716317501337794
11598. finally come those little flicks of a rigger brush and the	job is done.	5.625927219607495
11599. inspiring- yes; instructive- maybe; duplicable-	no!   but for the technical fact we have the artist's	own testimony:   of late years i find that i like best to	work out-of-doors.	3.5592990106626794
11600. first i make preliminary watercolor sketches in	quarter scale in which i pay particular attention	to the design principles of three simple values- the lightest	light the middle tone and the darkest dark- by reducing the forms	of my subject to these large patterns.	4.692190965723014
11601. if a human figure or wild life	are to be part of the projected final picture i try to place them	in the initial sketch.	3.9963202343642896
11602. for me these will belong more completely to	their surroundings if they are conceived in this early stage though	i freely admit that i do not hesitate to add or eliminate figures on	the full sheet when it serves my final purpose.	5.118915888017673
11603. i am thoroughly	convinced that most watercolors suffer because the artist expects	nature will do his composing for him; as a result such pictures are	only a literal translation of what the artist finds in the scene before	him.	3.62390820156406
11604. just because a tree or other object appears in a certain spot	is absolutely no reason to place it in the same position in the painting	unless the position serves the design of the whole composition.	6.405631970963925
11605. if the artist would study his work more thoroughly and move certain	units in his design often only slightly finer pictures would result.	3.3881207819950947
11606. out of long experience i have found that incidental figures and other	objects like trees logs and bushes can be traced from the original	sketch and moved about in the major areas on the final sheet until they	occupy the right position which i call 'clicking'.	4.961145280354793
11607. speed	in painting a picture is valid only when it imparts spontaneity	and crispness but unless the artist has lots of experience so that	he can control rapid execution he would do well to take these first sketches	and soberly reorder their design to achieve a unified composition.	3.209886264625602
11608. if i have seemed to emphasize the structure of the composition	i mean to project equal concern for color.	6.593771630735852
11609. often in working	out-of-doors under all conditions of light and atmosphere a particular	passage that looked favorable in relation to the subject will be	too bright too dull or too light or too dark when viewed indoors in	a mat.	3.3169517168284313
11610. when this occurs i make the change on the sketch or on the	final watercolor- if i have been working on a full sheet in the field.	6.094665584620069
11611. when working from one of my sketches i square it up and	project its linear form freehand to the watercolor sheet with charcoal.	3.575724095516561
11612. when this linear draft is completed i dust it down to a faint	image.	6.633585476871335
11613. from this point i paint in as direct a manner as possible by	flowing on the washes with as pure a color mixture as i can manage.	3.7352154924481513
11614. however first	i thoughtfully study my sketch for improvement of color and	design along the lines i have described.	5.401184612781937
11615. then i plan my attack:	the parts i will finish first the range of values the accenting of	minor details- all in all mechanics of producing the finished job	with a maximum of crispness.	3.489903292692135
11616. the longer i work the more i am sure	that for me at least a workmanlike method is important.	5.4458704352785405
11617. trial and	error are better placed in the preliminary sketch than in hoping for miracles	in the final painting.	3.6184846317107864
11618. as for materials i use the	best available.	7.642841618880798
11619. i work on a watercolor easel in the field and frequently	resort to a large garden umbrella to protect my eyes from undue	strain.	4.209942433614777
11620. in my studio i work at a tilt-top table but leave the paper	unfixed so that i can move it freely to control the washes.	5.703849168403248
11621. i have	used a variety of heavy-weight hand-made papers but prefer an english	make rough surface in 400-pound weight.	3.482756621527782
11622. after selecting a sheet	and inspecting it for flaws	i sponge it thoroughly on both sides with	clean cold water.	5.501664557314014
11623. then i dry the sheet under mild pressure so that	it will lie flat as a board.	3.66112728245063
11624. in addition to the usual tools	i make constant use of cleansing tissue not only to wipe my brushes	but to mop up certain areas to soften edges and to open up lights	in dark washes.	4.921622415761599
11625. the great absorbency of this tissue and the fact that	it is easier to control than a sponge makes it an ideal tool for the	watercolorist.	3.5875916390777025
11626. i also use a small electric hand-blower to dry large	washes in the studio.	5.738606935414685
11627. my brushes are different from those used	by most watercolorists for i combine the sable and the bristle.	3.528619941816238
11628. the	red sables are 8; two riggers 6 and 10; and a very large	flat wash brush.	4.942699345168607

11631. in analyzing the watercolors of roy mason	the first thing that comes to mind is their essential decorativeness	yet this word has such a varied connotation that it needs some elaboration	here.	3.298716630773311

11634. long observation has taught	mason that most landscape can be reduced to three essential planes:	a foreground in sharp focus- either a light area with dark accents	or a dark one with lights; a middle distance often containing the	major motif; and a background usually a silhouetted form foiled against	the sky.	4.428751758773167

11701. arm shoulder chest upper and lower back strength will be aided with	the horse kick.	3.458583707626979
11702. start on hands and feet.	9.033127480291002
11703. keeping the hands in	the starting position run in place to a quick rhythm.	4.058455848041582
11704. after this has	become easy use slower and slower rhythms kicking higher and higher.	5.828801616840923

11706. push-ups are	essential but few have the strength for them at first.	6.323364492868553
11707. start on the	knees in a large circle.	5.594515332795095

11712. start by falling forward to a point close to the feet and as strength	improves fall farther and farther out.	6.304973187132825
11713. try to push back to the stand	position from the stretched position without any intermediate pushes	from the hands.	3.9802136422962398
11714. the push-up itself can be taught by starting at the	top of the push-up with legs spread wide.	4.913555213704977
11715. let the body down slowly	taking at least five seconds for the letting down.	4.322538467542994

11719. start with the class	standing in a circle with weight on the right foot and the left extended	a little way into the circle.	4.140343812854018

11723. the right will land first followed by the left.	4.149319176101824
11724. return to the	standing position.	8.164279681234856

11771. many cells bacteria and other microorganisms are transparent to visible	light and must be stained for microscopic investigation.	3.639060282286688
11772. this stain	often disrupts the normal cell activity or else colors only the outside.	5.308088020147237
11773. a completely new insight into living cells and their structure	will be possible by use of a new technique which replaces visible light	with ultraviolet radiation and combines a microscope with a color-tv	system to view the results.	3.226041221082924
11774. fig 1 is a simplified block	diagram of the ultraviolet microscopy system developed at the medical	electronics center of rockefeller institute.	5.538484082971844
11775. by combining the	talents of a medical man dr aterman a biophysicist mr	berkely	and an electronics expert dr zworykin this novel technique	has been developed which promises to open broad avenues to understanding	life processes.	3.0534952985565855
11776. three different wavelengths of ultraviolet	radiation are selected by the variable filters placed in front of the	three mercury xenon lights which serve as the ultraviolet sources.	5.271612405400728
11777. these wavelengths are reflected in sequence through the specimen by the	rotating mirror; the specimen is magnified by the microscope.	3.358056094492811
11778. instead	of the observer's eye the image orthicon in the tv camera	does the looking.	5.5746634549830985
11779. the microscope and orthicon are both selected	to operate well into the ultraviolet spectrum which means that all	lenses must be quartz.	3.2600209719827506
11780. the video signal is amplified and then	switched in synchronism with the three ultraviolet light sources which	are sequenced by the rotating mirror so that during one-twentieth of	a second only one wavelength corresponding to red green or blue is	seen.	4.171652518616693
11781. to another the lights are switched by a commutator-like assembly rotated	by a synchronous motor.	3.7704818129728763
11782. this assembly also supplies a 20-cps	this is the same system	as was used in the field-sequential color-tv system which preceded	the present simultaneous system.	5.259470700327897
11783. three separate amplifiers then	drive a 21-inch tricolor tube.	4.22863362144715
11784. the result is a color picture of the	specimen where the primary colors correspond to the three different ultraviolet	wavelengths.	5.725075865744171
11785. many of the cells and microorganisms which	are transparent to visible light absorb or reflect the much shorter	wavelengths of the ultraviolet spectrum.	3.7217314536583666
11786. different parts of these cells	sometimes absorb or reflect different wavelengths so that it is often	possible to see internal portions of cells in a different color.	5.630079712214926

11789. electronically analyzed	the medical title of lobar ventilation	in man by drs c j martin and a c young covers	a brief paper which is one part of a much larger effort to apply electronics	to the study of the respiratory process.	3.3061012529641753

11791. this unit	affectionately dubbed the monster can be wheeled to any convenient	location and provides a wealth of information about the patient's	breathing.	3.4956912767515047
11792. in the lower center rack an 8-channel recorder	indicates the percentage of carbon dioxide and nitrogen from the upper	and lower lobes of one lung the total volume of inhalation per breath	the flow of air from both lobes and the pressure of the two lobes	with respect to each other.	4.8254066559506175

11795. techniques	the original electrocardiograph primarily	indicates irregularities in the heartbeat but today's techniques allow	exact measurements of the flow of blood through the aorta dimensioning	of the heart and its chambers and a much more detailed study of	each heartbeat.	3.2582274938226625
11796. for many of these measurements the chest must be opened	but the blood vessels and the heart itself remain undisturbed.	6.314546001646945
11797. a group of researchers at the university of washington have given	a paper which briefly outlines some of these techniques.	4.225047823165709
11798. one simple	method of measuring the expansion of the heart is to tie a thin rubber	tube filled with mercury around the heart and record the change	in resistance as the tube is stretched.	5.562740942646394
11799. a balanced resistance bridge	and a pen recorder are all the electronic instrumentation needed.	3.6226229283906344
11800. sonar can be used to measure the thickness of the heart by placing	small crystal transducers at opposite sides of the heart or blood vessel	and exciting one with some pulsed ultrasonic energy.	5.84521349300396
11801. the travel	time of sound in tissue is about 1500 meters per second thus it takes	about 16	|msec to traverse 25 mm of tissue.	2.8895486728775452
11802. a sonar or radar-type	of pulse generator and time-delay measuring system is required for	body-tissue evaluation.	4.881462525708442
11803. in addition to the heart and aorta successful	measurements of liver and spleen have also been made by this technique.	4.134467857295008
11804. the doppler effect using ultrasonic signals can be employed to	measure the flow of blood without cutting into the blood vessel.	4.733329716945738
11805. a still more sophisticated system has been devised for determining	the effective power of the heart itself.	4.27108323395694
11806. it uses both an ultrasonic	dimensioning arrangement of the heart and a catheter carrying a thermistor	inserted into the bloodstream.	6.028133507356662
11807. the latter measures the heat carried	away by the bloodstream as an indication of the velocity of the blood	flow.	3.665830727817856
11808. it is also possible to utilize a pressure transducer mounted	at the end of a catheter which is inserted into the heart's left	ventricle to indicate the blood pressure in the heart itself.	5.738718490974237
11809. this pressure	measurement may be made at the same time that the ultrasonic dimensioning	measurement is made.	4.386371300950684
11810. a simplified version of the instrumentation	for this procedure is shown in fig 2.	6.582067536864325
11811. outputs of the two	systems are measured by a pulse-timing circuit and a resistance bridge	followed by a simple analogue computer which feeds a multichannel recorder.	3.2019811401495124
11812. from this doctors can read heart rate change in diameter pressure	and effective heart power.	5.76404763097206
11813. several	years ago headlines were made by a small radio transmitter capsule	which could be swallowed by the patient and which would then radio internal	pressure data to external receivers.	3.5548988312821375
11814. this original capsule contained	a battery and a transistor oscillator and was about 1 cm in	diameter.	5.150246658853786
11815. battery life limited the use of this pill to about 8	to 30 hours maximum.	4.074361125971572
11816. a refinement of this technique has been described	by drs zworykin and farrar and mr berkely of the medical	electronics center of the rockefeller institute.	5.04341596854167
11817. in this	novel arrangement the pill is much smaller and contains only a resonant	circuit in which the capacitor is formed by a pressure-sensing	transducer.	3.68595538952117
11818. as shown in fig 4 an external antenna is placed over	or around the patient and excited 3000 times a second with short 400-kc	bursts.	5.475500747678005
11819. the energy received by the pill causes the resonant	circuit to ring on after the burst and this ringing takes	place at the resonant frequency of the pill.	3.1686631169358637
11820. these frequencies	are amplified and detected by the fm receiver after each burst	of transmitted energy and after the pill has been calibrated	precise internal pressure indications can be obtained.	4.777032260172171
11821. one of	the advantages of this method is that the pill can remain in the	patient for several days permitting observation under natural conditions.	3.977075408658643
11822. applications to organs other than the gastrointestinal tract are	planned for future experiments.	5.763560815200224
11823. one	of the most gratifying applications of an important technique of submarine	detection is in the exploration of the human body.	4.413953436112784
11824. our readers	are familiar with the principles of sonar where sound waves are sent	out in water and the echoes then indicate submerged objects.	5.6534121925940894
11825. various	methods of pulsing scanning and displaying these sound waves are used	to detect submarines map ocean floors and even communicate under water.	3.1444255705336857
11826. in medicine the frequencies are much higher transducers and the	sonar beams themselves are much smaller and different scanning techniques	may be used but the principles involved are the same as in sonar.	5.163271165514348
11827. because the body contains so much liquid transmission of	ultrasonic signals proceeds fairly well in muscles and blood vessels.	3.706947852047047
11828. bones and cartilage transmit poorly and tend to reflect the ultrasonic	signals.	5.479531074810612
11829. based on this phenomenon a number of investigators have used	this method to look through human organs.	3.970505685773367
11830. a good example of	the results obtainable with ultrasonic radiation is contained in papers	presented by dr g baum who has explored the human eye.	4.969246182556908
11831. he	can diagnose detachment of the retina where conventional methods indicate	blindness due to glaucoma.	3.4286492565394697
11832. the method used to scan the eye ultrasonically	is illustrated in fig 6.	5.12253540309554
11833. the transducer is coupled to the	body through a water bath not shown.	3.4813515918266864
11834. for display dr baum uses	a portion of an f an airborne radar indicator and then photographs	the screen to obtain a permanent record.	5.064806225448796
11835. a typical sonogram	of a human eye together with a description of the anatomical	parts is shown in fig 5.	3.971164034789404
11836. the frequency used for these experiments	is 15 mc and the transducer is a specially cut crystal with an epoxy	lens capable of providing beam diameters smaller than one millimeter.	4.532376710484129
11837. the transducer itself moves the beam in a sector scan just like	a radar antenna while the entire transducer structure is moved over a	90-degree arc in front of the eye to look into all corners.	3.276051835601905
11838. the total	picture is only seen by the camera which integrates the many sector	scans over the entire 90-degree rotation period.	4.623256038727154
11839. drs	howry	and holmes at the university of colorado medical school have applied	the same sonar technique to other areas of soft tissue and have	obtained extremely good results.	3.505573426663146

11844. oersted's boyhood represented a minimal chance of either	attaining greatness or serving his people so well and over so long a	span of life.	4.840258147584723
11845. he was born in the small danish town of rudkoebing on	the island of langeland in the south-central part of denmark on august	14 1777.	3.6813052142621574
11846. his father soeren was the village apothecary whose slender	income made it difficult to feed his family let alone educate	them in a town without even a school.	5.124774737556087
11847. the two older boys hans and anders	his junior by a year therefore went daily to the home of a	warm	and friendly wigmaker nearby for instruction in german; his wife	taught the two boys to read and write danish.	3.179663492563273
11848. other brothers later joined	them for instruction with oldenburg the wigmaker and also arithmetic	was added to bible reading german and danish in the informal	curriculum.	4.959542435460062
11849. oldenburg's contributions were soon exhausted and the	boys had to turn to a wider circle of the town's learned such as	the pastor to supplement the simple teaching.	3.296463540277197
11850. from the town surveyor	hans learned drawing and mathematics and from a university student	some academic subjects.	6.091894555550861
11851. the mayor of the town taught them english	and french.	4.113731303374945
11852. whatever hans or anders learned separately they passed	on to each other; they read every book that they could borrow in the	village.	5.051207520174723
11853. at 12 hans was sufficiently mature to help his father in	the apothecary shop which helped stimulate his interest in medicine	and science.	3.569855238143688
11854. his earlier love for literature and history remained with	him for his entire life.	5.784682147278082
11855. in 1793 the brothers decided to enter	the university of copenhagen and the following	spring found them at the university preparing to matriculate for the	autumn session.	3.6551797087174718
11856. while hans devoted himself to the sciences of medicine	physics and astronomy his brother studied law.	5.6667362968534825
11857. the brothers continued	to help each other during their studies sharing a joint purse	lodging together in the dormitory and dining together at the home of	their aunt.	3.0487908747793013
11858. they supplemented their income by small government assistance	by tutoring and economizing wherever they could.	5.127098173462991
11859. so impressive	were those serious years of study at the university that hans later	wrote to be perfectly free the young man must revel in the great	kingdom of thought and imagination; there is a struggle there in which	if he falls it is easy for him to rise again there is freedom	of utterance there which draws after it no irreparable consequences on	society h.	3.386025060674755
11860. i lived in this onward-driving contest where each day	overcame a new difficulty gained a new truth or banished a previous	error.	4.974878276485287
11861. he openly proclaimed his pleasure in lecturing and writing	about science.	3.716810533257547
11862. in this third year at the university hans in 1797	was awarded the first important token of recognition a gold medal for	his essay on limits of poetry and prose.	5.445747215914355
11863. he completed his training	in pharmacy also taking his degree with high honors in 1797	and in 1799 was awarded the degree of doctor of philosophy along with	a prize for an essay in medicine.	3.2561947862521765
11864. he proposed a fresh theory of alkalis	which later was accepted in chemical practices.	5.697513424194561
11865. activity	han's student days were at a time when europe	was in a new intellectual ferment following the revolutions in america	and in france germany and italy were rising from divisive nationalisms	and a strong wave of intellectual awareness was sweeping the	continent.	3.297237116338127
11866. the new century opened with oersted beginning	his professional career in charge of an apothecary shop in copenhagen	and as lecturer at the university.	5.028230322411699
11867. he was stirred by the announcement	of volta's	discovery of chemical electricity and he immediately applied	the voltaic pile to experiments with acids and alkalis.	3.427328242085277
11868. the following	year he devoted to the customary wanderjahr traveling in	germany france and the netherlands meeting the philosophers schelling	fichte and tieck.	4.593811635011336
11869. he also met count rumford	who was then serving the elector	of bavaria and the physicist ritter; these were oersted's main	contacts in science.	3.2840445753987058
11870. from go^ttingen where he stayed	for 10 days he wrote the first question asked everywhere is	about galvanism.	5.7296392150159425
11871. as everybody is curious to see the battery of glass	tubes i have invented i have had quite a small one made here of	four glass	tubes and intend to carry it with me.	3.709248181043376
11872. oersted joined ritter at jena and stayed with him for 3 weeks continuing	their correspondence after he left.	5.4508225426024115
11873. with ritter he was exposed	to the fantastic profusion of ideas that stormed through his host's	fertile but disorganized mind.	3.5101672525802794
11874. oersted remodeled ritter's notes	into an essay in french which was submitted to the institut de france	for its annual prize of 3000 francs.	4.951029961098727
11875. the sound discoveries of	this quixotic genius were so diluted by those of fantasy that the prize	was never awarded to him.	3.1684756674495587
11876. in may 1803 ritter in another flight	of fancy wrote to oersted a letter that contained a remarkable prophecy.	5.128777244548681
11877. he related events on earth to periodic celestial phenomena and	indicated that the years of maximum inclination of the ecliptic coincided	with the years of important electrical discoveries.	3.4083558619958714
11878. thus 1745 corresponded	to the invention of the leiden jar by kleist 1764	that of the electrophorus by wilcke 1782 produced the condenser of	volta and 1801 the voltaic pile.	4.478507247442733

11885. during oersted's attendance at the university it was poorly	equipped with physical apparatus for experimenting in the sciences.	4.224225657200835

11891. eager as he was to pursue this promising	line he was so loaded down with the management of the pharmacy	and lectures in the medical and pharmaceutical faculties at the university	that he could devote only sunday afternoons to galvanizing.	3.331594549684054

11893. the	university was the only one in denmark and the status of professor	represented the upper social level.	4.098670243107277
