11898. his interest in finding a relationship between	voltaic electricity and magnetism is here first indicated.	5.746635349309722
11899. chapter	8 is entitled on magnetism and in it are included such	remarks as one has always been tempted to compare the magnetic forces	with the electrical forces.	3.3886470285851953
11900. the great resemblance between electrical	and magnetic attractions and repulsions and the similarity of their	laws necessarily would bring about this comparison.	4.69710760190442
11901. it is true that	nothing has been found comparable with electricity by communication;	but the phenomena observed had such a degree of analogy to those	depending on electrical distribution that one could not find the slightest	difference h.	3.4281529932314267
11902. the form of galvanic activity is halfway between	the magnetic form and the electrical form.	5.629575236996868
11903. there forces are more latent	than in electricity and less than in magnetism h.	4.26678370523171
11904. but in such	an important question we would be satisfied if the judgment were that	the principal objection to the identity of forces which produce electricity	and magnetism were only a difficulty and not a thing which is	contrary to it h.	5.171599652926726
11905. one could also add to these analogies that steel	loses its magnetism by heat which proves that steel becomes a better	conductor through a rise in temperature just as electrical bodies do.	3.321928957974159
11906. it is also found that magnetism exists in all bodies of nature as	proven by bruckmann and coulomb.	5.5996512875195865
11907. by that one feels that magnetic	forces are as general as electrical forces.	4.216349955026766

12612. every year about this time national gargle your cooling	system week rolls around.	5.87130348515721
12613. it pays in the long run to take good	care of the water works.	4.872538674938746
12614. do it this way for the summer gargle:	first drain that old coolant down the storm sewer.	6.494111101952181
12615. don't	save the anti-freeze even if it the expensive permanent type.	4.136738630657867
12616. the word means it won't boil away easily nothing else.	5.384162717558169

12631. spring and summer may be here officially but those thermos stay	in.	4.03608647915459

12633. if you	run into excess plug fouling on one truck check to be sure that the rig	has a thermostat.	4.17427928475983

13891. the	majority of children in the united states could benefit by some form	of orthodontic treatment says dr allan g brodie professor	and head of the department of orthodontics at the university of	illinois and a nationally recognized authority in his field.	3.862451617722936
13892. what do parents need to know about those years of the braces in	order not to waste a child's time and their money?	6.071696080186159
13893.  how can they	tell whether a child needs orthodontic treatment?	4.675198032830457
13894.  why and when should	tooth-straightening be undertaken?	7.804330364095896
13895.  what is it likely to cost?	5.882637166813505
13896. 	occlusion is the dentist's expression	for the way teeth fit together when the jaws are closed.	5.1142439645020925
13897. malocclusion	or a bad fit is what parents need to look out for.	3.9370368672567118
13898. one main type	of malocclusion is characterized by a receding chin and protruding upper	front teeth.	5.353488447313329
13899. a chin too prominent in relation to the rest of the	face a thrusting forward of the lower front teeth an overdeveloped lower	jawbone and an underdeveloped upper jaw indicate the opposite type	of malocclusion.	3.3328883236045983
13900. these two basic malformations have of course	many variations.	6.787151725006055
13901. a child probably requires some form of treatment	if he has any of the following conditions:  a noticeable	protrusion of the upper or lower jaw.	3.8909629302496485
13902. crooked overlapping	twisted or widely spaced teeth.	6.182048259188013
13903. front teeth not meeting	when the back teeth close.	4.429547263880529
13904. upper teeth completely covering	the lowers when the back teeth close.	6.0040033053534785
13905. the eyeteeth	beginning	to protrude like fangs.	3.7179718297676136
13906. second teeth that have come in before	the first ones have fallen out making a double row.	5.954862664638592
13907. contrary	to the thinking of 30 to 40 years ago when all malocclusion was	blamed on some unfortunate habit recent studies show that most tooth	irregularity has at least its beginning in hereditary predisposition.	3.452025260662425
13908. however this does not mean that a child's teeth or jaws must	necessarily resemble those of someone in his family.	5.972728169459358
13909. tooth deformity	may be the result of excessive thumb- or finger-sucking tongue-thrusting	or lip-sucking- but it's important to remember that	there's a difference between normal and excessive sucking	habits.	3.3400795608431952
13910. it's perfectly normal for babies to suck their thumbs and	no mother need worry if a child continues this habit until he is two	or three years old.	4.674052651574961
13911. occasional sucking up to the fifth year may not affect	a youngster's teeth; but after that if thumb-sucking pressure	is frequent it will have an effect.	3.88359317315066
13912. malocclusion can also	result if baby teeth are lost too soon or retained too long.	5.2905682872493625
13913. if a child	loses a molar at the age of two the adjoining teeth may shift toward	the empty space thus narrowing the place intended for the permanent	ones and producing a jumble.	3.4648175043455685
13914. if baby teeth are retained too long the	incoming second teeth may be prevented from emerging at the normal	time or may have to erupt in the wrong place.	5.582806568485322
13915. every orthodontist sees children who are embarrassed by	their malformed teeth.	4.098559801581752
13916. some such youngsters rarely smile or they try	to speak with the mouth closed.	5.629194545318953

13918. yet from the dentist's	point of view bad-fitting teeth should be corrected for physical reasons.	5.717926375119582
13919. bad alignment may result in early loss of teeth through	a breakdown of the bony structure that supports their roots.	3.6061630537689124
13920. this serious	condition popularly known as pyorrhea is one of the chief causes	of tooth loss in adults.	5.986294503205498
13921. then too misplaced or jammed-together	teeth are prone to trapping food particles increasing the	likelihood of rapid decay.	3.5730903513678087
13922. for these and other reasons says dr	brodie orthodontics can prolong the life of teeth.	6.396898899629193
13923. the failure of teeth to fit together when closed interferes with normal	chewing so that a child may swallow food whole and put a burden	on his digestive system.	3.3389479235537753
13924. because of these chewing troubles a child may	avoid certain foods he needs for adequate nutrition.	5.839788522766992
13925. badly placed	teeth can also cause such a speech handicap as lisping.	3.803809012916158
13926. how of straightening	most orthodontic work is done on children	between the ages of 10 and 14 though there have been patients	as young as two and as old as 55 says dr brodie.	5.572281893401881
13927. in	the period from 10 to 14 the permanent set of teeth is usually completed	yet the continuing growth of bony tissue makes moving badly placed	teeth comparatively easy.	3.313621021869122
13928. orthodontic work is possible because teeth	are held firmly but not rigidly by a system of peridontal membrane with	an involved nerve network to the bone in the jaw; they are not	anchored directly to the bone.	5.002572462425051
13929. abnormal pressure applied over a period	of time produces a change in the bony deposit so a tooth functions	normally in the new position into which it has been guided.	3.8538579162637276
13930. what	can 10-year-old susan expect when she enters the orthodontist's	office?	5.642299672414959
13931.  on her first visit the orthodontist will take x rays	photographs tooth measurements and tooth prints- an impression	of the mouth that permits him to study her teeth and jaws.	3.387145849664571
13932. if he decides to proceed he will custom-make for susie an appliance	consisting of bands plastic plates fine wires and tiny springs.	5.047711685480067
13933. this	appliance will exert a gentle and continuous or intermittent pressure	on the bone.	3.678974380299685
13934. as the tooth moves bone cells on the pressure side	of it will dissolve and new ones will form on the side from which the	tooth has moved.	5.357232123784969
13935. this must be done at the rate at which new bony tissue	grows and no faster.	4.788587256509348
13936. if teeth are moved too rapidly serious	injury can be done to their roots as well as to the surrounding	bone holding them in place explains dr brodie.	6.3340415114045205
13937. moving one	or two teeth can affect the whole system and an ill-conceived plan	of treatment can disrupt the growth pattern of a child's face.	3.39425172578644
13938. during the first few days of wearing the appliance and immediately	following each adjustment susan may have a slight discomfort or soreness	but after a short time this will disappear.	5.734926947992972
13939. parents are often	concerned that orthodontic appliances may cause teeth to decay.	4.038575658384135
13940. when	in place a well-cemented band actually protects the part of the tooth	that is covered.	5.813362099503714
13941. next susie will enter the treatment stage	and visit the orthodontist once or twice a month depending on the severity	of her condition.	3.7545749283089656

13943. last comes the	retention stage.	6.107327094811762
13944. susie's teeth have now been guided into a desirable	new position.	6.0159411590210965

14012. one way to do	this is by proxy sittings wherein the person seeking a message	does not himself meet with the medium but is represented by a substitute	the proxy sitter.	5.030170839578631
14013. if the latter knows nothing about the absent sitter	except his name he cannot possibly	give any clues conscious or unconscious far less ask leading questions.	3.3428476535743563
14014. all he can do is to be an objective and careful questioner seeking	to help the sensitive in clarifying and making more specific her paranormal	impressions.	6.014085893834841
14015. sometimes in these experiments appointment	sittings are used.	4.838465295888417
14016. here the absent sitter makes a date	with a communicator asking him	to come in at a certain hour when a channel will be open for	him.	5.71884390139958
14017. in this case the proxy sitter will know only the name of the communicator	nothing else.	4.50818619508045
14018. he gives this to the medium at the appointed	time and the reading then will be concerned with material about or messages	from the communicator.	5.52302361986221

14023. here again laboratory approaches	are being evolved for it is recognized how elastic these readings	can be how they can apply to many people and are often stated	in general terms all too easily applied to any individual's own case.	3.478791828347538
14024. if you look at a reading meant for someone else you will probably	see that many of the items could be considered as applicable to you	even when you were not in the picture at all! an interested sitter	may think the sensitive has made a hit describing something accurately	for him but can he really be sure that another sitter hearing	the same statement would not apply it subjectively to his own circumstances?	5.252016371023453

14035. methods have been developed of assigning weights	to statements; that is it is known empirically that names beginning	with r are more common than those beginning with z; that	fewer women are named miranda than elizabeth; that in the united	states more people die of heart disease than of smallpox.	3.2162315088829567

14040. it is very important indeed in the field	of extra-sensory perception and its relation to the survival hypothesis	to know whether the statements are actually only those which any	intuitive person might venture and an eager sitter attach to himself.	5.016894107592663

14381. but men willing to sail at all into waters where	wooden ships could be crushed like eggs were hard to find.	3.4192113443667345
14382. hudson	knew he had to use these men as long as he remained an explorer.	7.294745153247165
14383. and	he refused to be anything else.	4.924054970131128
14384. it is believed that hudson	was related to other seafaring men of the muscovy company and was	trained	on company ships.	5.471618699052042
14385. he was a londoner married with three sons.	5.000942724774431
14386. in 1610	hudson was probably in his early forties a good navigator a stubborn	voyager but otherwise fatally unsuited to his chosen profession.	4.9316480970496475

14389. greene was in actuality	a young ruffian from kent who had broken with his parents in	order to keep the company he preferred- pimps panders and whores.	3.35843172034072
14390. he was not the sort of sailor hudson wanted his backers to see on board	and he had greene wait at gravesend where the discovery picked	him up.	5.452036139691165
14391. for the first three weeks the ship skirted up the	east coast of great britain then turned westward.	4.3363082712516725
14392. on may 11 she	reached iceland.	8.617828950476344

14400. fog hung	over the route constantly.	6.953181329562874
14401. turbulent tides rose as much as fifty feet.	4.754829922614346
14402. the ship's compass was useless because of the nearness of the magnetic	north pole.	5.353758461050822

14411. patiently he explained what he knew	about their course and their objectives.	3.847554598437605
14412. when hudson had finished	the town meeting broke down into a general wordy	argument.	6.2763344984104465
14413. one man remarked that if he had a hundred pounds he would give ninety	of them to be back in england.	4.6429331722823814
14414. up spoke carpenter staffe who	said he wouldn't give ten pounds to be home.	5.526079340218114
14415. the meeting broke up.	4.338222572957455

14417. all through july the discovery picked her way along the 450-mile-long	strait avoiding ice and rocky islands.	3.6959855582662144
14418. on august 3 two massive	headlands reared out of the mists- great gateways never before	so far as hudson knew seen by europeans.	5.468047558875993
14419. to starboard was a cape	a thousand feet high patched with ice and snow populated by thousands	of screaming sea birds.	3.386048689068941
14420. to port was a point 200 feet high rising behind	to a precipice of 2000 feet.	5.481006201449294
14421. hudson named the capes digges and	wolstenholme for two of his backers.	4.285525618655276
14422. hudson pointed the discovery	down the east coast of the newly discovered sea	confident he was on his way to the warm waters of the	pacific.	6.01323243382709
14423. after three weeks' swift sailing however the ship entered	an area of shallow marshes and river deltas.	3.7216864372203506

14425. this must have	been hudson's blackest discovery.	4.698994017707924
14426. for he seemed to sense at once	that before him was no south sea but the solid bulk of the north	american continent.	5.683611474052741
14427. this was the bitter end and hudson seemed to	know he was destined to failure.	4.109505326826519

14430. hundreds of miles to the north the route back to england	through the furious overfall was again filling with ice.	6.1410023441594905

14437. juet had made plentiful enemies several men	stepped forward.	4.251078231078398

14450. thomas douglas fifth earl of selkirk a noble humanitarian	scot concerned with the plight of the crofters of his native highlands	conceived a plan to settle them in the valley of the red river	of the north.	5.466067680241783

14453. the grant which stretched	southward to lake traverse- the headwaters of the red- was	made in may 1811 and by october of that year a small group of scots	was settling for the winter at york factory on hudson bay.	3.0635024047780792

14457. within	a few years the scots engaged in breaking the thick sod and stirring	the rich soil of the valley were joined by a group called meurons.	3.4400754387874244
14458. the latter members of two regiments of swiss mercenaries transported	by great britain to canada to fight the americans in the	war of 1812 had settled in montreal and kingston at the close of	the war in 1815.	4.7725882111521685
14459. selkirk persuaded eighty men and four officers to go	to red river where they were to serve as a military force to protect	his settlers from the hostile northwest company which resented the	intrusion of farmers into the fur traders' empire.	3.260483228045761
14460. the mercenaries	were little interested in farming and added nothing to the output of	the farm plots on which all work was still done with hoes as late as	1818.	4.525058373887604
14461. it was the low yield of the selkirk plots and the ravages	of grasshoppers in 1818 that led to the dispersal of the settlement	southward.	3.82995120453051

14465. the selkirk settlers had been anticipated in their move	southward by british fur traders.	3.25630140190918

14467. when in 1816 an act of congress forced the foreign firm	out of the united states its british-born employees now become american	citizens- joseph rolette joseph renville and alexis bailly-	continued in the fur business.	3.4830855393112636
14468. on big stone lake near the	headwaters of the red river robert dickson superintendent of	the western indian department of canada had a trading post and planned	in 1818 to build a fort to be defended by twenty men and two small	artillery pieces.	4.9926028731762
14469. his trading goods came from canada to the forks	of red river and from selkirk's settlement he brought them south	in carts.	3.532831985821469
14470. these carts were of a type devised in pembina in the days	of alexander henry the younger about a decade before the selkirk	colony was begun.	5.230993522117324
14471. in 1802 henry referred to our new carts as	being about four feet off the ground and carrying five times as much as	a horse could pack.	3.607927278565776
14472. they were held together by pegs and withes and	in later times drawn by a single ox in thills.	5.493168538356528
14473. it was dickson	who suggested to lord selkirk that he return to the atlantic coast	by way of the united states.	4.495058948714011
14474. in september 1817 at fort daer	dickson met the noble lord whom with the help of a band of sioux	he escorted to prairie du chien.	5.251871593275629
14475. during the trip selkirk decided	that the route through illinois territory to indiana and the eastern	united states was the best route for goods from england to reach	red river and that the united states was a better source of supply	for many goods than either canada or england.	3.5239444128387225

14479. in 1819 grasshoppers again destroyed the crop at the	forks and in december 1819 twenty men left fort	daer for the most northerly american outpost at prairie du chien.	3.4130260462020052

14485. thereafter seed and food became	more plentiful and the colony remained in the north the year round.	4.366090797720429
14486. activity by british traders and the presence of a colony	on the red prompted the united state war department in 1819 to send	lieutenant-colonel henry leavenworth from detroit to put a post	300 miles northwest of prairie du chien until then the most advanced	united states post.	4.761485966651116

14512. the resultant town platted in 1847 and named for the patron of father	galtier's mission st paul was to become an important center	of the fur trade and was to take on a new interest for those selkirkers	who remained at red river.	4.663687046221192

14514. accordingly though	the practice violated the no-trading provision of the selkirk charter	which reserved all such activity in merchandise and furs to the	hudson's bay company some settlers went into trade.	4.654718538038419

14524. the letters of the common soldiers are rich in humor.	6.726298922130206

14541. william r stillwell	an admirable georgian whose delightful correspondence is preserved	in the georgia department of archives and history liked	to	tease his wife in his letters.	3.305658460994469

14548. the soldiers who comprised the rank and file	of the civil war armies were an earthy people.	5.193049825750433

14550. one of the most	common of camp maladies was diarrhoea.	6.686521810564452

14557. the letters	which poured forth from camps were usually written under adverse circumstances.	3.0882741523507713

14561. scarcity of paper caused many	southerners to adopt the practice of cross-writing ie after writing	from left to right of the page in the usual manner they gave the	sheet a half turn and wrote from end to end across the lines previously	written.	3.2870177205749562

14568. the most	common type of letter was that of soldier husbands to their wives.	5.4756715566544925

14570. rebs who owned slaves occasionally would include	in their letters admonitions or greetings to members of the negro	community.	5.3978589104507275
14571. occasionally they would write to the slaves.	5.498896921335763
14572. early in the	war it was not uncommon for planters' sons to retain in camp negro	body servants to perform the menial chores such as cooking foraging	cleaning the quarters shining shoes and laundering clothes.	4.780352161205187
14573. sometimes these servants wrote or dictated for enclosure with the letters	of their soldier-masters messages to their relatives and to members	of their owners' families.	3.234167663867925

14579. i told them some sweet lies and they believed it	all h i would tell them i got a letter from home stating that five	of my negroes had runaway and ten of pappies but i wold say i	recond he did not mind it for he had a plenty more left and then they	would lean to me like a sore eyd kitten to a basin of milk.	3.2820143235841184
14580. some of the letters were pungently expressive.	8.11097695231674
14581. an ohio soldier who	from a comrade just returned from leave received an unfavorable comment	on the conduct of his sister took pen in hand and delivered himself	thus: dear sis alf sed he heard that you and hardy was	a runing together all the time and he though he wod gust quit having	any thing mor to doo with you for he thought it was no more yuse h.	3.137467578240256

14610. private jenkins lloyd jones of the wisconsin light artillery wrote	in his diary: i strolled among the alabamans on the right	h found some of the greenest specimens of humanity i think in the universe	their ignorance being little less than the slave they despise	with as imperfect a dialect 'they recooned as how you'uns all would	be a heap wus to we'uns all'.	4.33807703606334
14611. in a similar vein but writing	from the opposite side thomas taylor a private in the 6th alabama	volunteers in a letter to his wife stated: you know that	my heart is with you but i never could have been satisfied to have staid	at home when my country is invaded by a thievin foe by a set of	cowardly skunks whose motto is booty h.	3.331379833161534
14612. the popularity of folklore in america stands in direct proportion	to the popularity of nationalism in america.	5.280680018183611
14613. and the emphasis on nationalism	in america is in proportion to the growth of american influence	across the world.	4.322217865239808
14614. thus if we are to observe american folklore	in the twentieth century we will do well to establish the relationships	between folklore nationalism and imperialism at the outset.	6.130338737308098
14615. historians have come to recognize two cardinal facts concerning nationalism	every age rewrites the events	of its history in terms of what should have been creating legends	about itself that rationalize contemporary beliefs and excuse contemporary	actions.	3.44504985020844
14616. what actually occurred in the past is seldom as important	as a country	superimposes its cultural and political attitudes on others it searches	its heritage in hopes of justifying its aggressiveness.	5.156978865864451
14617. its folklore	and legend usually disguised as history are allowed to account	for group actions to provide a focal point for group loyalty and to	become a cohesive force for national identification.	3.3650312044345467
14618. one can apply	these facts to britain in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries	as she spread her dominion over palm and pine and they can be	applied again to the united states in more recent years.	5.595673858174777
14619. the popularity	of local color literature before the spanish-american war the	steady currency of the lincoln myth the increased emphasis on the	frontier west in our mass media are cases in point.	2.9659391419425383
14620. nor is it an accident	that baseball growing into the national game in the last 75 years	has become a microcosm of american life that learned societies such	as the american folklore society and the american historical	association were founded in the 1880s or that courses in american literature	american civilization american anything have swept our school	and college curricula.	4.874903501076716
14621. of course nationalism has really	outlived its usefulness in a country as world-oriented as ours and its	continued existence reflects one of the major culture lags of the	twentieth-century	united states.	3.668530056421257
14622. yet nationalism has lost few of its	charms for the historian writer or man in the street.	5.982548809520852
14623. it is an understandable	paradox that most american history and most american literature	is today written from an essentially egocentric and isolationistic	point of view at the very time america is spreading her dominion	over palm and pine.	3.5371142575334567
14624. after all the average american as he lies and	waits for the enemy in korea or as she scans the newspaper in some vain	hope of personal contact with the front is unconcerned that his or	her plight is the result of a complex of personal economic and governmental	actions far beyond the normal citizen's comprehension and control.	5.06612578745593
14625. anyone's identification with an international struggle whether	warlike or peaceful requires absurd oversimplification and intense	emotional involvement.	3.389548142225757
14626. such identification comes for each group in each	crisis by rewriting history into legend and developing appropriate	national heroes.	5.272346384626087
14627. in america such self-deception has served	a particularly useful purpose.	3.963470865481852
14628. a heterogeneous people have needed it	to attain an element of cultural and political cohesion in a new and	ever-changing	land.	5.5991233737645185
14629. but we must never forget most of the appropriate	heroes and their legends were created overnight to answer immediate needs	almost always with conscious aims and ends.	3.6359879691123926
14630. parson weems's george	washington became the symbol of honesty and the father image of	the uniting states.	5.343336809989916
14631. abraham lincoln emerged as an incarnation of	the national constitution.	3.9267233572837936
14632. robert e lee represented the dignity	needed by a rebelling confederacy.	6.056505437531987
14633. and their roles are paralleled by	those of patrick henry nathan hale andrew jackson davy crockett	theodore roosevelt and many many more.	3.226277631986375
14634. therefore the	scholar as he looks at our national folklore of the last 60 years	most of the legends that are created	to fan the fires of patriotism are essentially propagandistic and are	the concept that an american national	folklore exists is itself probably another propagandistic legend.	4.653625936711027
14635. folklore is individually created art that a homogeneous group	of people preserve vary and recreate through oral transmission.	3.478508650225037
14636. it	has come to mean myths legends tales songs proverbs riddles superstitions	rhymes and such literary forms of expression.	4.993182234860855
14637. related to	written literature and often remaining temporarily frozen in written	form it loses its vitality when transcribed or removed from its oral	existence.	3.1603246843976986
14638. though it may exist in either literate or illiterate societies	it assumes a role of true cultural importance only in the latter.	6.000868438829295
14639. in its propagandistic and commercial haste to discover our	folk heritage the public has remained ignorant of definitions such as	this.	3.4989202103184427
14640. enthusiastically americans have swept subliterary and bogus	materials like paul bunyan tales abe lincoln anecdotes and labor	union songs up as true products of our american oral tradition.	4.496699797812079
14641. nor	have we remembered that in the melting pot of america the hundreds of	isolated and semi-isolated ethnic regional and occupational groups did	not fuse into a homogeneous national unit until long after education	and industrialization	had caused them to cast oral tradition aside as	a means of carrying culturally significant material.	3.124880441711414
14642. naturally	such scholarly facts are of little concern to the man trying to make	money or fan patriotism by means of folklore.	5.450819613216656
14643. that much of what he	calls folklore is the result of beliefs carefully sown among the people	with the conscious aim of producing a desired mass emotional reaction	to a particular situation or set of situations is irrelevant.	3.4531983103807837
14644. as long	as his material is americana can in some way be ascribed to the masses	and appears democratic to his audience he remains satisfied.	5.301393063358247
14645. from all this we can now see that two streams of development	run through the history of twentieth-century american folklore.	4.249121094883736
14646. on	the one side we have the university professors and their students trained	in teutonic methods of research who have sought out collected	and studied the true products of the oral traditions of the ethnic	regional and occupational groups that make up this nation.	5.212080524509343
14647. on the other	we have the flag-wavers and the national sentimentalists who have been	willing to use any patriotic frontier western or colonial material	willy-nilly.	3.4947768031962774
14648. unfortunately few of the artists	who have used american folklore	since 1900 have known enough to distinguish between the two streams	even in the most general of ways.	5.830366728356786
14649. after all the field is large difficult	to define and seldom taught properly to american undergraduates.	4.109248698884216
14650. in addition this country has been settled by many peoples of many	heritages and their lore has become acculturated slowly in an age of	print and easy communication within an ever-expanding and changing society.	5.022547268105706
14651. the problems confuse even the experts.	3.9187784020083396
14652. for that matter	the experts themselves are a mixed breed.	6.943961823869843
14653. anthropologists housewives	historians and such by profession they approach their discipline	as amateurs collectors commercial propagandists analysts or some combination	of the four.	3.089929375474509
14654. they have widely varying backgrounds and aims.	7.707208562355284
14655. they have little esprit de corps.	5.579924127450785
14656. the outlook for the	amateur for instance is usually dependent on his fondness for local	history or for the picturesque.	5.197553983517495
14657. his love of folklore has romanticism	in it and he doesn't care much about the dollar-sign or the footnote.	3.629445752317321
14658. folklore is his hobby and he all too rightly wishes it to remain	as such.	5.722473702862179
14659. the amateur is closely related to the collector who is	actually no more than the amateur who has taken to the field.	3.9383966771887113
14660. the collector	enjoys the contact with rural life; he hunts folklore for the	very field and stream reasons that many persons hunt game; and	only rarely is he acutely concerned with the meaning of what he has	located.	4.724985607045022
14661. fundamentally both these types the amateur and the collector	are uncritical and many of them don't distinguish well between	real folklore and bogus material.	3.5284641107971555
14662. but there are also the commercial	propagandists and the analysts- one dominated by money the other	by nineteenth-century german scholarship.	5.730722013966938
14663. both are primarily concerned	with the uses that can be made of the material that the collector	has found.	4.4437749535625475
14664. both shudder at the thought of proceeding too far beyond	the sewage system and the electric light lines.	5.808780069108387
14665. the commercial propagandist	who can't afford to be critical gets along well with the	amateur from whom he feeds but he frequently steps on the analyst's	toes by refusing to keep his material genuine.	3.003492169199115
14666. his standards are	of course completely foreign to those of the analyst.	6.805033854621803
14667. to both the amateur	and the commercial progandist the analyst lacks a soul lacks appreciation	with his endless probings and classifications.	3.5883818778973526
14668. dominated by	the vicious circle of the university promotion system the analyst looks	down on and gets along poorly with the other three groups although	he cannot deny his debt to the collector.	5.234954495035173
14669. the knowledge that	most americans have of folklore comes through contact with commercial	propagandists and a few energetic amateurs and collectors.	3.2977167755295347
14670. the work	done by the analysts the men who really know what folklore is all about	has no more appeal than any other work of a truly scientific sort	and reaches a limited learned audience.	5.002857607657291
14671. publishers want books that	will sell recording studios want discs that will not seem strange to	ears used to hillbilly and jazz music grade and high schools want quaint	but moral material.	3.1050860538352363
14672. the analyst is apt to be too honest to fit	in.	6.108280345240351
14673. as a result most people don't have more than a vague idea what	folklore actually is; they see it as a potpourri of charming moral	legends and patriotic anecdotes with a superstition or remedy thrown	in here and there.	3.539282177118174
14674. and so well is such ignorance preserved by the amateur	and the money-maker that even at the college level most of the	hundred-odd folklore courses given in the united states survive on sentiment	and nationalism alone.	5.457447201062681
14675. if one wishes to discuss a literary	figure who uses folklore in his work the first thing he must realize	is that the literary figure is probably part of this ignorant american	public.	3.8536546883749736
14676. and while every writer must be dealt with as a special	case the interested student will want to ask himself a number of questions	about each.	5.467230504306217
14677. does the writer know the difference between an ersatz	ballad or tall tale and a true product of the folk?	4.143168988459315
14678.  when	the writer uses material does he tamper with it to improve its commercial	effect or does he leave it pure?	5.360778805358215
14679.  is the writer propagandistic?	7.463754447514029
14680. 	is he swept away by sentiment and nostalgia for an america that was?	5.322820982344415
14681. 	or does he sincerely want to tap the real springs of american	attitude and culture regardless of how unpopular and embarrassing they	may be?	3.0981338396967595
14682.    when he gets the answers to his questions he will be	discouraged.	7.458703807307273
14683. in the first place a good many writers who are said to	use folklore do not unless one counts an occasional superstition or	tale.	3.8329482323001343
14684. robert frost for instance writes about rural life in new england	but he does not include any significant amount of folklore in	his poems.	5.722115313667493
14685. this has not however prevented publishers from labeling	him a folk poet simply because he is a rural one.	4.193111846324983
14686. in the second	place a large number of writers making a more direct claim than frost	to being folk writers of one sort or another clearly make	no distinctions between genuine and bogus material.	4.804382662964549
14687. stephen vincent	benet's john brown's body comes immediately to mind in this	connection as does john steinbeck's the grapes of wrath	and carl sandburg's the people yes.	3.0180152686253314
14688. the last two writers	introduce strong political bias into their works and not unlike the union	leaders that we will discuss soon see folklore as a reservoir of	protest by a downtrodden and publically silenced mass.	4.6709179066692155
14689. folklore as	used by such writers really reflects images engraved into it by the very	person using it.	3.7671715840646627
14690. the folk are simply not homogeneous with respect	to nation or political attitude.	5.149483804145759
14691. in fact there is much evidence to	indicate they don't care a bit about anything beyond their particular	regional ethnic and occupational limits.	3.7602803887976184
14692. nevertheless with a reading	public that longs for the good old days and with an awareness	of our expanding international interests it is easy for the benets	to obtain a magnified position in literature by use of all sorts of	americana real or fake and it is easy for the steinbecks and sandburgs	to support their messages of reform by reading messages of reform	into the minds of the folk.	5.02609396089018
14693. as part of the same arrangement torrio had in the spirit of peace	and good will and in exchange for armed support in the april election	campaign bestowed upon o'banion a third share in the hawthorne	smoke shop proceeds and a cut in the cicero beer trade.	4.028481199576978
14694. the coalition	was to prove inadvisable.	5.796364078801092
14695. o'banion was a complex and frightening	man whose bright blue eyes stared with a kind of frozen candour	into others'.	3.610352529551028
14696. he had a round frank irish face creased in a	jovial grin that stayed bleakly in place even when he was pumping bullets	into someone's body.	5.51901391848393
14697. he carried three guns- one in the right	trouser pocket one under his left armpit one in the left outside coat	pocket- and was equally lethal with both hands.	3.454531306071416
14698. he killed accurately	freely and dispassionately.	7.018463612176696
14699. the police credited him with twenty-five	murders but he was never brought to trial for one of them.	3.952834170340022
14700. like a fair number of bootleggers he disliked alcohol.	6.767733594970962
14701. he was an expert	florist tenderly dextrous in the arrangement of bouquets and wreaths.	3.928526380180934
14702. he had no apparent comprehension of morality; he divided humanity	into right guys and wrong guys and the wrong ones he	was always willing to kill and trample under.	5.102404557212536
14703. he had what was described	by a psychologist as a sunny brutality.	4.253314812421402
14704. he walked with a heavy	list to the right as that leg was four inches shorter than the other	but the lurch did not reduce his feline quickness with his guns.	5.0825419502091425
14705. landesco	thought him just a superior sort of plugugly but he was	in fact with his aggression and hostility and nerveless indifference	to risking or administering pain a casebook psychopath.	3.0386814950933965
14706. he was also	at this time although not so interwoven in high politics and the rackets	as torrio and capone the most powerful and most dangerous mob	leader in the chicago underworld the roughneck king.	4.879881206270596
14707. o'banion	was born in poverty the son of an immigrant irish plasterer	in the north side's little hell close by the sicilian quarter	and death corner.	3.349776265955869
14708. he had been a choir boy at the holy name cathedral	and also served as an acolyte to father o'brien.	5.913869133811326
14709. the influence	of mass was less pervasive than that of the congested slum tenements	among the bawdy houses honkytonks and sawdust saloons of his birthplace;	he ran wild with the child gangs of the neighbourhood and	went through the normal pressure-cooker course of thieving police-dodging	and housebreaking.	2.927043802258212
14710. at the age of ten when he was working as	a newsboy in the loop he was knocked down by a streetcar which resulted	in his permanently shortened leg.	5.575405252634135
14711. because of this he was known as	gimpy	.	5.688451798697071
14712. in his teens o'banion was enrolled in the vicious	market street gang and he became a singing waiter in mcgovern's	cafe a notoriously low and rowdy dive in north clark street where	befuddled customers were methodically looted of their money by the singing	waiters before being thrown out.	4.439932822192848
14713. he then got a job with the chicago	herald-examiner as a circulation slugger a rough fighter	employed to see that his paper's news pitches were not trespassed upon	by rival vendors.	3.531143271545994
14714. he was also at the same time gaining practical	experience as a safe breaker and highwayman and learning how to shoot	to kill from a neanderthal convicted murderer named gene geary later	committed to chester asylum as a homicidal maniac but whose eyes	misted with tears when the young dion sang a ballad about an irish	mother in his clear and syrupy tenor.	4.459265041173106
14715. o'banion's first conflict	with the police came in 1909 at seventeen when he was committed	to bridewell prison for three months for burglary; two years	later he served another three months for assault.	3.3462069269590176
14716. those were his only	interludes behind bars although he collected four more charges on his	police record in 1921 and 1922 three for burglary and one for robbery.	5.058304861559922
14717. but by now o'banion's political pull was beginning to be effective.	4.358815443052118
14718. on the occasion of his 1922 indictment the $10000 bond was	furnished by an alderman and the charge was nolle prossed.	5.25921616661183
14719. on one	of his 1921 ventures he was actually come upon by a detective sergeant	john j ryan down on his knees with a tool embedded in a labour	office safe in the postal telegraph building; the jury wanted	better evidence than that and he was acquitted at a cost of $30000	in bribes it was estimated.	3.2004833379870923
14720. as promptly as torrio o'banion jumped	into bootlegging.	6.633055244632644
14721. he conducted it with less diplomacy and more spontaneous	violence than the sicilians but he had his huge north side	portion to exploit and he made a great deal of money.	3.785183248865057
14722. unlike the	sicilians he additionally conducted holdups robberies and safe-cracking	expeditions and refused to touch prostitution.	5.409346306168594
14723. he was also personally	active in ward politics and by 1924 o'banion had acquired	sufficient political might to be able to state: i always deliver	my borough as per requirements.	3.43299644614213

14725. 	until 1924 o'banion pistoleers and knuckle-duster bullyboys had	kept his north side domain solidly democratic.	3.1554562043264105

14727.  a o'banion	in his pistol pocket.	4.378794343344965

14729. to forestall any change of allegiance	the democrats hastily organised a testimonial banquet for o'banion	as public reward for his past services and as a reminder of where	his loyalties lay.	3.2710012910513684

14735. hughes said that he had	understood the party was to be in honour of jerry o'connor the	proprieter of a loop gambling house.	4.038755718627504
14736. but when i arrived and recognised	a number of notorious characters i had thrown into the detective	bureau basement half a dozen times i knew i had been framed and	withdrew almost at once.	5.120871434301028
14737. in fact o'connor was honoured	during the ceremony with the presentation of a $2500 diamond stickpin.	3.7721282784279726
14738. there was a brief interruption while one of o'banion's men	jerked out both his guns and threatened to shoot a waiter who was pestering	him for a tip.	5.305228723776154
14739. then o'banion was presented with a platinum	watch set with rubies and diamonds.	3.8872698739288243
14740. this dinner was the start	of a new blatancy in the relationship between the gangs and the politicians	which prior to 1924 says pasley had been maintained with	more or less stealth but which henceforth was marked by these ostentatious	gatherings denounced by a clergyman as belshazzar feasts	at which politicians fraternized cheek by jowl with gangsters	openly in the big downtown hotels.	4.330920370439309

14746. this further demonstration of o'banion's ballooning power	did not please torrio and capone.	5.219411838969384

14755. that sort of braggadocio for that sort	of reason in the view of torrio and capone was a nonsense.	4.291309295638629
14756. a further example of the incompatible difference in personalities was	when two policemen held up a torrio beer convoy on a west side street	and demanded $300 to let it through.	4.977270642685434
14757. one of the beer-runners telephoned	o'banion- on a line tapped by the detective bureau- and	reported the situation.	3.700032494138171

14759.  why i can get them knocked off for	half that much.	4.532739699231295

14761. but in the meantime the beer-runner	unhappy with this solution telephoned torrio and returned to	o'banion with the message: say dionie i just been talking	to johnny and he said to let them cops have the three hundred.	3.496453904876131
14762. he	says he don't want no trouble.	6.4830934300900225
14763. but torrio and capone had	graver cause to hate and distrust the irishman.	3.988416815989557
14764. for three years	since the liquor territorial conference torrio had with his elastic	patience and because he knew that retaliation could cause only violent	warfare and disaster to business tolerated o'banion's impudent	double-crossing.	4.860979482545153
14765. they had suffered in sulky silence the sight of	his sharp practice in cicero.	3.892213388300137

14773. still more jealous bitterness was engendered by the o'banion	gang's seizure from a west side marshalling yard of a freight-car	load of canadian whisky worth $100000 and by one of the biggest	coups of the prohibition era- the sibley warehouse robbery	which became famous for the cool brazenness of the operation.	3.1199955486996904
14774. here was	stored $1000000 worth of bonded whisky.	7.110546329340116
14775. these 1750 cases were carted	off in a one-night operation by the o'banion men who left in	their stead the same number of barrels filled with water.	3.298289796868936
14776. a tsunami may be started by a sea bottom slide an earthquake	or a volcanic eruption.	5.316541664550725
14777. the most infamous of all was launched by the	explosion of the island of krakatoa in 1883; it raced across the pacific	at 300 miles an hour devastated the coasts of java and sumatra	with waves 100 to 130 feet high and pounded the shore as far away	as san francisco.	3.0771600624525837
14778. the ancient greeks recorded several catastrophic	inundations by huge waves.	4.93477398084845
14779. whether or not plato's tale of	the lost continent of atlantis is true skeptics concede that the myth	may have some foundation in a great tsunami of ancient times.	3.458769702513656
14780. indeed	a tremendously destructive tsunami that arose in the arabian sea	in 1945 has even revived the interest of geologists and archaeologists	in the biblical story of the flood.	4.951098155982842
14781. one of the most damaging	tsunami on record followed the famous lisbon earthquake of november	1 1755; its waves persisted for a week and were felt as far away	as the english coast.	3.673417915543668
14782. tsunami are rare however in the atlantic	ocean; they are far more common in the pacific.	6.234118263045057
14783. japan has had 15	destructive ones since 1596.	4.409568632654016
14784. the hawaiian	islands are struck severely an average of once every 25 years.	5.203160651303985
14785. in 1707 an earthquake in japan generated waves so huge that they piled	into the inland sea; one wave swamped more than 1000 ships and	boats in osaka bay.	3.08709740227152
14786. a tsunami in the hawaiian islands in 1869	washed away an entire town leaving only two forlorn trees	standing where the community had been.	4.923476378581387
14787. in 1896 a japanese tsunami killed	27000 people and swept away 10000 homes.	3.765611835673706
14788. the dimensions	of these waves dwarf all our usual standards of measurement.	4.955708063978362
14789. an ordinary	sea wave is rarely more than a few hundred feet long from crest to	crest- no longer than 320 feet in the atlantic or 1000 feet in the	pacific.	3.7548209347727175
14790. but a tsunami often extends more than 100 miles and sometimes	as much as 600 miles from crest to crest.	5.7682684221900695
14791. while a wind wave never	travels at more than 60 miles per hour the velocity of a tsunami in	the open sea must be reckoned in hundreds of miles per hour.	3.8107672681635125
14792. the greater	the depth of the water the greater is the speed of the wave;	lagrange's law says that its velocity is equal to the square root of	the product of the depth times the acceleration due to gravity.	4.97822400540345
14793. in	the deep waters of the pacific these waves reach a speed of 500 miles	per hour.	4.115033662317976
14794. tsunami are so shallow in comparison with their length	that in the open ocean they are hardly detectable.	5.762750455320563
14795. their amplitude	sometimes is as little as two feet from trough to crest.	4.188193632640667
14796. usually it	is only when they approach shallow water on the shore that they build	up to their terrifying heights.	5.829196997217348
14797. on the fateful day in 1896 when the	great waves approached japan fishermen at sea noticed no unusual swells.	3.4723556638758666
14798. not until they sailed home at the end of the day through a sea	strewn with bodies and the wreckage of houses were they aware of what	had happened.	5.796700664400545
14799. the seemingly quiet ocean had crashed a wall of water	from 10 to 100 feet high upon beaches crowded with bathers drowning	thousands of them and flattening villages along the shore.	2.988988095500783
14800. the	giant waves are more dangerous on flat shores than on steep ones.	5.512738906264294
14801. they	usually range from 20 to 60 feet in height but when they pour into	a v-shaped inlet or harbor they may rise to mountainous proportions.	3.225259920133523
14802. generally the first salvo of a tsunami is a rather sharp swell	not different enough from an ordinary wave to alarm casual observers.	5.679850904537833
14803. this is followed by a tremendous suck of water away from the shore	as the first great trough arrives.	4.2678649528529755
14804. reefs are left high and dry and	the beaches are covered with stranded fish.	5.531777198781952
14805. at hilo large numbers	of people ran out to inspect the amazing spectacle of the denuded beach.	3.772937677165987
14806. many of them paid for their curiosity with their lives for some	minutes later the first giant wave roared over the shore.	5.667905826060847
14807. after an earthquake	in japan in 1793 people on the coast at tugaru were so terrified	by the extraordinary ebbing of the sea that they scurried to higher	ground.	3.5184910041238946
14808. when a second quake came they dashed back to the beach	fearing that they might be buried under landslides.	6.4653840173061585
14809. just as they reached	the shore the first huge wave crashed upon them.	4.486615751903594
14810. a tsunami	is not a single wave but a series.	6.3495956241150315
14811. the waves are separated by intervals	of 15 minutes to an hour or more	and this has often lulled people into thinking after the first great	wave has crashed that it is all over.	3.5485050642182165
14812. the waves may keep coming for many	hours.	5.682544619344219
14813. usually the third to the eighth waves in the series are the	biggest.	4.753170488560258
14814. among the observers of the 1946 tsunami at hilo was	francis p shepard of the scripps institution of oceanography	one of the world's foremost marine geologists.	4.962917104018775
14815. he was able to make	a detailed inspection of the waves.	5.028118994121712
14816. their onrush and retreat he reported	was accompanied by a great hissing roaring and rattling.	5.7371107898292815
14817. the	third and fourth waves seemed to be the highest.	5.19330259066995
14818. on some of the islands'	beaches the waves came in gently; they were steepest on the	shores facing the direction of the seaquake from which the waves had come.	5.94312210454231
14819. in hilo bay they were from 21 to 26 feet high.	3.836369455779967
14820. the highest waves	55 feet occurred at pololu valley.	5.394489840545958
14821. scientists and fishermen	have occasionally seen strange by-products of the phenomenon.	3.935306754343909
14822. during	a 1933 tsunami in japan the sea glowed brilliantly at night.	5.736822461624465
14823. the	luminosity of the water is now believed to have been caused by the	stimulation of vast numbers of the luminescent organism noctiluca miliaris	by the turbulence of the sea.	3.6404611752356333
14824. japanese fishermen have sometimes	observed that sardines hauled up in their nets during a tsunami have	enormously swollen stomachs; the fish have swallowed vast numbers	of bottom-living diatoms raised to the surface by the disturbance.	4.570763999933075
14825. the	waves of a 1923 tsunami in sagami bay brought to the surface and	battered to death huge numbers of fishes that normally live at a depth	of 3000 feet.	3.236908191211317
14826. gratified fishermen hauled them in by the thousands.	6.533693042209724
14827. the tsunami-warning system developed since the 1946 disaster in	hawaii relies mainly on a simple and ingenious instrument devised	by commander c k green of the coast and geodetic survey staff.	2.969509691089846
14828. it consists of a series of pipes and a pressure-measuring chamber	which record the rise and fall of the water surface.	6.367047692481048
14829. ordinary water	tides are disregarded.	5.529907949732825
14830. but when waves with a period of between 10 and	40 minutes begin to roll over the ocean they set in motion a corresponding	oscillation in a column of mercury which closes an electric circuit.	5.0314623855487675
14831. this in turn sets off an alarm notifying the observers at the	station that a tsunami is in progress.	3.799543278685722
14832. such equipment has been installed	at hilo midway attu and dutch harbor.	5.89064791861986
14833. the moment the alarm	goes off information is immediately forwarded to honolulu which	is the center of the warning system.	3.5820060336976125
14834. this center also receives	prompt reports on earthquakes from four coast survey stations in the	pacific which are equipped with seismographs.	5.059090317363498
14835. its staff makes a preliminary	determination of the epicenter of the quake and alerts tide	stations near the epicenter for a tsunami.	3.4611743589232535
14836. by means of charts showing	wave-travel times and depths in the ocean at various locations it is	possible to estimate the rate of approach and probable time of arrival	at hawaii of a tsunami getting under way at any spot in the pacific.	5.061213072442912
14837. the civil and military authorities are then advised of the danger	and they issue warnings and take all necessary protective steps.	3.175861070500638
14838. all	of these activities are geared to a top-priority communication system	and practice tests have been held to assure that everything will work	smoothly.	5.20606663516909
14839. since the 1946 disaster there have been 15 tsunami	in the pacific but only one was of any consequence.	4.1599391043973
14840. on november 4	1952 an earthquake occurred under the sea off the kamchatka peninsula.	6.101143421564066
14841. at 17:07 that afternoon the shock was recorded	by the seismograph alarm in honolulu.	3.7638908396749096

14844. while accounts of the progress of the tsunami came	in from various points in the pacific	the hawaiian station made its calculations	and notified the military services and the police that the first big	wave would arrive at honolulu at 23:30 greenwich time.	4.894729403280938
14845. it	turned out that the waves were not so high as in 1946.	4.539310099165339

14849. but it is	plain that a warning system however efficient is not enough.	4.328616213398768
14850. in the	vulnerable areas of the pacific there should be restrictions against	building homes on exposed coasts or at least a requirement that they	be either raised off the ground or anchored strongly against waves.	5.719998424780542
14851. the key to the world of geology is change; nothing remains the	same.	4.427346237428759
14852. life has evolved from simple combinations of molecules in the	sea to complex combinations in man.	5.247502538847231
14853. the land too is changing and	earthquakes are daily reminders of this.	3.4415092925137114
14854. earthquakes result when movements	in the earth twist rocks until they break.	5.823179458592186
14855. sometimes this is accompanied	by visible shifts of the ground surface; often the shifts	cannot be seen but they are there; and everywhere can be found scars	of earlier breaks once deeply buried.	3.5043856981724115
14856. today's earthquakes are most	numerous in belts where the earth's restlessness is presently concentrated	but scars of the past show that there is no part of the earth	that has not had them.	5.6707827764715
14857. the effects of earthquakes on civilization	have been widely publicized even overemphasized.	3.4782192013748525
14858. the role of	an earthquake in starting the destruction of whole cities is tremendously	frightening but fire may actually be the principal agent in a particular	disaster.	4.76528966450784
14859. superstition has often blended with fact to color reports.	3.9573610692888765
14860. we have learned from earthquakes much of what we now know	about the earth's interior for they send waves through the earth	which emerge with information about the materials through which they	have traveled.	5.24865693224948
14861. these waves have shown that 1800 miles below the surface	a liquid core begins and that it in turn has a solid inner core.	3.8890959648292016
14862. earthquakes originate as far as 400 miles below the surface	but they do not occur at greater depths.	6.312619420480644
14863. two unsolved mysteries are	based on these facts.	4.635905118399602
14864. as far down as 400 miles below the surface	the material should be hot enough to be plastic and adjust itself to	twisting forces by sluggish flow rather than by breaking as rigid surface	rocks do.	4.896433095422318
14865. if earthquakes do occur at such depths why not deeper?	4.277128998250544
14866. 	knowledge gained from studying earthquake waves has been	applied in various fields.	5.17723199946372
14867. in the search for oil and gas we make	similar waves under controlled conditions with dynamite and learn from	them where there are buried rock structures favorable to the accumulation	of these resources.	3.2665018086421633
14868. we have also developed techniques for recognizing	and locating underground nuclear tests through the waves in the	ground which they generate.	5.548267417316218
14869. the following discussion of this subject	has been adapted from the book by	l don leet.	3.7445275364543007
14870. at twelve	minutes after five on the morning of wednesday april 18 1906	san francisco was shaken by a severe earthquake.	5.456626014607467
14871. a sharp tremor	was followed by a jerky roll.	4.45681205808264
14872. ireland's county limerick near the river	shannon there is a quiet little suburb by the name of garryowen which	means garden of owen.	5.752381299987032
14873. undoubtedly none of the residents realize	the influence their town has had on american military history	or the deeds of valor that have been done in its name.	3.721249659190493
14874. the cry garryowen!	bursting from the lips of a charging cavalry trooper was	the last sound heard on this earth by untold numbers of cheyennes	sioux and apaches mexican banditos under pancho villa japanese	in the south pacific and chinese and north korean communists	in korea.	4.236429494089839
14875. garryowen is the battle cry of the 7th u s cavalry	regiment the fighting seventh.	3.9339477793768456
14876. today a battle	cry may seem an anachronism for in the modern army esprit de corps	has been sacrificed to organizational charts and tables.	5.245691610759221

14878. of all the thousands of men who have	served in the 7th cav perhaps no one knows its spirit better than	lieutenant colonel melbourne c chandler.	5.963185423857245

14881. chandler had been commissioned in the medical	service corps and was serving as a personnel officer for the kansas	city medical depot when he decided that if he was going to make	the army his career he wanted to be in the fighting part of it.	3.7971204998872214

14885. first of all no unit likes to have a new co brought in from	the outside especially when he's an armchair trooper.	4.025186194408475

14890. but his first few days with troop	h were full of surprises beginning with first sergeant robert	early.	6.2467249787589685

14903. it didn't take captain	chandler long to realize that he had to carry a heavy load of tradition	on his shoulders as commander of troop h.	4.174044080812938

14917. he set out to keep troop h the best troop in the best regiment.	4.525911662293298
14918. one of his innovations was to see to it that every man- cook	and clerk as well as rifleman- qualified with every weapon in the	troop.	5.9973006166756395
14919. even the mess sergeant bill brown a dapper cocky transfer	from an airborne division went out on the range.	3.918785815827068

14921. carroll was sharp	and military but he was up against tough competition for that ra	berth and he wanted to play it cool.	3.942088921353137

14923. when the korean war began on june 25	1950 the anniversary of the day custer had gone down fighting at the	little big horn and the day the regiment had assaulted the beachhead	of leyte during world war 2 the 7th cavalry was not in the	best fighting condition.	3.7395928866155668
