15329. tetanus	could be avoided by pouring warm turpentine over a wound.	3.8426718236398685
15330. one family	bound wounds with bacon or salt pork strips or if these were not	handy plain lard.	5.242086628048569
15331. another sprinkled sugar on hot coals and held the	wounded foot or hand in the smoke.	3.742137195147589
15332. rabies were cured or prevented	by madstones which the pioneer wore or carried.	5.298400067287981
15333. in 1872 there were	known to be twenty-two in norton county and one had been in the	family for 200 years.	3.659214311162756
15334. another cure for hydrophobia was to suck the wounds	then cauterize them with a hot knife or poker.	5.471246944611803
15335. while nowadays	we recognize the fact that there are many causes for bleeding at	the nose not long ago a nosebleed was simply that and treatment had	little	variation.	4.213525010071489
15336. since a fall or blow might have caused it a cold pack	was usually first aid.	5.604137911281678
15337. this might be applied to the top of the nose	or the back of the neck pressed on the upper lip or inserted into the	nostril.	4.515237790282173
15338. nosebleed could be	stopped by wrapping a red woolen string about the patient's neck and	tying in it a knot for each year of his life.	4.849612334369998
15339. or the victim could chew	hard on a piece of paper meanwhile pressing his fingers tight in	his ears.	4.1012311299445505
15340. old sores could be healed by the constant application	of a wash made of equal parts vinegar and water.	5.343647118517518
15341. blood blisters could	be prevented from forming by rubbing a work blister immediately with	any hard nonpoisonous substance.	3.247142737443795
15342. felons were cured by taking common	salt and drying it in the oven pounding it fine and mixing it with equal	parts of spirits of turpentine; this mixture was then spread on	a cloth and wrapped around the affected part.	4.8684386246821205
15343. as the cloth dried more	of the mixture was applied and after twenty-four hours the felon was	supposed to be killed.	3.600551852224746
15344. insect bites were cured in many	ways.	6.737264959005488
15345. many an old-timer swore by the saliva method; get a bite	spit on it was a proverb.	4.125898657485777
15346. this was used also for bruises.	8.169742291666292
15347. yellow	clay was used as a poultice for insect bites and also for swellings;	not long ago denver mud was most popular.	3.709890844007406
15348. chiggers were a	common pest along streams and where gardens and berries thrived; so	small as to be scarcely visible to the eye they buried themselves in	the victim's flesh.	4.644261875888863
15349. bathing the itching parts with kerosene gave relief	and also killed the pests.	3.540118645056104
15350. ant bites were eased by applying liquid	bluing.	6.304390395178846
15351. for mosquito bites a paste of half a glass of salt and half	a glass of soda was made.	3.736613662645642
15352. for wasp stings onion juice obtained by	scraping an onion gave quick relief.	5.4178175702996425
15353. a handier remedy was to bathe the	painful part in strong soapy water; mud was sometimes used as well	as soap.	3.3472562936547883
15354. just plain old black dirt was also used as a pack to relieve	wasp or bee stings.	6.361830750763861
15355. bedbugs were a common pest in pioneer days;	to keep them out of homes even in the 1900's was a chore.	3.6928317848475687
15356. bed	slats were washed in alum water legs of beds were placed in cups	of kerosene and all woodwork was treated liberally with corrosive sublimate	applied with a feather.	4.539197090024252
15357. kerosene was very effective in ridding	pioneer homes of the pests.	3.844794914863195
15358. at times pioneer children got lice in their	hair.	7.019103612813838
15359. a kerosene shampoo seems a heroic treatment but it did the	job.	3.9901754769345295
15360. to remove an insect from one's ear warm water should	be inserted.	5.732091949427223
15361. a cinder or other small object could be removed from the	eye by placing a flaxseed in the eye.	3.378192221099297
15362. as the seed swelled its glutinous	covering protected the eyeball from irritation and both the cinder	and the seed could soon be washed out.	5.015143164676345
15363. another way to remove small	objects from the eye was to have the person look cross-eyed; the particle	would then move toward the nose where it could be wiped out with	a wisp of cotton.	3.6039462690703417
15364. shingles were cured by gentian an old drug	used in combinations.	5.740818936332996
15365. for erysipelas a mixture of one dram borax and	one	ounce glycerine was applied to the afflicted part on linen cloth.	3.6375598420758815
15366. itching	skin considered just nerves was eased by treating with	whiskey and salt.	5.268997091423891
15367. winter itch was treated by applying strong apple cider	in which pulverized bloodroot had been steeped.	3.4194757520437524
15368. to cure fungus growths	on mouth or hands people made a strong tea by using a handful of	sassafras bark in a quart of water.	4.948445769896883
15369. they drank half a cup of this morning	and night and they also washed and soaked their hands in the same	solution.	3.7527057616955006
15370. six treatments cured one case which lasted a month and	had defied other remedies.	5.568541885435484
15371. frostbite was treated by putting the feet	and hands in ice water or by rubbing them with snow.	3.5426076037012213
15372. now one hears that	heat and hot water are used instead.	6.391428473785135
15373. another remedy was oil of eucalyptus	used as well for chilblains.	4.323475933233158
15374. chilblains were also treated with	tincture of capsicum or cabbage leaves.	5.405684168477695
15375. boils have always been	a source of much trouble.	4.190598043042248
15376. a german informant gave me a sure cure	made by combining rye flour and molasses into a poultice.	4.972593859105199
15377. another poultice	was made from the inner bark of the elm tree steeped in water	until it formed a sticky gummy solution.	3.4633765339237024
15378. this was also used for sores.	9.339336831688017
15379. another frequent pioneer difficulty caused by wearing rough and heavy	shoes and boots was corns.	3.51801238403089
15380. one veracious woman tells me she has	used thin potato parings for both corns and calluses on her feet and they	remove the pain or fire.	4.731994034662397
15381. another common cure was to soak the	feet five or ten minutes in warm water then to apply a solution of	equal parts of soda and common brown soap on a kid bandage overnight.	3.3262008894044337
15382. this softened the skin so that in the morning when the bandage was removed	the corn could be scraped off and a bit of corn plaster put on.	5.640277438551651
15383. there were many cures for warts.	5.701544802916987
15384. one young girl told me how her	mother removed a wart from her finger by soaking a copper penny in	vinegar for three days and then painting the finger with the liquid several	times.	4.926088450698359
15385. another wart removal method was to rub each wart with a	bean split open and then to bury the bean halves under the drip of the	house for seven days.	3.2771400109417406
15386. saliva gathered in the mouth after a night's	sleep was considered poisonous; wetting a wart with this saliva on	wakening the first thing in the morning was supposed to cause it to disappear	after only a few treatments and strangely enough many warts did	just that.	5.031782845911738
15387. one wart cure was to wrap it in a hair from a blonde gypsy.	4.238966618365083
15388. another was to soak raw beef in vinegar for twenty-four hours tie	it on the wart and wear it for a week.	5.497419259162108
15389. a simpler method was to tie	a thread tightly around the wart at its base and wear it this way.	3.5154964806401416
15390. one person recommended to me washing the wart with	sulphur water; another said it should be rubbed with a cut potato	three times daily.	5.4337764957120225
15391. another common method was to cut an onion in two and	place each half on the wart for a moment; the onion was then fastened	together with string and placed beneath a dripping eave.	3.3402568784227467
15392. as the	onion decayed so did the wart.	7.016501728167982
15393. sore muscles were relieved by	an arnica rub; sore feet by calf's-foot an herb from the pioneer's	ubiquitous herb garden or by soaking the feet in a pan of hot water	in which two cups of salt had been dissolved.	2.953821346873411
15394. leg cramps one person	tells me were relieved by standing barefoot with the weight of the	body on the heel and pressing down hard.	5.106107461816358
15395. this does give relief as i	can testify.	4.5895451080791725
15396. one doctor prescribed a tablespoon of whiskey or brandy	before each meal for leg cramps.	5.3583808554287415
15397. pains in the back of the leg and in	the abdomen were prevented from reaching the upper body by tying a rope	about the patient's waist.	3.6657752002177033
15398. for sprains and swellings one	pint of cider vinegar and half a pint of spirits of turpentine added	to three well beaten eggs was said to give speedy relief.	5.036565718895132
15399. except for the wine waiter in a restaurant- always an inscrutable	plenipotentiary unto himself the genii with the keys to unlock	the gates of the wine world are one's dealer and the foreign shipper	or negociant who in turn supplies him.	3.1300461483002575
15400. in instances where	both of these are persons or firms with integrity the situation is ideal.	5.885450190624282
15401. it may on occasion be anything but that.	5.126523030690678
15402. however by cultivating	a wine dealer and accepting his advice one will soon enough ascertain	whether he has any knowledge of wines	and better yet whether he	has a taste for wine.	4.878635467996016
15403. again by spreading one's purchases over several	wine dealers one becomes familiar with the names and specialties	of reputable wine dealers and shippers abroad.	3.4287168428458448
15404. this is important because	despite all the efforts of the french government an appreciable	segment of france's export trade in wines is still tainted with a	misrepresentation approaching downright dishonesty and there are many	too many negociants who would rather turn a sou than amass a	creditable reputation overseas.	4.747091955318595
15405. a good negociant or shipper	will not only be the man or the firm which has cornered the wines from	the best vineyards or the best parts of them; he may also be the	one who makes and bottles the best blends- sound wines from vineyards	generally in his own district.	3.2774283176461836
15406. these are the wines the french themselves	use for everyday drinking for even in france virtually no one	drinks the grands crus on a meal-to-meal basis.	5.123413192491559
15407. the grands	crus are expensive and even doting palates tire of them.	3.2227716387407965
15408. and certainly	in the case of the beginner or the comparatively uninitiated wine	drinker the palate and the capacity for appreciation will not be ready	for the grands crus as a steady diet without frequent recourse	to crus of less renown.	5.0481115496327496
15409. there is nothing infra dig about a	good blend from a good shipper.	4.536674028014359
15410. some of them are very delicious indeed	and there are many good ones exported- unfortunately along with	others not so good and worse.	6.2543434691995
15411. consultation with a reputable wine dealer	and constant experimentation- steering ever from the known to	the unknown- are the requisites.	3.353195635173351
15412. wine waiters are something	else again; especially if one is travelling or dining out a great	deal their importance mounts.	5.168968702126477
15413. most of them the world over operate	on the same principle by which justice is administered in france and	some other latin countries: the customer is to be considered guilty	of abysmal ignorance until proven otherwise with the burden of proof	on the customer himself.	3.5286592195222037
15414. now the drinking of wine	is for the most part a recondite affair for manifestly if everyone	in the world who could afford the best wines also liked them the	supply would dry up in no time at all.	5.11921943211362
15415. this is the only valid and extenuating	argument that may be advanced in defense of the reprehensible	attitude of the common wine waiter.	4.237023099595537
15416. a really good wine waiter is	paradoxically the guardian of his cellar against	the visigoths.	5.342164348303958
15417. faced on the one hand with an always exhaustible	supply of his best wines and on the other by a clientele usually equipped	with inexhaustible pocketbooks it is a wonder indeed that all wine	waiters are not afflicted with chronic ambivalence.	3.790590145616654
15418. the one way to	get around them- short of knowing exactly what one wants and sticking	to it- is to frequent a single establishment until its wine waiter	is persuaded that one is at least as interested in wine as in spending	money.	4.80653157687486
15419. only then perhaps will he reveal his jewels and his bargains.	4.232996876001275
15420. wine bought from a dealer should ideally be allowed to rest	for several weeks before it is served.	6.089772873614738
15421. this is especially true of	red wines and a practice which though not always practicable is well	worth the effort.	3.6489128492678655
15422. it does no harm for wine to stand on end for a matter	of days but in terms of months and years it is fatal.	5.932979238699473
15423. wine stored	for a long time should be on its side; otherwise the cork dries	and air enters to spoil it.	3.785090596585804
15424. when stacking wine on its side in a bin	care should always be taken to be sure there is no air bubble left next	to the cork.	6.407516774048027
15425. fat bottles such as burgundies have a way of rolling	around in the bin and often need little props such as a bit of cardboard	or a chip of wood to hold them in the proper reclining posture.	3.713208599658834
15426. too much dampness in the cellar rots the corks again with ill effects.	6.189963672510851
15427. the best rule of thumb for detecting corked wine	is to smell the wet end of the cork after	pulling it: if it smells of wine the bottle is probably all right;	if it smells of cork one has grounds for suspicion.	3.224970166334959
15428. seasonal	rises or drops in temperature are bad for wine: they age it prematurely.	5.182958278171667
15429. the ideal storage temperature for long periods is about fifty-five	degrees with an allowable range of five degrees above or below	this provided there are no sudden or frequent changes.	3.159445737139519
15430. prolonged vibration	is also undesirable; consequently one's wine closet or cellar	should be away from machines or electrically driven furnaces.	4.578167709070222
15431. if	one lives near a subway or an express parkway the solution is to have	one's wines stored with a dealer and brought home a few at a time.	3.316327648619022
15432. light especially daylight is always bad for wine.	6.496869929792201
15433. all in	all though there is a good deal of nonsense expended over the preparations	thought necessary for ordinary wine drinking; many people go	to extreme lengths in decanting chilling or warming or banishing without	further investigation any bottle with so much as a slightly suspicious	cork.	3.4133502019235147
15434. no one should wish to deny these purists the obvious pleasure	they derive from all this and to give fair warning where warning	is due no one who becomes fond of wines ever avoids acquiring some degree	of purism! but the fact remains that in most restaurants including	some of the best of paris and bordeaux and dijon the bottle	is frankly and simply brought from the cellar to the table when ordered	and all the conditioning or preparation it ever receives takes place	while the chef is preparing the meal.	4.6761119159239435
15435. a white wine already at cool	cellar temperature may be adequately chilled in a bucket of ice and	water or the freezing compartment of a refrigerator	in about fifteen minutes; for those who live in a winter	climate there is nothing better than a bucket of water and snow.	3.472932160700087
15436. though	by no means an ideal procedure a red wine may similarly be brought	from the cellar to the dining room and opened twenty minutes or so	before serving time.	5.081104147982709
15437. it may be a bit cold when poured; but again	as one will have observed at any restaurant worth its salt wine should	be served in a large tulip-shaped glass which is never filled more	than half full.	3.4701395654341374
15438. in this way red wine warms of itself quite rapidly-	and though it is true that it may not attain its potential of taste	and fragrance until after the middle of the meal in	the meantime it will have run the gamut of many beguiling and interesting	stages.	5.721426438214127
15439. the only cardinal sin which may be committed in warming	a wine is to force it by putting it next to the stove or in front of an	open fire.	3.8044377128786215
15440. this invariably effaces any wine's character and drives	its fragrance underground.	5.404059247478897
15441. it should not be forgotten that	wines mature fastest in half-bottles less fast in full bottles slowly	in magnums- and slower yet in tregnums double magnums jeroboams	methuselahs and imperiales respectively.	3.3180804078701653
15442. very old red wines	often require several hours of aeration and any red wine brought from	the cellar within half an hour of mealtime should be uncorked and allowed	some air.	5.019497979167233
15443. but white wines never! white wines should be opened	when served having been previously chilled in proportion to their	sweetness.	3.507476508172271
15444. thus sauternes or barsacs should be very cold; a pouilly-fuisse	or a chablis somewhat less cold.	5.267637228675293
15445. over-chilling is an accepted	method for covering up the faults of many a cheap or poor white	wine especially a dry wine- and certainly less of a crime than serving	a wine at a temperature which reveals it as unattractive.	3.0535211445623247
15446. the fragrance and taste of any white wine will die a lingering death	when it is allowed to warm or is exposed for long to the air.	4.709134173968681
15447. to quote	professor saintsbury: the last glass of claret or burgundy	is as good as the first; but the first glass of chateau d'yquem	or montrachet is a great deal better than the last! this does not	mean though that a red wine improves with prolonged aeration: there	is a reasonable limit- and wines kept over to the next meal or	the next day after they have once been opened are never as good.	3.3044386387205553
15448. if	this must be done they should always be corked and kept in a cool place;	it should be remembered that their lasting qualities are appreciably	shorter than those of milk.	5.370386390130379
15449. a few red wines notably those	of the beaujolais are better consumed at cellar temperature.	3.6684763673716536
15450. by	tradition a red wine should be served at approximately room temperature-	if anything a little cooler- and be aged enough for the tannin	and acids to have worked out and the sediment have settled well.	4.909984805745861
15451. thus	red wine must if possible never be disturbed or shaken; very old	red wine is often decanted so that the puckering bitter elements which	have settled to the bottom will not be mingled with the wine itself.	3.328022283969501
15452. a tug-of-war between an old bottle and an inefficient corkscrew may	do as much harm as a week at sea.	4.984841410623213
15453. the cork should be pulled gradually	and smoothly and the lip of the bottle wiped afterward.	3.3174571825024954
15454. many	people use wicker cradles for old red wine lifting the bottle carefully	from the bin into the cradle and eventually to the table without	disturbing the sediment.	5.003235748269755
15455. another school frowns on such a shortcut and	insists that after leaving the bin an old red wine should first stand	on end for several days to allow the sediment to roll to the very bottom	after which the bottle may be gently eased to a tilted position	on its side in the cradle.	3.3144187971601005
15456. in france when one wishes to entertain	at a restaurant and serve truly fine old red wines one visits the	restaurant well ahead of time chooses the wines and with the advice	of the manager and his chef builds the menu around them.	5.008863036223412
15457. the wine	waiter will see to it that the bottles are taken from the bin and opened	at least in time to warm and aerate preferably allowed to stand on	end for as long as possible and perhaps in the case of very old wines	be decanted.	3.530518719474757
15458. decanting old wine aerates it fully; it may also be-	practically speaking- a matter of good economy.	5.626492482584624
15459. for in the process	of decanting the bottle is only tilted once instead of several	or more times at the table: hence a minimum of the undesirable mixture	of wine and dregs.	3.4743543293984605
15460. though there are many exceptions which	we have noted in preceding pages white wine is as a rule best consumed	between two and six years old and red wines nowadays between three	and ten.	5.4418252361961015
15461. red wines of good years tend to mature later and to keep	longer; the average claret is notably longer-lived than its opposite	number red burgundy.	3.3190259624176943
15462. some clarets do not come into their own until	they are ten or fifteen years of age or even more.	5.906872439593482
15463. if a red bordeaux	of a good name and year is bitter or acid or cloying and muddy-tasting	leave it alone for a while.	3.5124145673223808
15464. most of the wines of beaujolais on	the other hand should be drunk while very young; and alsatians	may be.	5.775183175644224
15465. giffen replied punctually and enthusiastically: rest assured that	your accompanying letter of instructions shall be in the letter	and spirit strictly complied with h and most particularly in regard	to that part of them relative to the completion of your noble and humane	views.	3.360783550520865
15466. giffen lost no time in visiting the plantation.	6.9810125125050835
15467. the slaves appeared to be in good health and at work under john palfrey's	overseer.	4.213504183742124
15468. an excellent crop was expected that year.	7.746795235075987
15469. william	who lived in neighboring st mary's parish had taken charge and	decided that it would be best for all if the plantation were operated	for another year.	3.7141664041990543
15470. giffen advised acceptance of this plan citing the	depressed market for land then prevailing and the large stock of provisions	at the plantation.	5.273518243759973
15471. if sold then the land and improvements might	bring only $5000.	4.455810606303588
15472. early in january 1844 he had a conference with	henry and william in new orleans and upon learning of gorham's	intention henry remonstrated calmly but firmly with his brother.	5.488739391824771
15473. the emancipation plan would not only be injurious to all the heirs	he contended but would be a form of cruelty perpetrated on the hapless	negroes.	3.736988491593059
15474. they were not capable of supporting themselves off the plantation	and louisiana law required their removal from the state.	5.4600022359796645
15475. gorham	refused to accept money for slave property but did he realize how	much expense and trouble the transportation of his negroes to the	north involved?	3.322889279793025
15476.  the suggestion that giffen hire out the slaves was	not realistic since no planter would take the risk of having negroes	who knew they were to be free living with his own slaves.	5.364130069902268
15477. henry hid	his annoyance although both he and william were furious with their	yankee brother.	3.848432822440647
15478. william who did not write to gorham told giffen	that unless he could operate the plantation as usual for a year he would	sue amicably to protect his interests.	5.637843278084288
15479. palfrey was	determined	that his portion of the slaves be converted to wage laborers	during the transition period before emancipation.	4.192551547956272
15480. if william wished	to continue operations for a year why not simply leave the negroes	undisturbed and pay them as high wages to remain there as are ever	paid the labor of persons of their sex + age.	5.062805502776953
15481. a disposition to exert	themselves for my benefit would perhaps be a motive with some of them	h to come into the scheme.	3.5511956108590184
15482. their having family ties on our plantation	+ the adjoining one would be a stronger inducement.	6.272918566414503
15483. when he heard	of his brothers' anger palfrey was still hopeful that they could	be persuaded to accept his notion of paying wages.	3.6041881089493617
15484. if not he was willing	to accede to william's wishes in any way that did not block	his ultimate aim.	5.721490807698482
15485. william was adamant on one point: under no circumstances	would he allow the negroes to remain on the plantation with his	and henry's slaves if they were told of their coming freedom.	3.4910768170566775
15486. knowing	the antipathy that existed in louisiana against increasing the	number of free negroes giffen suggested that palfrey bring them	to boston at once and then send them on to liberia.	4.796473350627029
15487. lacking specific	instructions he agreed to william's condition.	4.659976540925971
15488. in march	there was a division of the slaves and giffen carried out his instructions	as nearly as possible.	5.766446145480097
15489. of the fifty-two slaves giffen succeeded	in getting a lot of twenty twelve of whom were females.	4.392096600623622
15490. i considered	that your views would be best carried out he explained	by taking women whose progeny will of course be free + more fully extend	the philantrophy of emancipation.	4.94327348130131
15491. i have also taken the old servants	of your father as a matter of conscience + justice.	4.352905793718449
15492. the ages	of the slaves ranged from sixty-five for an old house servant to	an unnamed newborn child.	4.579892839206584
15493. if palfrey ever had any doubts about the	wickedness of slavery they were put aside after he received an inventory	of the slave property he had inherited.	3.553432904750206
15494. this cold reckoning of human	worth in a legal paper devoid of compassion or humanity was all	he needed.	4.941573213669669
15495. each human being known only by a given name had a cash value.	4.080935826329548
15496. old sam's sixty-five years had reduced his value to $150;	rose a twelve-year-old with child-bearing potential was worth $400.	4.9534846450017
15497. in rejecting any claim to the value of the slave property palfrey	was giving up close to $7000.	4.181258974175148
15498. palfrey's brothers each received	lots of sixteen negroes and for bookkeeping purposes it was agreed	that all lots were to be valued at $6666.	5.112940009721441
15499. thus twenty black	souls were to remain ignorant of their imminent journey to the land	of free men.	3.7002159221096163
15500. giffen extracted one concession from william: the house	servants could be free at any time gorham thought expedient.	5.498511996235474
15501. despite giffen's warning palfrey still had plans for freeing	his slaves in louisiana.	3.952060696346963
15502. yet even if he could get the necessary approval	fourteen of his negroes could not be manumitted without special	permission.	6.532030340085189
15503. according to state law a slave had to be at least thirty	years old before he could be freed.	4.84518982067225
15504. palfrey petitioned the state legislature	to waive the requirement.	6.666177651823738
15505. otherwise freedom would mean removal	from the state in which as the place of their past residence from	birth or for many years it would h be materially for their advantage	to be at liberty to remain.	3.7916646370754066
15506. on march 11 the louisiana legislature	voted unanimously to table the petition.	6.496631967677088
15507. news of the legislative	veto appeared in the new orleans papers and henry and william	became incensed by the fact that they had not been told of the attempt	in advance.	4.474986091890322

15885. she drew	on all her resources of mind and heart to help them- to make them	at home in the world; and as graduates gratefully recall she drew on	her purse as well.	3.4194705178456695
15886. many a student was able to remain at spelman only	because of her unobtrusive help.	6.593095940921038
15887. under miss upton the work	of the year 1909-10 went forward without interruption.	4.021590584817318
15888. after all	she had come to spelman seminary in 1888 and had been since 1891 except	for one year associate principal or dean.	5.202339905595801
15889. she had taught classes	in botany astronomy geometry	and	psychology.	4.8350984203123915
15890. miss upton and miss packard as a matter of fact	had many tastes in common.	6.516687098752345
15891. both had eager and inquiring minds; and	both believed that intellectual growth must go hand in hand with the	development of sturdy character and christian zeal.	3.416175941232999
15892. both loved the	out-of-doors including mountain climbing and horseback riding.	6.020778426706562
15893. in 1890	when the trip to europe and the holy land was arranged for miss	packard it was miss upton who planned the trip and with rare	executive ability bore the brunt of the entire pilgrimage from	beginning to end.	3.308108645245033
15894. so strenuous it was physically with its days of	horseback riding over rough roads that it seems an amazing feat of endurance	for both miss packard and miss upton.	4.997907948462936
15895. yet they thrived on	it.	6.293058348638691
15896. at the fifteenth	anniversary as already quoted miss	upton projected with force and eloquence the spelman of the future	as a college of first rank with expanding and unlimited horizons.	4.861471389591381
15897. when dr wallace buttrick wise in his judgment of people declined	to have the science building named for him he wrote miss tapley	h if you had asked me i think i would have	suggested that you name the building for miss upton.	3.4452260252815865
15898. her services	to the school for many years were of a very high character and i	have often thought that one of the buildings should be named for her.	6.123981037249959
15899. such were the qualities of the acting-president of the seminary	after the death of miss giles.	4.292714274151041
15900. at the meeting of the	board of trustees on march 3 1910 miss upton presented the annual	report of the president.	5.554392551096734
15901. she noted that no student had been withdrawn	through loss of confidence; that the enrollment showed an increase	of boarding students as was desired; and that the year's work	had gone forward smoothly.	3.2616913837134844
15902. she urged the importance of more thorough	preparation for admission.	7.122768812805592
15903. the raising of the $25000 improvement	fund two days before the time limit expired and the spontaneous praise	demonstration held afterward on the campus were reported as	events which had brought happiness to miss giles.	2.98945447390337
15904. with the fund in	hand the debt on the boilers had been paid; rockefeller and packard	halls had been renovated; walks laid; and ground had been broken	for the superintendent's home.	4.692050373629276
15905. miss upton spoke gratefully of	the response of spelman graduates and negro friends in helping to raise	the fund and their continuing efforts to raise money for greatly	needed current expenses.	3.4066838961742842
15906. she spoke also with deep thankfulness of the	many individuals and agencies whose interest and efforts through the	years had made the work so fruitful in results.	4.9796714463545415
15907. two bequests	were recorded: one of $200 under the will of mrs harriet a	copp of los angeles; and one of $2000 under the will of miss celia	l brett of hamilton new york a friend from the early days.	3.648065231185945
15908. miss upton told the trustees that the death of miss giles	was the sorest grief the seminary had ever been called upon	to bear.	5.610143950412803
15909. the daughters of spelman she said had never known or thought	of spelman without her.	3.278131120286422
15910. the removal of miss packard 18 years earlier	had caused them great sorrow but they still had miss giles.	5.24157374259934
15911. now the school was indeed bereft.	5.854174856586736
15912. yet spelman has strong deep roots	and will live for the blessing of generations to come.	5.576408553001405
15913. miss mary jane packard sophia's half-sister became ill in	march 1910; and when school closed she was unable to travel to massachusetts.	3.511772870238664
15914. she remained in atlanta through june and july; she	died on august sixth.	5.799862314912646
15915. before coming on a visit to spelman	in 1885 miss mary had been a successful teacher in worcester and	her position there was held open for her for a considerable period.	3.8209326693762207
15916. but	she decided to stay at spelman.	7.282057842894028
15917. she helped with teaching as well	as office work for a few years- the catalogues show that she had classes	in geography rhetoric and bookkeeping.	3.7506246917282207
15918. soon the office work claimed	all her time.	7.207739235689933
15919. she was closely associated with the founders in all	their trials and hardships.	4.363492299262223
15920. quiet and energetic cheerful and calm	she too was a power in the development of the seminary.	6.13152396433418
15921. miss giles	always used to refer to her as sister.	4.794543105678146
15922. she served as secretary	in the seminary office for 25 years and was in charge of correspondence	records and bookkeeping.	6.094868507413877
15923. the books of the school hold a memorial	to her; and so do the hearts of students and of teachers.	3.690844687691552
15924. mary j packard states a messenger editorial was efficient	pains-taking self-effacing loving radiating the spirit of her	master.	5.573083162524061
15925. with infinite patience she responded to every call no matter	at what cost to herself and to her all went for she was sure to	have the needed information or word of cheer.	3.331597288878283
15926. in a few school districts one finds a link between school and	job.	6.620236546692586
15927. in those vocational programs organized with smith-hughes money	there may be a close tie between the labor union and a local employer	on the one hand and the vocational teacher on the other.	3.8595352759101673
15928. in these cases	a graduate may enter directly into an apprentice program saving	a year because of his vocational courses in grades 11 and 12.	5.531867028768157
15929. the apprentice	program will involve further education on a part-time basis usually	at night perhaps using some of the same equipment of the high	school.	3.4536989727869836
15930. these opportunities are to be found in certain cities in such	crafts as auto mechanics carpentry drafting electrical work tool-and-die	work and sheet-metal work.	5.3112657381534225
15931. formally organized vocational	programs supported by federal funds allow high school students to	gain experience in a field of work which is likely to lead to a full-time	job on graduation.	3.8368048972307434
15932. the diversified occupations program is a	part-time trade-preparatory program conducted over two school years on	a cooperative basis between the school and local industrial and business	employers.	4.4867701948143575
15933. the distributive education program operates in	a similar way with arrangements between the school and employers in	merchandising	fields.	3.3337831435392444
15934. in both cases the student attends school half-time	and works in a regular job the other half.	5.831957940040705
15935. he receives remuneration	for his work.	4.686636604752437
15936. in a few places cooperative programs between schools	and employers in clerical work have shown the same possibilities for allowing	the student while still in school to develop skills which are	immediately marketable upon graduation.	5.049127865896487
15937. adult education courses	work-study programs of various sorts- these are all evidence of	a continuing interest of the schools in furthering educational opportunities	for out-of-school youth.	3.4526149064151226
15938. in general however it may be said	that when a boy or a girl leaves the high school the school authorities	play little or no part in the decision of what happens next.	6.279339114417796
15939. if the	student drops out of high school the break with the school is even	more complete.	4.6323849359150016
15940. when there is employment opportunity for youth this	arrangement- or lack of arrangement- works out quite well.	5.6705588844176225
15941. indeed	in some periods of our history and in some neighborhoods the job opportunities	have been so good that undoubtedly a great many boys who were	potential members of the professions quit school at an early age and	went to work.	3.5647262192832705
15942. statistically this has represented a loss to the nation	although one must admit that in an individual case the decision in	retrospect may have been a wise one.	5.644469972990522
15943. i make no attempt to measure the	enduring satisfaction and material well-being of a man who went to work	on graduation from high school and was highly successful in the business	which he entered.	3.91158150659901
15944. he may or may not be better off than his	classmate who went on to a college and professional school.	6.738284879363466
15945. but in	the next decades the nation needs to educate for the professions all	the potential professional talent.	3.572741361644253
15946. in a later chapter dealing	with the suburban school i shall discuss the importance of arranging	a program for the academically talented and highly gifted youth in any	high school where he is found.	5.1805458004626
15947. in the negro neighborhoods and also	to some extent in the mixed neighborhoods the problem may be one of	identification and motivation.	3.6769041825776894
15948. high motivation towards higher education	must start early enough so that by the time the boy or girl reaches	grade 9 he or she has at least developed those basic skills which are	essential for academic work.	5.2319686189724965
15949. undoubtedly far more can be done in the	lower grades in this regard in the negro schools.	4.540298677188453
15950. however the teacher	can only go so far if the attitude of the community and the family	is anti-intellectual.	6.894737834817887
15951. and the fact remains that there are today few	shining examples of negroes in positions of intellectual leadership.	4.826235708296906
15952. this is not due to any policy of discrimination on the part of the northern	universities.	7.235701716379934
15953. quite the contrary as i can testify from personal	experience as a former university president.	4.3079872488951665
15954. rather we see here	another vicious circle.	7.386427935333034
15955. the absence of successful negroes in the world	of scholarship and science has tended to tamp down enthusiasm among	negro youth for academic careers.	3.4839047375885617
15956. i believe the situation is improving	but the success stories need to be heavily publicized.	7.101282803990791
15957. here again	we run into the roadblock that negroes do not like to be designated	as negroes in the press.	4.241173919631063
15958. how can the vicious circle be broken?	7.930817569135098
15959.  this	is a problem to which leaders of opinion both negro and white	should devote far more attention.	3.8906721241601674
15960. it is at least as important as the	more dramatic attempts to break down barriers of inequality in the south.	6.182760148253
15961. i should like to underline four points	i made in my first report with respect to vocational education.	3.933738806153965
15962. first	and foremost vocational courses should not replace courses which	are essential parts of the required academic program for graduation.	5.560067465492394
15963. second	vocational courses should be provided in grades 11 and 12 and	not require more than half the student's time in those years; however	for slow learners and prospective dropouts these courses ought to	begin earlier.	3.185503827770343
15964. third the significance of the vocational courses is	that those enrolled are keenly interested in the work; they realize	the relevance of what they are learning to their future careers and this	sense of purpose is carried over to the academic courses which they	are studying at the same time.	5.30990874133622
15965. fourth the type of vocational training	programs should be related to the employment opportunities in the	general locality.	3.9697080212519062
15966. this last point is important because if high school	pupils are aware that few if any graduates who have chosen a certain	vocational program have obtained a job as a consequence of the training	the whole idea of relevance disappears.	4.964787133862941
15967. vocational training which	holds no hope that the skill developed will be in fact a marketable	skill becomes just another school chore for those whose interest	in their studies has begun to falter.	3.5891643870809866
15968. those who because of population	mobility and the reputed desire of employers to train their own employees	would limit vocational education to general rather than specific	skills ought to bear in mind the importance of motivation in any kind	of school experience.	4.98197566832755
15969. i have been using the word vocational	as a layman would at first sight think it should be used.	4.277359842431041
15970. i intend	to include under the term all the practical courses open to boys	and girls.	5.699545639358849
15971. these courses develop skills other than those we think of	when we use the adjective academic.	3.8269510852396826
15972. practically all of these practical	skills are of such a nature that a degree of mastery can be obtained	in high school sufficient to enable the youth to get a job at	once on the basis of the skill.	5.848619103563004
15973. they are in this sense skills marketable	immediately on graduation from high school.	4.959317446651428
15974. to be sure in tool-and-die	work and in the building trades the first job must be often	on an apprentice basis but two years of half-time vocational training	enables the young man thus to anticipate one year of apprentice status.	5.596602997864921
15975. similarly a girl who graduates with a good working knowledge of stenography	and the use of clerical machines and who is able to get a job	at once may wish to improve her skill and knowledge by a year or two	of further study in a community college or secretarial school.	3.711533665914506
15976. of course	it can be argued that an ability to write english correctly and	with some degree of elegance is a marketable skill.	5.509084206933182
15977. so too is the	mathematical	competence of a college graduate who has majored in mathematics.	4.187990436490919
15978. in a sense almost all high school and college courses could be	considered as vocational to the extent that later in life the student	in his vocation will be called upon to use	some of the skills developed and the competence obtained.	5.301523731992618
15979. in spite	of the shading of one type of course into another i believe it is useful	to talk about vocational courses as apart from academic courses.	3.527487459618779
15980. perhaps a course in typewriting might be regarded as the exception which	proves the rule.	6.743551075849924
15981. today many college bound students try to take a	course in personal typing as they feel a certain degree of mastery of	this skill is almost essential for one who proposes to do academic work	in college and a professional school.	3.394506267572008
15982. most of our largest	cities have one or more separate vocational or technical high schools.	6.954340841059927
15983. in this respect public education in the large cities differs from education	in the smaller cities and consolidated school districts.	3.98770790944214
15984. the	neighborhood high schools are not strictly speaking comprehensive schools	because some of the boys and girls may be attending a vocational	or technical high school instead of the local school.	5.789189142712123
15985. indeed one	school superintendent in a large city objects to the use of the term	comprehensive	high school for the senior high schools in his city because	these schools do not offer strictly vocational programs.	4.040032481027029
15986. he prefers	to designate such schools as general high schools.	5.885699153774174
15987. the suburban	high school it is worth noting also is not a widely comprehensive	high school because of the absence of vocational programs.	3.962018261086417
15988. the reason	is that there is a lack of interest on the part of the community.	7.252316448486804
15989. therefore	employment and education in all the schools in a metropolitan	area are related in different ways from those which are characteristic	of the comprehensive high school described in my first report.	3.689491074212074
15990. the separate vocational or technical high schools in the large cities	must be reckoned as permanent institutions.	5.3943519488177545
15991. by and large their programs	are satisfactorily connected both to the employment situation and	to the realities of the apprentice system.	3.8118052258246724
15992. it is not often realized	to what degree certain trades are in many communities closed areas of	employment except for a lucky few.	5.396239595184503
15993. one has to talk confidentially with	some of the directors of vocational high schools to realize that a	boy cannot just say i want to be a plumber and then by doing	good work find a job.	3.912437402945142
15994. it is far more difficult in many communities	to obtain admission to an apprentice program which involves union approval	than to get into the most selective medical school in the nation.	5.643749375242763
15995. two stories will illustrate what i have in mind.	4.991032718671067
15996. one vocational instructor	in a city vocational school speaking of his course in a certain	field said he had no difficulty placing all students in jobs outside	of the city.	5.386123774028865
15997. in the city he said the waiting list for those	who want to join the union is so long that unless a boy has an inside	track he can't get in.	4.012263386287267
15998. in a far distant part of the united states	i was talking to an instructor about a boy who in the twelfth grade	was doing special work.	6.518775622561437
15999. what does he have in mind to do when he	graduates?	5.250006805719212
16000.  oh he'll be a plumber came the answer.	6.959770930656972
16001. but	isn't it almost impossible to get into the union?	4.761102950225223
16002.  i asked.	11.036555719764213
16003. he'll have no difficulty i was told.	4.610929223678916
16004. he has very good	connections.	9.279011926614878
16005. in my view there should be a school which offers	significant vocational programs for boys within easy reach of every	family in a city.	3.853442678196173
16006. ideally these schools should be so located that	one or more should be in the area where demand for practical courses is	at the highest.	5.775970831626279
16007. an excellent example of a successful location	of a new vocational high school is the dunbar vocational high school	in chicago.	4.001525431938328
16008. located in a bad slum area now undergoing redevelopment	this school and its program are especially tailored to the vocational	aims of its students.	4.98115145588813
16009. hardly a window has been broken since	dunbar	first was opened	.	4.451341649416764
16010. i discovered in the course of a visit there that almost	all the pupils were negroes.	6.349378591372346
16011. they were learning trades as diverse	as shoe repairing bricklaying carpentry cabinet making auto mechanics	and airplane mechanics.	3.377805729474608
16012. the physical facilities at dunbar are	impressive but more impressive is the attitude of the pupils.	5.478892397003062
16013. the soybean seed is the most important leguminous food in the	world.	4.001127797188773
16014. in the united states where half of the world crop is grown	soybeans are processed for their edible oil.	7.232181681191164
16015. the residue from soybean	processing goes mainly into animal feeds.	3.2739559583728566
16016. soybeans are extensively	processed into a remarkable number of food products in the orient.	5.533034457175527
16017. american chemists seeking to increase exports of soybeans have	adapted modern techniques and fermentation methods to improve their	use in such traditional japanese foods as tofu and miso and in tempeh	of indonesia.	3.1710219315218837
16018. soybean flour grits flakes milk and curd can	be bought in the united states.	6.278549298932917
16019. peanuts are the world's	second most important legume.	4.316507289196969
16020. they are used mainly for their oil.	7.990411948690678
16021. we	produce peanut oil but to a much greater extent we eat the entire seed.	3.7990560809129197
16022. blanched peanuts as prepared for making peanut butter or for eating	as nuts are roasted seeds whose seedcoats have been rubbed off.	4.704021819672127
16023. cereal grains supplemented with soybeans or dry edible peas or beans	comprise about two-thirds or three-fourths of the diet in parts of	asia and africa.	3.1439796213751467
16024. in western europe and north america where	the level of economic development is higher grains and other seed	products furnish less than one-third of the food consumed.	5.378214363821506
16025. rather	meat and potatoes sugar and dairy products are the main sources of	carbohydrate	protein oils and fats.	3.590943295112403
16026. people depend less on seeds for	foods in australia new zealand and argentina where extensive grazing	lands support sheep or cattle and the consumption of meat is high.	4.801771795594259
16027. feeds for livestock took about one-sixth of the world's	cereal crop in 1957-1958.	3.6202154837430127
16028. most of the grain is fed to swine and dairy	cows and lesser amounts to beef cattle and poultry.	5.781355722730654
16029. about 90 percent	of the corn used in the united states is fed to animals.	5.443909733979485
16030. the rest	is used for human food and industrial products.	5.35919046723483
16031. more than half of the	sorghum and barley seeds we produce and most of the byproducts of the	milling of cereals and the crushing of oilseeds are fed to livestock.	3.63784090906467
16032. more than 200 million tons of seeds and seed products are fed	to livestock annually in the united states.	6.694195808354904
16033. the efficiency	with which animals convert grains and forages to meat has risen steadily	in the united states since the 1930's and has paralleled the increased	feeding of the cake and meal that are a byproduct when seeds	are processed for oil.	3.0673963634217603
16034. the demand for food is so great in	the world that little arable land can be given over to growing the nonfood	crops.	5.302102327651656
16035. seeds grown for industrial uses hold a relatively minor	position.	4.4993702892178735
16036. chief among the seed crops grown primarily for industrial	uses are the oil-bearing seeds- flax castor tung	perilla and oiticica	.	4.972194126584992
16037. oils or liquid fats from the	seeds of flax and tung have long been the principal constituents of paints	and varnishes for protecting and beautifying the surfaces of wood	and metal.	3.092590253943143
16038. these oils develop hard smooth films when they dry and form	resinlike substances.	5.530522984063367
16039. the artist who paints in oil uses drying	oils to carry the pigments and to protect his finished work for the	ages.	3.4980811685640814
16040. one of the finest of artists' oils comes from poppy seeds.	6.457877095760962
16041. seeds of soybean cotton corn sesame and rape yield semidrying	oils.	4.092739756334606
16042. some are used in paints along with drying oils.	7.513632102507015
16043. palm oil	protects the surfaces of steel sheets before they are plated with tin.	3.660698235382483
16044. castor oil made from castorbeans has gone out of style as a	medicine.	5.831181288001266
16045. this nondrying oil however is now more in demand than ever	before as a fine lubricant as a constituent of fluids for hydraulically	operated equipment and as a source of chemicals to make plastics.	3.4084517883065075
16046. almond oil another nondrying oil was once used extensively	in perfumery to extract flower fragrances.	5.055490866473619
16047. it is still used in drugs	and cosmetics but it is rather scarce and sometimes is adulterated with	oils from peach and plum seeds.	3.7738341661489176
16048. liquid fats from all these	oilseeds enter into the manufacture of soaps for industry and the household	and of glycerin for such industrial uses as making explosives.	5.027989428621366
16049. sizable amounts of soybean coconut and palm kernel oil- seed	oils that are produced primarily for food purposes- also are used	to make soaps detergents and paint resins.	3.0912482365080156
16050. solid fats from	the seeds of the mahua tree the shea tree and the coconut palm are used	to make candles in tropical countries.	5.118631099523057
16051. seeds are a main source	of starch for industrial and food use in many parts of the world.	4.174280913357474
16052. corn and wheat supply most of the starch in the united states canada	and australia.	6.996494153850537
16053. in other countries where cereal grains are not	among the principal crops of a region starchy tubers or roots are processed	for starch.	3.5105748883935752
16054. starch is used in the paper textile and food-processing	industries and in a multitude of other manufacturing operations.	6.171928363888234
16055. gums were extracted from quince psyllium flax	and locust seeds in ancient times.	3.4836575047882574
16056. today the yearly import	into the united states of locust bean gum is more than 15 million pounds;	of psyllium seed more than 2.	6.257460172785795
16057. the discovery during	the second world war that guar gum was similar to imported locust	gum increased its cultivation in western asia and initiated it in the	united states.	3.066076843508136
16058. water-soluble gums are used in foods and drugs	and in the manufacture of pulp and paper as thickeners stabilizers	or dispersing agents.	5.171625722703583
16059. guar gum thickens salad dressings and stabilizes	ice cream.	3.7607201937380976
16060. quince seed gum is the main ingredient in wave-setting	lotions.	6.054390605247889
16061. once regarded as an agricultural nuisance psyllium was sold	in the 1930's as a mechanical laxative under 117 different brands.	3.5858027748734176
16062. locust gum is added to pulp slurries to break up the lumps of fibers	in making paper.	5.4472271917936865
16063. the seeds of hard fibrous stony fruits	called nuts provide highly concentrated foods oils and other materials	of value.	3.0163563831944287
16064. most nuts consist of the richly packaged storage kernel	and its thick adherent brown covering- the seedcoat.	5.156893571827797
16065. the	kernels of brazil nuts cashews coconuts filberts hazelnuts hickory	nuts pecans walnuts and pine nuts are predominantly oily.	3.0871935491610603
16066. almonds	and pistachio nuts are not so high in oil but are rich in protein.	6.233050502763629
16067. all nut kernels are rich in protein.	5.0184961491750295
16068. the world production of familiar seed nuts- almonds brazil nuts	filberts and the english walnuts- totals about 300 thousand tons annually.	4.869100960860793
16069. coconuts the fruit of the coconut palm have the largest	of all known seeds and are grown in south pacific islands as a	crop for domestic and export markets.	3.1808144067763418
16070. the oil palm of west africa yields	edible oil from both the flesh and the seed or kernel of its fruit.	4.8294809453554715
16071. world production of copra the oil-bearing flesh of the coconut	was a little more than 3 million tons in 1959.	3.736386428771044
16072. exports from producing	countries in terms of equivalent oil were a little more than 1 million	tons about half of which was palm kernels or oil from them and about	half was palm oil.	5.586096902285764
16073. other nuts consumed in lesser quantity include	the spicy nutmeg; the soap nut which owes its sudsing power	to natural saponins; the marking nut used for ink and varnish; the	aromatic sassafras nut of south america; and the sweet-smelling	cumara nut which is suited for perfumes.	2.844251444911868
16074. a forest crop that has	not been extensively cultivated is ivory nuts from the tagua palm.	4.812288638400915
16075. the so-called vegetable ivory is the hard endosperm of the egg-sized	seed.	3.358254835772406
16076. it is used for making buttons and other small hard objects of	turnery.	6.3845690763913385

16460. this conclusion is dependent on the assumption that traditional sex mores	will continue to sanction both premarital chastity as the ideal	and the double standard holding females primarily responsible for	preserving the ideal.	4.5173325376387305
16461. our discussion of this involves using	erik erikson's schema of identity vs identity diffusion	as a conceptual tool in superimposing a few common denominators onto	the diverse personality and family configurations of the unwed mothers	from whose case histories we quoted earlier.	2.9671732271427547
16462. our discussion does not	utilize all the identity crises postulated by erikson but is intended	to demonstrate the utility of his theoretical schema for studying	unwed mothers.	4.908232565737355
16463. we hope thereby to emphasize that from a psychological	standpoint the effectual prevention of illegitimacy is a continuous	long-term process involving the socialization of the female from infancy	through adolescence.	3.493478611063657
16464. hypothesizing a series of developmental	stages that begin in the individual's infancy and end in his old	age erikson has indicated that the adolescent is faced with a series	of identity crises.	5.116864099800266
16465. the successful and positive resolution of these	crises during adolescence involves an epigenetic principle- during	adolescence the individual's positive resolutions in each area of identity	crisis depend to a considerable degree on his already having	resolved preliminary and preparatory identity crises during his infancy	childhood and early adolescence.	2.853080539850683
16466. within erikson's schema the	adolescent's delinquent behavior- in this case her unwed motherhood-	reflects her identity diffusion or her inability to resolve	these various identity crises positively.	5.027480946130255
16467. the adolescent	experiences identity crises in terms of time perspective vs time diffusion.	3.764953482249754
16468. time perspective- the ability to plan for the future and	to postpone gratifying immediate wants in order to achieve long-range	objectives- is more easily developed if from infancy on the individual	has been able to rely on and trust people and the world in which	she lives.	5.8585486429131794
16469. erikson has noted that unless this trust developed early	the time ambivalence experienced in varying degree and temporarily	by all adolescents	gratification of wants during childhood while not yet having fully	may develop	into a more permanent sense of time diffusion.	3.011742316293461
16470. experience of this time	diffusion ranges from a sense of utter apathy to a feeling of desperate	urgency to act immediately.	5.799950499278181
16471. these polar extremes in time	diffusion were indicated in some of the comments by unwed mothers reported	in earlier chapters.	3.8350670405036738
16472. some of these mothers apparently feeling a	desperate urgency made on the spur of the moment commitments in love	and sex that would have life-long consequences.	5.535690600944514
16473. others displayed	utter apathy and indifference to any decision about the past or the future.	3.9627928305242084
16474. for many of these unwed mothers the data on their family life	and early childhood experiences revealed several indications and sources	of their	basic mistrust of their parents in particular and of the world in	general.	5.620042528475065
16475. however as erickson has noted the individual's	failure to develop preliminary identities during infancy and childhood	need not be irreversibly deterministic with respect to a given area of	identity diffusion in his adolescence.	3.335666605375184
16476. and as shown in chapter	6 some snp females originally developed such trust only	during their adolescence through the aid of and their identification	with alter-parents.	5.3486993400948135
16477. in the specific case of time diffusion we	must emphasize the significance of the earlier development of mistrust	when it is combined with the inevitable time crisis experienced by	most adolescents in our society and with the failure of	the adolescent period to provide opportunities for developing trust.	3.50321462322102
16478. the adolescent experiences two closely related crises: self-certainty	vs an identity consciousness; and role-experimentation	vs negative identity.	4.568070230587944
16479. a sense of self-certainty and the freedom	to experiment with different roles or confidence in one's own unique	behavior as an alternative to peer-group conformity is more easily	developed during adolescence if during early childhood the individual	was permitted to exercise initiative and encouraged to develop some	autonomy.	3.037137213434863
16480. however if the child has been constantly surrounded	during nursery and early school age by peer groups; inculcated	with the primacy of group acceptance and group standards; and allowed	little initiative in early play and work patterns- then in adolescence	her normal degree of vanity sensitivity and preoccupation with	whether others find her appearance and behavior acceptable will be compounded.	4.293048175007103
16481. her ostensible indifference to and rebellion against suggestions	and criticisms by anyone except peer friends during adolescence	are the manifestations in her adolescence of her having been indoctrinated	in childhood to feel shame if not guilt for failing to behave	in a manner acceptable to and judged by the performance of her nursery-	and elementary-school peer friends.	3.0148273763930646
16482. to be different is to invite	shame and doubt; and it is better to be shamed and criticized by one's	parents who already consider one different and difficult to understand	than by one's peers who are also experiencing a similar groping	for and denial of adult status.	4.842079404217424
16483. the attitudes of some unwed	mothers quoted in chapter 2 revealed both considerable preoccupation	with being accepted by others and a marked absence of self-certainty.	3.170228059726984
16484. many appeared to regard their sexual behavior as a justifiable	means of gaining acceptance from and identification with others; but	very few seemed aware that such acceptance and identification need	to be supplemented with more enduring and stable identification of and	with one's self.	4.568061767619136
16485. another identity crisis confronting the	adolescent involves anticipation of achievement vs work-paralysis.	4.038178542916547
16486. the adolescent's capacity to anticipate achievement and to exercise	the self-discipline necessary to complete tasks successfully depends	on the degree to which he or she developed autonomy initiative and	self-discipline during childhood.	4.803220713079487
16487. the developmental process involves	the individual's progressively experiencing a sense of dignity and achievement	resulting from having completed tasks having kept commitments	and having created something	dress of one's own design rather than in the design it ought	.	3.1647960671313227
16488. these childhood experiences are sources of the self-certainty	that the adolescent needs for experimenting with many roles and	for the freedom to fail sometimes in the process of exploring and	discovering her skills and abilities.	5.32397134018062
16489. if she has not had such	experiences the female's normal adolescent degree of indecision will	be compounded.	3.936430090383749
16490. she may well be incapacitated by it when she is confronted	with present and future alternatives- eg whether to prepare	primarily for a career or for the role of a homemaker; whether	to stay financially dependent on her parents or help support herself	while attending school; whether to pursue a college education or a	job after high school; and whether to attend this or that college and	to follow this or that course of study.	4.708241114310284
16491. erikson has noted that as	this indecision mounts it may result in a paralysis of workmanship.	3.7783584940427155
16492. this paralysis may be expressed in the female's starting- and	never completing- many jobs tasks and courses of study; and in	the fact that she bases her decisions about work college carreer and	studies on what others are doing rather than on her own sense of identity	with given skills abilities likes and dislikes.	4.481474113767717
16493. the absence	during her childhood and early adolescence of experiences in developing	the self-discipline to complete tasks within her ability- experiences	that would have been subsequent sources of anticipation of achievement-	and her lack of childhood opportunities to practice autonomy	and initiative in play and expression both tend in her adolescence	to deprive her of the freedoms to role-experiment and to fail occasionally	in experimenting.	2.8413160161174975
16494. the comments made by some unwed mothers	reflect this paralysis of workmanship.	5.172896016431143
16495. they	attended school and selected courses primarily on the basis of decisions	others made; they accepted a job primarily because it was available	convenient and paid reasonably.	3.5252467909281235

16497. as their identity diffusion increased they became more	susceptible to sporadic diversions in love and sexual affairs.	3.63536376514575
16498. these	affairs temporarily relieved the monotony of school or work activities	containing no anticipation of achievement and joy of craftsmanship	no sense of dignity derived from a job well done.	5.156821350409037
16499. childhood	experiences in learning work and self-discipline habits within a context	of developing autonomy and initiative have considerable significance	for the prevention of illegitimacy.	3.454962968134259
16500. the excerpts from case histories	presented above confirm this significance though through different	facets of experience.	4.471463326555969
16501. for example some unwed mothers had had no work	experiences household chores and responsibilities during childhood	and early adolescence; they subsequently occupied their leisure hours	in searching for something exciting and diverting.	3.236486103288527
16502. on	the other hand some unwed mothers had had so much work and responsibility	imposed on them at an early age and had thus had so little freedom	or opportunity to develop autonomy and initiative that their work	and responsibilities became dull and unrewarding burdens- to be escaped	and rebelled against through fun and experimentation with forbidden	sexual behavior.	4.663951216890161
16503. the adolescent also faces the identity	crisis that erikson has termed ideological polarization vs diffusion	of ideals.	3.15540604288166

16505. adolescents have a much-discussed	tendency to polarize ideas and values to perceive things as	either-or black or white- nuances of meaning are relatively	unimportant.	3.1798949730716517
16506. this tendency is perhaps most clearly revealed in the	literature on religious conversions and experiences of adolescents.	5.117586985914995
16507. erikson	has postulated that such ideological polarization temporarily	resolves their search for something stable and definite in the rapidly	changing and fluctuating no-man's-land between childhood and adulthood.	3.1410381935783933
16508. it provides identification- with an idea a value a cause that	cuts through or even transcends the multiple and ambivalent identities	of their passage from child to adult and permits their forceful	and overt expression of emotion.	4.659199268665206
16509. the positive development during	adolescence of this capacity to think and to feel strongly and with	increasing independence and to identify overtly either with or against	given ideas values and practices depends to a considerable degree	on both previous and present opportunities for developing autonomy	initiative and self-certainty.	3.0381706478906927
16510. most adolescents have some ideological	diffusion at various developmental stages as they experience a proliferation	of ideas and values.	5.524345192796912
16511. the diffusion is most pronounced and	most likely to become fixed however in those who have had no or very	minimal opportunities to develop the autonomy and initiative that could	have been directed into constructive expression and so served as sources	of developing self-certainty.	3.330710791767683
16512. a pronounced ideological	diffusion- ie inability to identify independently with given	ideas and value systems- is reflected in many ways.	4.899804395904138
16513. for example	it is evinced by the adolescent whose beliefs and actions	represent primarily his rebellion and reaction again the ideas and behavior	patterns of others rather than his inner conviction and choice.	3.173187051332121

16516. the case histories provide some interesting illustrations of ideological	diffusion embodied in the unwed mother's inability to identify	independently with a given value system or behavior pattern and	her subsequent disinclination to assume any individual responsibility	for her sexual behavior.	4.379131806793119

16526. the duration and other circumstances	of the selden case made it a flagrant example of the gross abuses of	patent infringement actions.	5.22348428909712
16527. the suit as we have seen came before	the courts when patent attorneys inventors and laymen were making mounting	demands for reforms in the american patent system.	3.2984994652192765
16528. chief among	the defects they singled out were the complicated and wearisome procedures	in equity.	5.385245736842853
16529. in a long and angry footnote to his opinion	judge hough had lent the weight of judicial condemnation to such criticism.	3.86917103364231

16531. as long as the bar prefers to adduce evidence by written deposition	rather than viva voce before an authoritative judicial officer	i fear that the antiquated rules will remain unchanged and expensive	prolixity remain the best known characteristic of equity.	3.258279397868236

16533. he cited the elephantine dimensions of the selden case	record; the duplication of testimony and exhibits; the numerous	squabbles over minor matters; the objections stated at outrageous	length; and the frequent and rancorous verbal bouts uncalled	for and	unjustifiable from the retort discourteous to the lie direct.	2.9268850803060924
16534. the fundamental difficulty of which the selden case was	a striking example concluded hough will	remain as long as testimony is taken without any authoritative judicial	officer present and responsible for the maintenance of discipline	and the reception or exclusion of testimony.	4.931115298868617

16536. william a	redding asserted that if the case had been heard in open court under	rules of evidence the testimony would have been completed in sixty	days instead of five years.	5.93606653477725

16561. even	before it was formally dissolved in 1912 the alam	was succeeded by the automobile board of trade the direct lineal	ancestor of the present-day automobile manufacturers association.	3.294930902877064

16566. from	the earliest days of the motor car industry before the alam	was established patent infringement loomed as a serious and	vexing problem.	5.581668887883709
