16786. thus such great american documentaries	as the river and the plow that broke the plains	were composed as visual stories rather than as illustrated lectures.	5.1627150013379
16787. the discovery that movies are a form of fiction was made in the early	years of this century and it was made chiefly by two men a french	magician georges melies and an american employee of edison edwin	s porter.	3.6247600356683494
16788. of the two porter is justly the better known for	he went far beyond the vital finding of fiction for films to take the	first step toward fashioning a language of film toward making the motion	picture the intricate efficient time machine that it has remained	since even in the most inept hands.	5.243262995839179
16789. melies however out of his professional instincts as a magician	discovered and made use of a number of illusionary techniques that remain	part of the vocabulary of film.	3.6988061899141074
16790. one of these is the dissolve	which makes possible a visually smooth transition from scene to scene.	6.029373877814694
16791. as the first scene begins to fade the succeeding scene begins	to appear.	4.339304977463066
16792. for a moment or two both scenes are present simultaneously	one growing weaker one growing stronger.	5.885494979193243
16793. in a series of fairy tales	and fantasies melies demonstrated that the film is superbly equipped	to tell a straightforward story with beginning middle and end complications	resolutions climaxes and conclusions.	3.394207345340816
16794. immediately the	film improved and it improved because in narrative it found a content	based on time to complement its own unbreakable connection with time.	5.034113540397289
16795. physically a movie is possible because a series of images is projected	one at a time at such a speed that the eye remembers the one	that has gone before even as it registers the one now appearing.	3.5550578585983272
16796. linking	the smoothly changing images together the eye itself endows them	with the illusion of movement.	5.159740533763365
16797. the projection time of painting	and sculpture is highly subjective varying from person to person and	even varying for a given person on different occasions.	3.2230697870414153
16798. so is the time	of the novel.	8.510561828755387
16799. the drama in the theater and the concert in the hall	both have a fixed time but the time is fixed by the director and the	players the conductor and the instrumentalists subject therefore	to much variation as record collectors well know.	3.2288969895828603
16800. the time of the motion	picture is fixed absolutely.	6.9279341737278965
16801. the film consists of a series of still	transparent photographs or frames 35-mm-wide.	3.815868852478173
16802. each frame	comes between the light and the lens and is individually projected	on the screen at the rate for silent movies of 16 frames per second	and for sound films 24 frames per second.	5.0832110538960045
16803. this is the rate of projection;	it is also the rate of photographing.	5.30458425452656
16804. time is built into	the motion picture which cannot exist without time.	6.339202564788142
16805. now time is also	the concern of the fictional narrative which is at its simplest	the story of an action with usually a beginning a middle and an end-	elements which demand time as the first condition for their existence.	3.561494628258594
16806. the moving picture of the train or the wave coming at the	audience is to be sure more intense than a still picture of the same	subject but the difference is really one of degree; the cinematic	element of time is merely used to increase the realism of an object which	would still be reasonably realistic in a still photo.	4.9428333807448555
16807. in narrative	time is essential as it is in film.	5.4120016671960745
16808. almost everything about the	movies that is peculiarly of the movies derives from a tension created	and maintained between narrative time and film time.	5.0845038506965095
16809. this discovery	of melies was vastly more important than his sometimes dazzling	magician's tricks produced on film.	3.601281553623482
16810. it was porter however	who produced the very first movie whose name has lived on through the	half century of film history that has since ensued.	5.102450338298521
16811. the movie was the	great train robbery and its effects on the young industry and	art were all but incalculable.	3.437049094190217
16812. overnight for one thing porter's	film multiplied the standard running time of movies by ten.	6.0047318513969765
16813. the	great train robbery is a one-reel film.	4.809866251337277
16814. one reel- from eight to	twelve minutes- became the standard length from the year of robbery	1903 until griffith shattered that limit forever with birth of	a nation in 1915.	4.731770809497988
16815. the reel itself became and still is the standard	of measure for the movies.	3.426776813993932
16816. the material of the porter film	is simplicity itself; much of it has continued to be used over the	years and the heart of it- good guys and bad guys in the old west-	pretty well dominated television toward the end of the 1950's.	5.452555255399199
16817. a	band of robbers enters a railroad station overpowers and ties up the	telegraph operator holds up the train and escapes.	3.3181383173846672
16818. a posse is formed	and pursues the robbers who having made their escape are whooping	it up with some wild wild women in a honky-tonk hide-out.	4.602522245175523
16819. the robbers	run from the hide-out take cover in a wooded declivity and are shot	dead by the posse.	3.106502593441713
16820. as a finale is appended a close-up of one of the	band taking aim and firing his revolver straight at the audience.	5.658899826992854
16821. all this is simple enough but in telling the story porter did	two important things that had not been done before.	4.2866154100786265
16822. each scene is shot	straight through as had been the universal custom from a camera fixed	in a single position but in the outdoor scenes especially in the	capture and destruction of the outlaws porter's camera position	breaks necessarily with the camera position standard until then which	had been roughly that of a spectator in a center orchestra seat at	a play.	4.863736356660671
16823. the plane of the action in the scene is not parallel with the	plane of the film in the camera or on the screen.	4.200535681561159
16824. if the change at	first sight seems minor we may recall that it took the italian painters	about two hundred years to make an analogous change and the italian	painters by universal consent were the most brilliant group of	geniuses any art has seen.	4.95781996966401
16825. in that apparently simple shift porter	opened the way to the sensitive use of the camera as an instrument of	art as well as a mechanical recording device.	4.48914063828991
16826. he did more than	that.	9.723790422156965
16827. he revealed the potential value of the cut as the basic	technique in the art of the film.	4.322242451283134
16828. cutting of course takes place automatically	in the creation of a film.	6.150171331158075
16829. the meaning of the word is quite	physical to begin with.	4.508165468282879
16830. the physical film is cut with a knife at the	end of one complete sequence and the cut edge is joined physically	by cement to the cut edge of the beginning of the next sequence.	5.353067043153037
16831. if	as a home movie maker you shoot the inevitable footage of your child	taking its first steps you have merely recorded an historical event.	3.1840767528742027
16832. if in preparing that shot for the inevitable showing to your friends	you interrupt the sequence to paste in a few frames of the child's	grandmother watching this event you have begun to be an artist in	film; you are employing the basic technique of film; you are cutting.	5.001412935738304
16833. this is what porter did.	6.367350921754556
16834. as the robbers leave the looted	train the film suddenly cuts back to the station where the telegrapher's	little daughter arrives with her father's dinner pail only	to find him bound on the floor.	5.021847105423565
16835. she dashes around in alarm.	5.215488607030812
16836. the two	events are taking place at the same time.	6.806930521138561
16837. time and space have both become	cinematic.	5.611448176857455
16838. we leap from event to event- including the formation	of the posse- even though the events in reality are taking	place not in sequence but simultaneously and not near each other but	at a considerable distance.	4.840491133619685
16839. the chase as a standard film	device probably dates from the great train robbery and there	is a reason for the continued popularity of the device.	3.5205908051873513
16840. the chase in	itself is a narrative; it presumes both speed and urgency and it demands	cutting- both from pursued to pursuer and from stage to stage	of the journey of both.	4.269981017788626
16841. the simple naked idea of one man chasing another	is of its nature better fitted for the film than it is for any other	form of fiction.	3.691421205582873
16842. the cowboy films the cops and robbers films and	the slapstick comedy films culminating in an insane chase are not	only catering to what critics may assume to be a vulgar taste for violence;	these films and these sequences are also seeking out- instinctively	or by design- the peculiarly cinematic elements of narrative.	4.250182939941654
16843. there	still remained the need for one great film artist to explore the full	potential of the new form and to make it an art.	4.551357934208036
16844. the man was dw	griffith.	8.143747309958542
16845. when he came to the movies- more or less by accident-	they were still cheap entertainment capable of enthralling the unthinking	for an idle few minutes.	3.7701580376643764
16846. in about seven years griffith either	invented or first realized the possibilities of virtually every resource	at the disposal of the film maker.	5.237778247354649
16847. before he was forty griffith	had created the art of the film.	4.9081720569203835
16848. not that there had not been	attempts mostly european to do exactly that.	6.805158849030802
16849. but in general the european	efforts to make an art of the entertainment had ignored the slowly	emerging language of the film itself.	4.517915150352603
16850. staggeringly condensed versions	of famous novels and famous plays were presented.	5.235221313790219
16851. great actors	and actresses- the most notable being sarah bernhardt- were hired	to repeat their stage performances before the camera.	3.314090966246622
16852. in all of this	extensive and expensive effort the camera was downgraded to the status	of recording instrument for art work produced elsewhere by the actor	or by the author.	5.180911582054445
16853. the phonograph today for all its high fidelity	and stereophonic sound is precisely what the early art purveyors in	the movies wished to make of the camera.	3.264649503134381
16854. not surprisingly this approach	did not work.	7.659046401134299
16855. the effort produced a valuable record of stage techniques	in the early years of the century and some interesting records	of great theater figures who would otherwise be only names.	3.3858758913147953
16856. but no art	at all was born of the art effort in the early movies.	7.640525736229979
16857. in general religious interest seems to exist in all parts of the metropolis;	congregational membership however is another thing.	4.192607318420068
16858. a congregation	survives only if it can sustain a socially homogeneous membership;	that is when it can preserve economic integration.	5.19277232363206
16859. religious	faith can be considered a necessary condition of membership in	a congregation since the decision to join a worshiping group requires	some motive force but faith is not a sufficient condition for joining;	the presence of other members of similar social and economic	level is the sufficient condition.	3.3853508948627455
16860. the breakdown of social	homogeneity in inner city areas and the spread of inner city blight account	for the decline of central city churches.	4.883603313949002
16861. central cities reveal	two adverse features for the major denominations: central cities	tend to be areas of residence for lower social classes; central	cities tend to be more heterogeneous in social composition.	3.3681076555445197
16862. the central	city areas in other words exhibit the two characteristics which	violate the life principle of congregations of the major denominations:	they have too few middle-class people; they mix middle-class people	with lower-class residents.	4.657887359978665
16863. central city areas have become progressively	poorer locales for the major denominations since the exodus	of middle-class people from most central cities.	3.6092579853938114
16864. with few exceptions	the major denominations are rapidly losing their hold on the central	city.	6.083483052642206
16865. the key to protestant development therefore is economic	integration of the nucleus of the congregation.	3.6922116039701174
16866. members of higher	and lower social status often cluster around this nucleus so that protestant	figures on social class give the impression of spread over all	social classes; but this is deceptive for the core of membership	is	concentrated in a single social and economic stratum.	5.245947626868565
16867. the congregation	perishes when it is no longer possible to replenish that core from the	neighborhood; moreover residential mobility is so high in metropolitan	areas that churches have to recruit constantly in their core stratum	in order to survive; they can lose higher- and lower-status members	from the church without collapsing but they need adequate recruits	for the core stratum in order to preserve economic integration.	3.1077392065022593
16868. the	congregation is first and foremost an economic peer group; it is	secondarily a believing and worshiping fellowship.	5.002690488845615
16869. if it were primarily	a believing fellowship it would recruit believers from all social	and economic ranks something which most congregations of the new protestantism	have not been able to do.	3.986340710607997
16870. they survive only when they can recruit social and economic peers.	7.190449566878833
16871. the vulnerability of protestant congregations to social differences	has often been attributed to the folksy spirit of protestant	religious life; in fact a contrast is often drawn in this regard	with the impersonal roman catholic parish.	3.212610369026049
16872. we have seen that	the folksy spirit is confined to economic peers; consequently the	vulnerability to social difference should not be attributed to the stress	on personal community in protestant congregations; actually there	is little evidence of such personal community in protestant congregations	as we shall see in another connection.	4.961975071162928
16873. the vulnerability of	protestantism to social differences stems from the peculiar role of	the new religious style in middle-class life where the congregation is	a vehicle of social and economic group identity and must conform therefore	to the principle of economic integration.	3.324002333752603
16874. this fact is evident	in the recruitment of new members.	5.994254510250427
16875. the	rule of economic integration in congregational life can be seen in the	missionary outreach of the major denominations.	4.449241787277296
16876. there is much talk	in theological circles about the church as mission and the church's	mission; theologians have been stressing the fact that	the church does not exist for its own sake but as a testimony in	the world for the healing of the world.	5.3709803003096335
16877. a crucial question therefore	is what evangelism and mission actually mean in metropolitan protestantism.	3.4959374394254192
16878. if economic integration really shapes congregational life then	evangelism should be a process of extending economic integration.	6.285200608917529
16879. the task of a congregation would be defined according to economic integration	as the work of co-opting individuals and families of similar	social and economic position to replenish the nuclear core of the congregation.	3.3331485836324752
16880. fill a vacancy; it can also mean the assimilation of centers of power	in a	mobile society congregational health depends on a constant process of	recruitment; this recruitment however must follow the pattern of	economic integration or it will disrupt the congregation; therefore	the recruitment or missionary outreach of the congregation will be co-optation	rather than proclamation- like elements will have to be assimilated.	4.698140747335367
16881. evangelism and congregational outreach have not been	carefully studied in the churches; one study in pittsburgh however	has illuminated the situation.	3.250895873909493
16882. in a sample of new members of pittsburgh	churches almost 60 per cent were recruited by initial contacts	with friendly members.	6.1189431865251676
16883. if we add to these contacts with friendly	members the contacts with an organization of the church	then a substantial two thirds of all recruitment	is through friendly contact.	3.8539339356175666
16884. on the surface this seems a sound	approach to christian mission: members of the congregation show by	their friendly attitudes that they care for new people; the new people	respond in kind by joining the church.	5.3255051593312785
16885. missionary outreach	by friendly contact looks somewhat different when one reflects on what	is known about friendly contact in metropolitan neighborhoods; the majority	of such contacts are with people of similar social and economic	position; association by level of achievement is the dominant principle	of informal relations.	3.056019701858924
16886. this means that the antennae of the congregation	are extended into the community picking up the wave lengths	of those who will fit into the social and economic level of the congregation;	the mission of the church is actually a process of informal	co-optation; the lay ministry is a means to recruit like-minded people	who will strengthen the social class nucleus of the congregation.	5.217372872702776
16887. churches can be strengthened through this process of co-optation so long	as the environs of the church provide a sufficient pool of people	who can fit the pattern of economic integration; once the pool of recruits	diminishes the congregation is helpless- friendly contacts no	longer keep it going.	3.308394693135786
16888. the transmutation of mission to co-optation	is further indicated by the insignificance of educational activities	worship preaching and publicity in reaching new members.	4.500781118117243
16889. the	proclamation of the churches is almost totally confined to pastoral contacts	by the clergy and friendly contacts	by members.	3.431970680302389
16890. 1 per cent of the initial contacts with	new members.	8.999289676026072
16891. in general friendly contact with a member followed by	contact with a clergyman will account for a major share of recruitment	by the churches making it quite evident that the extension of economic	integration through co-optation is the principal form of mission	in the contemporary church; economic integration and co-optation are	the two methods by which protestants associate with and recruit from	the neighborhood.	3.1072590375573945
16892. the inner life of congregations will prosper so long	as like-minded people of similar social and economic level can fraternize	together; the outer life of congregations- the suitability	of the environment to their survival- will be propitious so long as	the people in the area are of the same social and economic level as the	membership.	5.087735936906241
16893. economic integration ceases when the social and economic	statuses in an area become too mixed or conflict with the status of	the congregation.	3.7960587790480638
16894. in a rapidly changing society congregations will run	into difficulties repeatedly since such nice balances of economic integration	are hard to sustain in the metropolis for more than a single	generation.	5.411918331926779
16895. the fact that metropolitan churches of the major denominations	have moved approximately every generation for the last hundred	years becomes somewhat more intelligible in the light of this struggle	to maintain economic balance.	3.7000734776758906
16896. the expense of this type of organization	in religious life when one recalls the number of city churches which	deteriorated beyond repair before being abandoned raises fundamental	questions about the principle of protestant survival in a mobile	society; nonetheless the prevalence of economic integration in congregations	illumines the nature of the protestant development.	5.276825233686755
16897. it was observed in the introductory chapter that metropolitan life had	split into two trends- expanding interdependence on an impersonal	basis and growing exclusiveness in local communal groupings.	3.2150370411638596
16898. these trends	seem to be working at cross-purposes in the metropolis.	6.027172341041511
16899. residential	associations struggle to insulate themselves against intrusions.	4.206559903055832
16900. the motifs of impersonal interdependence and insulation of residential	communities have polarized; the schism between central city and suburb	negro and white blue collar and white collar can be viewed as	symptomatic of this deeper polarization of trends in the metropolis.	4.189170111665473
16901. it now becomes evident that the denominational church is intimately involved	with the economy of middle-class culture for it serves to crystallize	the social class identity of middle-class residential groupings.	3.51059128051183
16902. the accelerated pace of metropolitan changes has accentuated the	drive to conformity in congregations of the major denominations.	4.931640737586788
16903. this	conformity represents a desperate attempt to stabilize a hopelessly unstable	environment.	3.761311135318761
16904. more than creatures of metropolitan forces the	churches have taken the lead in counteracting the interdependence of metropolitan	life crystallizing and perpetuating the stratification of	peoples giving form to the struggle for social homogeneity in a world	of heterogeneous peoples.	4.742268099015346
16905. since american life is committed	above all to productivity and a higher standard of economic life the	countervailing forces of residential and religious exclusiveness have	fought a desperate rearguard action against the expanding interdependence	of the metropolis.	3.1908712259895498
16906. consumer communities have suffered at the hands	of the productive interests.	5.8557294993181745
16907. negroes puerto ricans and rural	newcomers are slowly making their way into the cities.	3.967205735087213
16908. soon they will	fight their way into the lower middle-class suburbs and the churches	will experience the same decay and rebuilding cycle which has characterized	their history for a century.	5.05929216948372
16909. the identification of the basic unit	of religious organization- the parish or congregation- with a	residential area is self-defeating in a modern metropolis for it simply	means the closing of an iron trap on the outreach of the christian	fellowship and the transmutation of mission to co-optation.	3.059273668575321
16910. mission	to the metropolis contradicts survival of the congregation in the residential	community because the middle classes are fighting metropolitan	interdependence with residential exclusion.	5.560092264438595
16911. this interpretation	of the role of residence in the economy of middle-class culture could	lead to various projections for the churches.	3.754832727787823
16912. it could be argued	that any fellowship which centers in residential neighborhoods is doomed	to become an expression of the panic for stable identity among the	middle classes.	5.440132921250145
16913. it could be argued that only such neighborhoods can sustain	religious activity since worship presupposes some local stabilities.	3.8998262652767495
16914. whatever projection one makes the striking fact about congregational	and parochial life is the extent to which it is a vehicle of the	social identity of middle-class people.	5.7845790864054445
16915. attention will be given	in the next chapter to the style of association in the denominational	churches; this style is characteristically an expression of the	communal style of the middle classes.	3.70723142938601
16916. the keynotes of this style are	activism and emphasis on achievements in gaining self-esteem.	4.7733683371620135
16917. these	values give direction to the life of the middle-class man or woman dictating	the methods of child rearing determining the pattern of community	participation setting the style for the psychiatric treatment of	middle-class illness and informing the congregational life of the major	denominations.	3.4026892598588376
16918. fellowship by likeness and mission by friendly	contact form the iron cage of denominational religion.	5.318324844237667
16919. its contents	are another matter for they reveal the kinds of interests pursued	by the congregation.	3.7223227058915485
16920. what goes on in the cage will occupy our attention	under the rubric of the organization church.	6.053585379383574
16921. an understanding	of the new role of residential association in an industrial society	serves to illuminate the forces which have fashioned the iron cage of	conformity which imprisons the churches in their suburban captivity.	3.36999977408315
16922. the perplexing question still remains as to why the middle classes	turn to the churches as a vehicle of social identity when their clubs	and charities should fill the same need.	4.937769860512282
16923. with capital largely squandered there seemed to them no other course	to pursue.	4.277471562758071
16924. the directors sold directly to concessionaires who	had to make their profits above the high prices asked by the company.	4.977946012262688
16925. these concessionaires traded where they wished and generally dealt	with the indians through engages who might be habitants voyageurs	or even soldiers.	3.3476637950452517
16926. the concessionaires also had to pay a tax of	one-tenth on the goods they traded and all pelts were to be taken to	company stores and shipped to france in company ships.	4.968083001849151
16927. the company	disposed of the pelts but with what profit the records do not show.	3.35413356369227
16928. in accord with its penurious policy the company failed to furnish	presents to hold the loyalty of the principal indians.	5.928857486813164
16929. the lavish	use of presents had been effective in expanding the indian trade	of new france and louisiana in the previous century and the change	in liberality aroused resentment in the minds of the red men.	3.257416654192512
16930. traders	from the english colonies were far more generous and indian loyalty	turned to them.	5.333138857328708
16931. protests from governors and intendants passed unheeded	and the parsimonious policy of the company probably let loose indian	insurrections that brought ruin to the company.	3.3367923866464344
16932. in 1721	the king sent three commissioners to louisiana with full powers to do	all that was necessary to protect the colony.	5.381323389306974
16933. they ordered the raising	of troops and obtained 75000 livres with which to build forts.	4.097633877764872
16934. they	adopted a program by which louisiana was divided into five districts.	5.753345907002701
16935. in each of these there was to be a strong military post and a trading	depot to supply the smaller trading houses.	4.69124889949019
16936. for southeastern	louisiana	mobile was the principal post and it was to furnish supplies	for trade to the north and east in the region threatened by british	traders.	6.617582467523564
16937. mobile was to be the anchor of a chain of posts extending	northward to the sources of the tennessee river.	4.451297267363611
16938. fort toulouse	on the alabama river had been erected in 1714 for trade with the alabamas	and choctaws but money was available for only one other new	post near the present nashville tennessee and this was soon abandoned.	4.785765605925853
16939. west of the mobile district was the lower mississippi	district of which new orleans was headquarters.	4.708266535367216
16940. dependent upon it	were posts on the lower mississippi and the region westward to the frontiers	of new spain.	5.359027204640037
16941. on the middle mississippi a principal	post was to be located near the mouth of the arkansas.	4.5219276550400735
16942. it was hoped	that to this post would flow a large quantity of furs from the west	principally down the arkansas river.	5.22811866285287
16943. on the ohio or wabash was to	be built another post at the fork of two great rivers.	3.763812085894518
16944. other	posts would be established up the ohio and wabash to protect communication	with canada.	5.72666227315342
16945. on the upper mississippi the illinois post was	to be established near kaskaskia and dependent posts were to be built	on the missouri where there are mines in abundance.	3.68638623713595
16946. each of the five principal posts was to have a director responsible	to a director-general at new orleans.	6.8090817683408495
16947. an elaborate system of accounting	and reports was worked out and the trade was to be managed in the	most scientific way.	4.133811696231232
16948. concessionaires were to be under the supervision	of the directors.	7.234257976273037

16950. the habitants were to be encouraged to trade and were to dispose	of their pelts to the concessionaires.	5.661369031744312
16951. only two principal storehouses	were actually established- one at mobile the other at new	orleans.	4.094480707492453
16952. new orleans supplied the goods for the trade on the mississippi	and west of that river and on the ohio and wabash.	6.643039518295273

16954. the power that bienville exercised during his first administration	cannot be determined.	5.421001307394899
16955. regulations for the indian trade were	made by the conseil superieure de la louisiane and bienville	apparently did not have control of that body.	3.6057830227172687
16956. the conseil even	treated the serious matter of british aggression as its business and	on its own authority sent to disaffected savages merchandise suitable	for the peltry trade.	4.285273748823909
16957. it decided also that the purely secular	efforts of bienville were insufficient and sent missionaries to	win the savages from the heathen carolinians.	3.4672108798643686
16958. during the first	administration of bienville the peltry trade of the mobile district	was a lucrative source of revenue.	5.7451149703762425
16959. the alabamas brought in annually	15000 to 20000 deerskins and the choctaws and chickasaws brought	the total up to 50000 pelts.	2.97808387616078
16960. these deerskins were the raw material	for the manufacture of leather and were the only articles which the	tribes of this district had to exchange for european goods.	5.260946121660153
16961. during his first administration bienville succeeded in keeping carolina	traders out of the alabama country and the choctaw country.	4.3870824871523855
16962. the	director of the post at mobile kept an adequate amount of french	goods of a kind to which they were accustomed to supply the indian	needs.	5.985849999957172
16963. the alabama and tombigbee rivers furnished a highway by which	goods could be moved quickly and cheaply.	3.115993761768256
16964. de la laude commander	of the alabama post had the friendship of the natives and was able	to make them look upon the british as poor competitors.	4.988800087330404
16965. diron d'artaguette	the most prominent trader in the district was energetic and	resourceful but his methods often aroused the ire of the french governors.	3.376963349199848
16966. he became after a time commander of a post on the alabama	river but his operations extended from mobile throughout the district	and he finally obtained a monopoly of the indian trade.	5.010149978120672
16967. the	chickasaws were the principal source of trouble in the mobile district.	4.0546858686065015
16968. their territory lay to the north near the sources of the alabama	the tombigbee the tennessee and cumberland rivers and was	easily accessible to traders among the near-by cherokees.	5.197249884433383
16969. in 1720 some	chickasaws massacred the french traders among them and did not	make peace for four years.	3.5735072615577796
16970. venturesome traders however continued to	come to them from mobile and to obtain a considerable number of pelts	for the french markets.	5.415504098379313
16971. british traders from south carolina incited	the indians against the french and there developed french and	british factions in the tribe.	3.570229702583179
16972. the chickasaws finally were the occasion	for the most disastrous wars during the french control of louisiana.	4.767718167552581
16973. to hold them was an essential part of french policy for they	controlled the upper termini of the routes from the north to mobile.	3.8519444826576237
16974. they threatened constantly to give the british a hold on this region	from whence they could move easily down the rivers to the french	settlements near the gulf.	5.076119907625149
16975. bienville realized that if the french	were to hold the southeastern tribes against the enticements of british	goods french traders must be able to offer a supply as abundant	as the carolinians and at reasonable prices.	3.552650194346549
16976. his urgings brought	some results.	7.487674195966194
16977. the company of the indies promised to send over a supply	of indian trading goods and to price them more cheaply in terms	of deerskins.	3.466439609814012
16978. but it coupled with this a requirement that indians	must bring their pelts to mobile and thus save all costs of transportation	into and out of the indian country.	6.003537090256503
16979. the insistence of bienville	upon giving liberal prices to the indians in order to drive	back the carolina traders was probably a factor that led to his recall	in 1724.	3.5667074169238036

16982. the company was impressed with some ideas of the danger from carolina	and when perier came over as governor in 1727 he was given special	instructions regarding the trade of the mobile district.	5.121173240511598
16983. but the	company of the indies holding to its program of economy made no arrangements	to furnish better goods at attractive prices.	3.5100441545844694
16984. to the directors	the problem appeared a matter of intrigue or diplomacy.	6.975843290991986

16986. these agents were to ascertain the difference between	english and french goods and the prices charged the indians.	5.40205827021927

16989. perier's intrigues gained some successes.	4.487010299911092

17324. probably	a larger percentage of virginians and south carolinians remain	unreconstructed than elsewhere with georgia north carolina and	alabama following along after them.	4.676921276527998
17325. old attitudes are held more tenaciously	in the tidewater than the piedmont; so that a line running	down the length of the south marking the upper limits of tidewater	would roughly divide the old south from the new but with of course	important minority enclaves.	3.480120998500898
17326. the long-settled areas of states	like virginia and south carolina developed the ante-bellum culture	to its richest flowering and there the memory is more precious and	the consciousness of loss the greater.	4.378442678165925
17327. also we should not even to-day	discount the fact that a region such as the coastal lowlands centering	on charleston had closer ties with england and the west indies	than with the north even after independence.	3.816074876251023
17328. the social and psychological	consequences of this continue to affect the area.	5.870944998847486
17329. in certain	respects defeat increased the persistent anglophilia of the old south.	4.336587881299557
17330. poor where they had once been rich humbled where they had been	arrogant having no longer any hope of sharing in the leadership of the	nation the rebels who would not surrender in spirit drew comfort from	the sympathy they felt extended to them by the mother country.	5.211723399215968
17331. and	no doubt many people in states like the carolinas and georgia which	were among the most tory in sentiment in the eighteenth century bitterly	regretted the revolt against the crown.	3.384077441450227
17332. among bourbons	the racial issue may have less to do with their remaining unreconstructed	than other factors.	6.405278596562045
17333. all southerners agree that slavery had to	go; but many historians maintain that except for northern meddling	it would have ended in states like virginia years before it did.	3.3306318066703207
17334. southern	resentment has been over the method of its ending the invasion	and reconstruction; their fears now are of miscegenation and negro	political control in many counties.	4.953156548556693
17335. but apart from racial problems	the old unreconstructed south- to use the moderate words favored by	mr thomas griffith- finds itself unsympathetic to most of what	is different about the civilization of the north.	3.2082316276556186
17336. and this in effect	means most of modern america.	7.480163790043658
17337. it is hard to see how the	situation could be otherwise.	5.139112117283126
17338. and therein i feel many northerners	delude themselves about the south.	5.977922130951302
17339. for one thing this is not a subject	often discussed or analyzed.	5.209608117295727
17340. there seems to be almost a conspiracy	of silence veiling it.	7.292734965780781
17341. i suppose the reason is a kind of wishful	thinking: don't talk about the final stages of reconstruction and	they will take care of themselves.	4.040090651344333
17342. or else the north really believes	that all southerners except a few quaint old characters have come	around to realizing the errors of their past and are now at heart sharers	of the american dream like everybody else.	5.074229583321682
17343. if the circumstances	are faced frankly it is not reasonable to expect this to be	true.	4.4886027481864
17344. the situation of the south since 1865 has been unique in the western	world.	6.643285073163195
17345. regardless of rights and wrongs a population and an area	appropriate to a pre-world-war-1 great power have been following	conquest	ruled against their will by a neighboring people and have had	imposed upon them social and economic controls they dislike.	3.29032728327201
17346. and the	great majority of these people are of anglo-saxon or celtic descent.	6.13128963925171
17347. this is the only case in modern history of a people of britannic	origin submitting without continued struggle to what they view as foreign	domination.	3.9685517867745044
17348. the fact is due mainly to international wars both hot	and cold.	5.665093439678942
17349. in every war of the united states since the civil war	the south was more belligerent than the rest of the country.	4.804147944035572
17350. so instead	of being tests of the south's loyalty the spanish war the	two world wars and the korean war all served to overcome old grievances	and cement reunion.	4.988670685186233
17351. and there is no section of the nation more	ardent than the south in the cold war against communism.	5.528528251424825
17352. had the	situation been reversed had for instance england been the enemy in	1898 because of issues of concern chiefly to new england there is	little doubt that large numbers of southerners would have happily put	on their old confederate uniforms to fight as allies of britain.	4.722181579233643
17353. it	is extraordinary that a people as proud and warlike as southerners	should have been as docile as they have.	3.6480400458851427
17354. the north should thank its	stars that such has been the case; but at the same time it should not	draw false inferences therefrom.	5.730015470222045
17355. the two main charges levelled	against the bourbons by liberals is that they are racists and social	reactionaries.	3.881977520237071
17356. there is much truth in both these charges and not	many bourbons deny them.	6.248782582272756
17357. whatever their faults they are not hypocrites.	5.519127485746325
17358. most of them sincerely believe that the anglo-saxon is the best	race in the world and that it should remain pure.	8.31508287436488
17359. many northeners	believe this too but few of them will say so publicly.	4.457463238702516
17360. the bourbon	economic philosophy moreover is not very different from that of northern	conservatives.	5.407031410762597
17361. but those among the bourbons who remain unreconstructed	go much further than this.	3.9828372752610997
17362. they believe that if the south	had been let alone it would have produced a civilization superior to that	of modern america.	5.983449782356791
17363. as it is they consider that the north is now	reaping the fruits of excess egalitarianism that in spite of its high	standard of living the american way has been proved inferior	to the english and scandinavian ways although they disapprove of the	socialistic features of the latter.	3.6963005470284327
17364. the south's antipathy	to northern civilization includes such charges as poor manners harsh	accents lack of appreciation of the arts of living like gastronomy	and the use of leisure.	4.8701503241398205
17365. their own easier slower tempo is especially	dear to southerners; and i have heard many say that they are content	to earn a half or a third as much as they could up north because	they so much prefer the quieter habits of their home town.	3.576143006418192
17366. in the past the duties of the state as sir henry maine noted	long ago were only two in number: internal order and external security.	6.110150373263157
17367. by prevailing over other claimants for the loyalties of men	the nation-state maintained an adequate measure of certainty and order	within its territorial borders.	3.3000780055005263
17368. outside those limits it asserted as	against other states a position of sovereign equality and as against	the inferior peoples of the non-western world a position of	dominance.	5.10547037388512
17369. it became the sole subject of international law		a body of legal principle which by and large was made up of what western	nations could do in the world arena.	4.28909923217658
17370. reflection of the power system in existence during the eighteenth and	nineteenth centuries.	6.618433614294976
17371. speaking generally it furthered- and still	tends to further- the interests of the western powers.	3.9599032591547068
17372. the enormous	changes in world politics have however thrown it into confusion so	much so that it is safe to say that all international law is now in	need of reexamination and clarification in light of the social conditions	beyond the two basic tasks mentioned	above no attention was paid by statesman or scholar to an idea of state	responsibility either internally or externally.	4.891912733337628
17373. this was particularly	true in the world arena which was an anarchical battleground characterized	by strife and avaricious competition for colonial empires.	3.84777732521699
17374. that any sort of duty was owed by his nation to other nations would have	astonished a nineteenth-century statesman.	5.444283781373598
17375. his duty was to his sovereign	and to his nation and an extension to peoples beyond the territorial	boundaries was not to be contemplated.	3.8778019888854627
17376. thus to cite but one	example the pax britannica of the nineteenth century whether with	the british navy ruling the seas or with the city of london ruling	world finance was strictly national in motivation however much other	nations may have incidentally benefited.	4.996172614692335
17377. at the same time all suggestions that some sort of societal	responsibility existed for the welfare of the people within the territorial	state was strongly resisted.	4.22029786828386
17378. social darwinism was able to stave	off the incipient socialist movement until well into the present century.	5.978950659447244
17379. however in recent decades for what doubtless are multiple	reasons an unannounced but nonetheless readily observable shift has	occurred in both facets of national activity.	3.464396707083179
17380. a concept of responsibility	is in process of articulation and establishment.	5.8060341396737805
17381. already firmly	implanted internally it is a growing factor in external matters.	4.744696903223991
17382. a little more than twenty years ago the american people turned	an important corner.	7.488865915005864
17383. in what has aptly been called a constitutional	revolution the basic nature of government was transformed from	one essentially negative in nature to	one with affirmative duties to perform.	3.3378439340500927
17384. the positive state came	into existence.	6.4025490497488295
17385. for lawyers reflecting perhaps their parochial preferences	there has been a special fascination since then in the role	played by the supreme court in that transformation- the manner in	which its decisions altered in the switch in time that saved nine	president roosevelt's ill-starred but in effect victorious court-packing	plan the imprimatur of judicial approval that was	finally placed upon social legislation.	3.0856895119210583
17386. of greater importance however	is the content of those programs which have had and are having enormous	consequences for the american people.	5.838231258118497
17387. labor relations have been	transformed income security has become a standardized feature of political	platforms and all the many facets of the american version of	the welfare state have become part of the conventional wisdom.	3.91104052171419
17388. a national	consensus of near unanimity exists that these governmental efforts	are desirable as well as necessary.	5.612325918859975
17389. ratified in the republican party	victory in 1952 the positive state is now evidenced by political	campaigns being waged not on whether but on how much social	legislation there should be.	3.393496488175681
17390. the general acceptance of the idea	of governmental responsibility for the economic	well-being of the american people is surely one of the two most significant	watersheds in american constitutional history.	6.189251525114625
17391. the other of	course was the civil war the conflict which a century ago insured	national unity over fragmentation.	3.820496581643808
17392. a third one of at least equal and	perhaps even greater importance is now being traversed: american	immersion and involvement in world affairs.	5.28911615129733
17393. internal national	responsibility now a truism need not be documented.	4.297650944854278
17394. nevertheless	it may be helpful to cite one example- that of employment- for as	will be shown below it cuts across both facets of the new concept.	5.2764187366993385
17395. thirty	years ago while the nation was wallowing in economic depression	the prevailing philosophy of government was to stand aside and allow	natural forces to operate and cure the distress.	3.3822803052078867
17396. that guiding	principle of the hoover administration fell to the siege guns of the	new deal; less than a score of years later congress enacted the	employment act of 1946 by which the national government assumed the	responsibility of taking action to insure conditions of maximum employment.	5.03333488306882
17397. hands-off the economy was replaced by conscious guidance through	planning- the economic side of the constitutional revolution.	3.90467355570693
17398. in	1961 the first important legislative victory of the kennedy administration	came when the principle of national responsibility for local	economic distress won out over a state's-responsibility	proposal- provision was made for payment for unemployment relief	by nation-wide taxation rather than by a levy only on those states afflicted	with manpower surplus.	4.941996217472675
17399. the american people have indeed come	a long way in the brief interval between 1930 and 1961.	3.807235481178492
17400. internal	national responsibility is a societal response to the impact of the	industrial revolution.	6.075758395869405
17401. reduced to its simplest terms it is an assumption	of a collective duty to compensate for the inability of individuals	to cope with the rigors of the era.	3.6793428702155158
17402. national responsibility for	individual welfare is a concept not limited to the united states or	even to the western nations.	6.504505019235902
17403. a measure of its widespread acceptance	may be derived from a statement of the international congress of jurists	in 1959.	4.113483489353386
17404. meeting in new delhi under the auspices of the international	commission of jurists a body of lawyers from the free world	the congress redefined and expanded the traditional rule of law	to include affirmative governmental duties.	4.8790998488301875
17405. it is noteworthy that	the majority of the delegates to the congress were from the less developed	former colonial nations.	4.0146969309145035
17406. the rule of law historically a principle	according everyone his day in court before an impartial tribunal	was broadened substantively by making it a responsibility of	government to promote individual welfare.	4.651376511975993
17407. recognizing that the rule	of law is a dynamic concept h which should be employed not only	to safeguard the civil and political rights of the individual in a free	society the congress asserted that it also included the responsibility	to establish social economic educational and cultural conditions	under which his legitimate aspirations and dignity may be realized.	3.222714640164158
17408. the idea of national responsibility thus has become a common	feature of the nations of the non-soviet world.	6.4937432227144365
17409. for better or for worse	we all now live in welfare states the organizing principle of which	is collective responsibility for individual well-being.	3.6853848925379227
17410. whether	a concept analogous to the principle of internal responsibility	operates in a nation's external relations is less obvious and more	difficult to establish.	5.068231808551735
17411. the hypothesis ventured here is that it does	and that evidence is accumulating validating that proposition.	3.540594548954762
17412. the content	is not the same however: rather than individual security it	is the security and continuing existence of an ideological group-	those in the free world- that is basic.	4.622105715881927
17413. external national	responsibility involves a burgeoning requirement that the leaders of	the western nations so guide their decisions as to further the viability	of other friendly nations.	3.217888419600229
17414. if internal responsibility suggests acceptance	of the socialist ideal of equality then external responsibility	implies adherence to principles of ideological supranationalism.	5.161431282000894
17415. reference to two other concepts- nationalism and sovereignty-	may help to reveal the contours of the new principle.	3.883124897471269
17416. in its beginnings	the nation-state had to struggle to assert itself- internally	against feudal groups and externally against the power and influence	of such other claimants for loyalty as the church.	4.979187579893193
17417. the breakup of	the holy roman empire and the downfall of feudalism led not more	than two centuries ago to the surge of nationalism.	3.213968880122953
17418. of the nation-state coincides roughly with the separate existence	of the united states as an independent entity it is perhaps natural	for americans to think of the nation as representative of the highest	the concept of	nationalism is the political principle that epitomizes and glorifies	the territorial state as the characteristic type of socal structure.	5.460617588605283
17419. but	it is more than that.	6.271798007364417
17420. for it includes the emotional ties that bind	men to their homeland and the complex motivations that hold a large	group of people together as a unit.	5.199492910941442
17421. today as new nations rise from	the former colonial empires nationalism is one of the hurricane forces	loose in the world.	4.058835883427613
17422. almost febrile in intensity the principle has	become worldwide in application- unfortunately at the very time that	nationalist fervors can wreak greatest harm.	5.21765576323059
17423. historically however	the concept is one that has been of marked benefit to the people of the	western civilizational group.	4.629304060660198
17424. by subduing disparate lesser groups	the nation has to some degree at least broadened the capacity for individual	liberty.	5.920131299245924
17425. within their confines moreover technological and	industrial growth has proceeded at an accelerated pace thus increasing	the cornucopia from which material wants can be satisfied.	3.2775748416910853
17426. while the	pattern is uneven some having gained more than others nationalism	has in fact served the western peoples well.	5.4453496606707334
17427. helped the peoples of the remainder of the world and whether	today's nationalism in the former colonial areas has equally beneficial	it is one of the ironic quirks	of history that the viability and usefulness of nationalism and the	territorial state are rapidly dissipating at precisely the time that	the nation-state attained its highest number.	3.421587903210742
17428. but	it is more than irony: one of the main reasons why nationalism is	no longer a tenable concept is because it has spread throughout the	planet.	6.1829963770641365
17429. in other words nationalism worked well enough when it had	limited application both as to geography and as to population; it	becomes a perilous anachronism when adopted on a world-wide basis.	3.36610398569744
17430. complementing the political principle of nationalism is the legal	principle of sovereignty.	5.989392029408129
17431. the former receives its legitimacy from the	latter.	3.8871950008856997
17432. operating side by side together they helped shore up the nation-state.	6.5832878445361995
17433. while sovereignty has roots in antiquity in its present	usage it is essentially modern.	3.8739413273272065
17434. jean bodin writing in the sixteenth	century may have been the seminal thinker but it was the vastly influential	john austin who set out the main lines of the concept as now	understood.	6.061302959566759
17435. austin's nineteenth-century view of law and sovereignty	still dominates much of today's legal and political thinking.	3.741668946031527
17436. to	him law is the command of the sovereign who	personifies the power of the nation while sovereignty is the power to	make law- ie to prevail over internal groups and to be free	from the commands of other sovereigns in other nations.	5.430799888626977
17437. these fundamental	ideas- the indivisibility of sovereignty and its dual	aspects- still remain the core of that concept of ultimate	political power.	3.614910204871718
17438. the nation-state then exemplifies the principle	of nationalism and exercises sovereignty: supreme power over	domestic affairs and independence from outside control.	4.354626768263743
17439. in fact however	both principles have always been nebulous and loosely defined.	4.319965414350225
17440. high-level	abstractions are always difficult to pin down with precision.	5.91104492761453
17441. that is particularly true of sovereignty when it is applied to democratic	societies in which popular sovereignty is said to exist	and in federal nations in which the jobs of government are split.	4.054446788514951
17442. nevertheless	nationalism and sovereignty are reputed in the accepted	wisdom to describe the modern world.	5.54054652942337
17443. is there a different reality behind	the facade?	5.332204119222106
17444.  does the surface hide a quite different picture?	7.424384575610066
17445. 	the short answer to those questions is yes.	4.097475925154126
17446. both concepts	are undergoing alteration; to some degree they are being supplanted	by a concept of national responsibility.	6.133969024613201
17447. as evidence to support	that view consider the following illustrative instances.	4.192525693189824
17448. can thermonuclear war be set off by accident?	7.242630139717669
17449.  what steps have been	taken to guard against the one sort of mishap that could trigger the	destruction of continents?	3.6025069005299186
17450.  are we as safe as we should be from such	a disaster?	7.261243567892158
17451.  is anything being done to increase our margin of safety?	4.577656512604009
17452. 	will the danger increase or decrease?	6.1517311794317955
17453.    i have just asked	these questions in the pentagon in the white house in offices of	key scientists across the country and aboard the submarines that prowl	for months underwater with neat rows of green launch tubes which contain	polaris missiles and which are affectionately known as sherwood	forest.	3.4389234466785523
17454. i asked the same questions inside the launch-control	rooms of an atlas missile base in wyoming where officers who wear	sidearms are manning the commit buttons that could start a war-	accidentally or by design- and in the command centers where other	pistol-packing men could give orders to push such buttons.	4.827212376027165
17455. to	the men in the instrument-jammed bomber cockpits submarine compartments	and the antiseptic windowless rooms that would be the foxholes of	tomorrow's impersonal intercontinental wars the questions seem farfetched.	3.379183301900336
17456. there is unceasing pressure but its sources are immediate.	6.823452472563424
17457. readiness exercises are almost continuous.	4.741443162537189
17458. each could be the real	thing.	8.525575885365981
17459. in the command centers there are special clocks ready	to tick off the minutes elapsed since e hour.	3.5134783019125875
17460. e	stands for execution- the moment a go order would unleash	an american nuclear strike.	5.516409257251272
17461. there is little time for the men in the	command centers to reflect about the implications of these clocks.	4.455895009262935
17462. they are preoccupied riding herd on control panels switches flashing	colored lights on pale green or gray consoles that look like business	machines.	5.037162437446246
17463. they know little about their machinery beyond mechanical	details.	4.7042707214146136
17464. accidental war is so sensitive a subject that most of the people	who could become directly involved in one are told just enough so	they can perform their portions of incredibly complex tasks.	5.007987332139285
17465. among	the policy makers generals physicists psychologists and others	charged with controlling the actions of the button pushers and their	hardware the answers to my questions varied partly according to	a man's flair for what the professionals in this field call scenarios.	3.3036563716625853
17466. as an air force psychiatrist put it: you can't have	dry runs on this one.	5.823763266971576
17467. the experts are thus forced to hypothesize	sequences of events that have never occurred probably never will-	but possibly might.	3.2926426165051823
17468. only one rule prevailed in my conversations with	these men: the more highly placed they are- that is the more they	know- the more concerned they have become.	5.406350715142241
17469. already accidental	war is a silent guest at the discussions within the kennedy administration	about the urgency of disarmament and nearly all other questions	of national security.	3.3383771494902144
17470. only recently new holes were	discovered in our safety measures and a search is now on for more.	5.6174451861940415
17471. work	is under way to see whether new restraining devices should be installed	on all nuclear weapons.	3.727334138670717
17472. meanwhile the experts speak of	wars triggered by false pre-emption escalation unauthorized	behavior and other terms that will be discussed in this report.	5.498814494536007
17473. they inhabit a secret world centered on go codes and gold	phones.	3.921627792029864
17474. their conversations were almost invariably accompanied	by the same gestures- arms and pointed forefingers darting toward	each other in arclike semicircular motions.	4.965934536235445
17475. one arm represented our bombers	and missiles the other arm theirs.	4.0601941996591195
17476. yet implicit in each	movement was the death of millions perhaps hundreds of millions perhaps	you and me- and the experts.	5.796128177063497
17477. these men are not callous.	6.1146427327137625
17478. it is their job to think about the unthinkable.	6.898382406846716
17479. unanimously they believe	that the world would become a safer place if more of us- and more	russians and communist chinese too- thought about accidental	war.	3.2764102683896206
17480. the first systematic thinking about this pandora's box	within pandora's boxes was done four years ago by fred ikle a	frail meek-mannered swiss-born sociologist.	4.874202331231591
17481. he was and is with the	rand corporation a nonprofit pool of thinkers financed by the	u s air force.	3.6351629890383506
17482. his investigations made him the paul revere	of accidental war and safety procedures were enormously increased.	5.233049370588526
17483. in recent weeks as a result of a sweeping defense policy reappraisal	by the kennedy administration basic united states strategy	has been modified- and large new sums allocated- to meet the accidental-war	danger and to reduce it as quickly as possible.	3.6584180974676794
17484. the	chain starts at bmews	in thule greenland.	6.3122183038668345
17485. its radar screens would register soviet	missiles shortly after they are launched against the united states.	3.9286631816847994
17486. bmews intelligence is simultaneously flashed to norad	in colorado springs	colorado for interpretation; to the sac command and control	post forty-five feet below the ground at offutt air force base near	omaha nebraska; to the joint war room of the joint chiefs	of staff in the pentagon and to the president.	4.696790085341974
17487. telephones	teletypes several kinds of radio systems and in some cases television	link all vital points.	3.8793715493908443
17488. alternate locations exist for all key command	centers.	6.369813526406495
17489. for last-ditch emergencies sac has alternate command	posts on kc-135 jet tankers.	3.6530443621729107
17490. multiple circuits routings and	frequencies make the chain as unbreakable as possible.	5.338423149073377
17491. the	same principle of redundancy applies to all communications on these	special networks.	3.7592352117662156
17492. and no messages can be transmitted on these circuits	until senders and receivers authenticate in advance by special	codes	that the messages actually come from their purported sources.	4.809837554569715
17493. additional	codes can be used to challenge and counterchallenge the authentications.	4.516651275477423
17494. only the president is permitted to authorize the	use of nuclear weapons.	7.23750960021665
17495. but what if somebody decides	to break it?	5.089728515625536
17496.  the president cannot personally remove the safety	devices from every nuclear trigger.	5.676850661785348
17497. he makes the momentous decision.	5.065355285940697
17498. hundreds of men are required to pass the word to the button pushers	and to push the buttons.	6.484430671621643
17499. what if one or more of them turn irrational	or suddenly coolly decide to clobber the russians?	4.266055600442039
17500.  what if the president	himself in the language of the military goes ape?	7.099410581381695
17501. 	or singlehandedly decided to reverse national policy and hit the soviets	without provocation?	3.626991457841105
17502.    nobody can be absolutely certain of	the answers.	7.084771979950038
17503. however the system is designed ingeniously and hopefully	so that no one man could initiate a thermonuclear war.	4.154341631712152
17504. even	the president cannot pick up his telephone and give a go order.	5.934799770189077
17505. even he does not know the one signal for a nuclear strike- the	go code.	4.876779332516552
17506. in an emergency he would receive available intelligence	on the gold-phone circuit.	6.324188071535498
17507. a system of gold- actually	yellow- phones connects him with the offices and action stations of	the secretary of defense the joint chiefs of staff the sac	commander and other key men.	3.3356539950396633
17508. all can be connected with the gold circuit	from their homes.	6.491377834340768
17509. all could help the president make his decision.	5.025019212763248
17510. the talk would not be in code but neither would it ramble.	5.741241096937546
17511. vital	questions would be quickly answered according to a preprepared agenda.	4.242921240985502
17512. officers who participate in the continual practice drills assured	me that the president's decision could be made and announced on the	gold circuit within minutes after the first flash from bmews.	5.099819319129285

17732. nowhere	in isfahan is this rich aesthetic life of the persians shown so	well as during the promenade at the khaju bridge.	5.3840819663997
17733. there has probably	always been a bridge of some sort at the southeastern corner of the	city.	4.246465024800554
17734. for one thing there is a natural belt of rock across the river	bed; for another it was here that one of the old caravan routes came	in.	6.556651431717557

17737. from upstream it looks like a	long arcaded box laid across the river; from downstream where the	water level is much lower it is a high elaborately facaded pavilion.	3.557517774544661
17738. the top story contains more than thirty alcoves separated from	each other by spandrels of blue and yellow tile.	4.720808513415344
17739. at either end and	in the center there are bays which contain nine greater alcoves as frescoed	and capacious as church apses.	3.4394957478224124
17740. here in the old days- when they	had come to see the moon or displays of fireworks- sat the king and	his court while priests soldiers and other members of the party lounged	in the smaller alcoves between.	5.808257428482971
17741. below twenty vaults tunnel	through the understructure of the bridge.	4.165828482005489
17742. these are traversed by	another line of vaults and thus rooms arched on all four sides are	formed.	5.525271863184004

17916. these seven founders	constituted an intellectual and social elite the most respectable	and disinterested leadership any revolution ever confessed.	5.0774155543106465

18090. midi garth also believes in subjective continuity	that begins with the feeling engendered by an initial movement.	5.269866200370428
18091. it	may be a free front-back swing of the leg leading to a sideways swing	of the arm that develops into a turn and the sensation of taking off	from the ground.	3.3875887496565578

18097. it is through the metamorphosed dancer that the	germ of form is discovered.	4.222923914762407

18105. though he is also concerned	with freeing dance from pedestrian modes of activity merce	cunningham has selected a very different method for achieving his aim.	3.494873693079797

18113. the sequence of movements in a cunningham dance is	unlike any sequence to be seen in life.	3.870736931090866
18114. at one side of the stage a dancer	jumps excitedly; nearby another sits motionless while still another	is twirling an umbrella.	6.108223005751381

18122. the answers derived by these means may determine not only the temporal	organization of the dance but also its spatial design special	slips designating the location on the stage where the movement is to be	performed.	5.05208865009737

18134. the north and the south were in greater agreement on sovereignty	through all their dispute about it than were the founding fathers.	5.539274738919639

18153. his emphasis   when the southern states exercised	their right to secede they formed what they officially styled the	confederate states of america.	3.6978939817885768

18267. 	in the physical sciences these achievements concern electricity chemistry	and atomic physics.	3.404302767652644
18268. in the life sciences there has been an	enormous increase in our understanding of disease in the mechanisms of	heredity and in bio- and physiological chemistry.	5.529814013634547
18269. the major effect	of these advances appears to lie in the part they have played in the	industrial revolution and in the tools which scientific understanding	has given us to build and manipulate a more protective environment.	3.3524836289703317
18270. in	addition our way of dealing directly with natural phenomena has also	changed.	5.920964748768236
18271. even in domains where detailed and predictive understanding	is still lacking but where some explanations are possible as with	lightning and weather and earthquakes the appropriate kind of human action	has been more adequately indicated.	3.235174764025385
18272. apparently the population	as a whole eventually acquires enough confidence in the explanations	of the scientists to modify its procedures and its fears.	5.1713771870697345

18513. there were fences in the old days when we were children.	5.2646694529024725
18514. across	the front of a yard and down the side they were iron either spiked	along the top or arched in half circles.	5.568548274237441

18646. and if i have gone into so much detail about so small	a work that is because it is also so typical a work representing the	germinal form of a conflict which remains essential in mann's writing:	the crude sketch of piepsam contains in its critical destructive	and self-destructive tendencies much that is enlarged and illuminated	in the figures of for instance naphta and leverku^hn.	4.986741040698484
18647. in method as well as in theme this little anecdote with its details	selected as much for expressiveness and allegory as for realism	anticipates a kind of musical composition as well as a kind of fictional	composition in which as leverku^hn says there shall be	nothing unthematic.	3.7886228283882444
18648. it resembles too pictures such as du^rer	and bruegel did in which all that looks at first to be solely pictorial	proves on inspection to be also literary the representation of a	proverb for example or a deadly sin.	4.885244588286568
18649. gladius dei	resembles the way to the churchyard in its representation	of a conflict between light and dark between life and a spirit	of criticism negation melancholy but it goes considerably further	in characterizing the elements of this conflict.	3.4938589713764308
18650. the monk savonarola	brought over from the renaissance and placed against the background	of munich at the turn of the century protests against the luxurious	works displayed in the art-shop of m bluthenzweig; in	particular against a madonna portrayed in a voluptuous style and modeled	according to gossip upon the painter's mistress.	4.389347989404208
18651. hieronymus	like piepsam makes his protest quite in vain and his rejection though	not fatal is ridiculous and humiliating; he is simply thrown out	of the shop by the porter.	3.0847460756917937
