18653. the reality to which they respond is rationally empty and their	art is an imitation of the inescapable powerfulness of this unknown and	empty world.	3.2081224312612595
18654. their artistic rationale is given to the witness of unreason.	6.72352060597446
18655. these polar concerns reflect	a philosophical and religious situation which has been developing	over a long period of time.	3.986379701674713
18656. the breakdown of classical structures of	meaning in all realms of western culture has given rise to several generations	of artists who have documented the disintegrative processes.	4.7033943677619074
18657. thus the image of man has suffered complete fragmentation in personal	and spiritual qualities and complete objectification in sub-human and	quasi-mechanistic powers.	3.642055295775078
18658. the image of the world tends to reflect the	hostility and indifference of man or else to dissolve into empty spaces	and overwhelming mystery.	5.636663178700594
18659. the image of god has simply disappeared.	4.771011601880828
18660. all such imitations of negative quality have given rise to a compensatory	response in the form of a heroic and highly individualistic humanism:	if man can neither know nor love reality as it is he can at	least invent an artistic reality which is its own world and which	can speak to man of purely personal and subjective qualities capable	of being known and worthy of being loved.	4.907949883451558
18661. the person of the artist	becomes a final bastion of meaning in a world rendered meaningless by	the march of events and the decay of classical religious and philosophical	systems.	3.2769958915809694
18662. whatever pole of this contrast one emphasizes and	whatever the tension between these two approaches to understanding	the artistic imagination it will be readily seen that they are not mutually	exclusive that they belong together.	5.45446556508078
18663. without the decay of a	sense of objective reference the	stress on subjective invention would never have been stimulated into	being.	3.634416387416098
18664. and although these insights into the nature of art may be in themselves	insufficient for a thoroughgoing philosophy of art their peculiar	authenticity in this day and age requires that they be taken seriously	and gives promise that from their very substance new and valid	chapters in the philosophy of art may be written.	5.159417389822263
18665. for better or worse	we cannot regard imitation in the arts in the simple mode of	classical rationalism or detached realism.	3.6172364831108643
18666. a broader concept of imitation	is needed one which acknowledges that true invention is important	that the artist's creativity in part transcends the non-artistic	causal factors out of which it arises.	4.62715309027267
18667. on the other hand we cannot regard	artistic invention as pure uncaused and unrelated to the times	in which it occurs.	3.7141928489386604
18668. we need a doctrine of imitation to save us from	the solipsism and futility of pure formalism.	6.009739708989989
18669. accordingly it is the	aim of this essay to advance a new theory of imitation	call mimesis in order to distinguish it from earlier theories of	and a new theory of invention	.	3.5743293091013837
18670. the arts	the word mimesis is usually associated	with plato and aristotle.	4.985361578836881
18671. for plato imitation is twice	removed from reality being a poor copy of physical appearance which	in itself is a poor copy of ideal essence.	3.663038549596215
18672. all artistic and mythological	representations therefore are imitations of imitations and	are completely superseded by the truth value of dialectic the	proper use of the inquiring intellect.	5.216666388096817
18673. in plato's judgment the	arts play a meaningful role in society only in the education of the young	prior to the full development of their intellectual powers.	3.731932490036408
18674. presupposed	in plato's system is a doctrine of levels of insight in which	a certain kind of detached understanding is alone capable of penetrating	to the most sublime wisdom.	4.759882635553747
18675. aristotle also tended to stratify all	aspects of human nature and activity into levels of excellence and	like plato he put the pure and unimpassioned intellect on the top level.	3.257450115660097
18676. the poetics in affirming that all human arts are modes	of imitation gives a more serious role to artistic mimesis than	did plato.	4.539397568489035
18677. but aristotle kept the principle of levels and even augmented	it by describing in the poetics what kinds of character and	action must be imitated if the play is to be a vehicle of serious and	important human truths.	3.7908380098663694
18678. for both plato and aristotle artistic mimesis	in contrast to the power of dialectic is relatively incapable of	expressing the character of fundamental reality.	5.779915409069291
18679. the central	concern of erich auerbach's impressive volume called mimesis	is to describe the shift from a classic theory of imitation	to a christian theory of imitation	in which the levels are dissolved.	2.930944109390738
18680. following the theme of incarnation	in the gospels the christian artist and critic sees in the most	commonplace and ordinary events figures of divine power and reality.	5.016632326788623
18681. here artistic realism involves the audience in an impassioned participation	in events whose overtones and implications are transcendent.	3.7372947530088023
18682. artistic mimesis under christian influence records the involvement	of all persons however humble in a divine drama.	4.946540683325256
18683. the artist unlike	the philosopher is not a removed observer aiming at neutral and rarified	high levels of abstraction.	3.4982065435643
18684. he is the conveyor of a sacred reality	by which he has been grasped.	7.371967856780534
18685. i have chosen to use the word mimesis	in its christian rather than its classic implications and	to discover in the concrete forms of both art and myth powers of theological	expression which as in the christian mind are the direct consequence	of involvement in historical experience which are not reserved	as in the greek mind only to moments of theoretical reflection.	3.3853799646850145
18686. in the first instance mimesis is here used to mean the	recalling of experience in terms of vivid images rather than in terms	of abstract ideas or conventional designations.	5.92152891945113
18687. by image is meant	not only a visual presentation but also remembered sensations of any	of the five senses plus the feelings which are immediately conjoined	therewith.	3.3292242947184176
18688. this is the primary function of the imagination operating	in the absence of the original experiential stimulus by which the images	were first appropriated.	6.353887874932947
18689. mimesis is the nearest possible thing to	the actual re-living of experience in which the imagining person recovers	through images something of the force and depth characteristic	of experience itself.	3.7250275376823803
18690. the images themselves like their counterparts	in experience are not neutral qualities to be surveyed dispassionately;	they are fields of force exerting a unique influence on the sensibilities	and a unique relatedness to one another.	4.3050032859246405
18691. they bring an inextricable	component of value within themselves with attractions and repulsions	native to their own quality.	3.8736877386750277
18692. as in experience one is seized by	given entities and their interrelations and is forced to respond in	value feelings to them so one is similarly seized in the mimetic presentation	of images.	5.039995935861949
18693. mimesis here is not to be confused with literalism	or realism in the conventional sense.	4.390834516967047
18694. a word taken in its dictionary	meaning a photographic image of a recognizable object the mere picturing	of a scene tends to lose experiential vividness and to connote	such conventional abstractions as to invite neutral reception without	the incitement of value feelings.	4.515964854326748
18695. similarly experience itself can	be conventionalized so that people react to certain preconceived clues	for behavior without awareness of the vitality of their experiential	field.	3.586590279523843
18696. a truly vivid imagination moves beyond the conventional recollection	to a sense of immediacy.	5.8646498434733445
18697. the mimetic character of the	imaginative consciousness tends to express itself in the presentation	of artistic forms and materials.	3.168650939557141
18698. when words can be used in a more fresh	and primitive way so that they strike with the force of sights and	sounds when tones of sound and colors of paint and the carven shape	all strike the sensibilities with an undeniable force of data in and of	themselves compelling the observer into an attitude of attention all	this imitates the way experience itself in its deepest character strikes	upon the door of consciousness and clamors for entrance.	4.802433735453558
18699. these	are like the initial ways in which the world forces itself upon the self	and thrusts the self into decision and choice.	3.9294976212904023
18700. the presence of genuine	mimesis in art is marked by the persistence with which the work	demands attention and compels valuation even though it is but vaguely	understood.	5.49394403412422
18701. underlying these conceptions of mimesis are certain	presuppositions concerning the nature of primary human experience which	require some exposition before the main argument can proceed.	3.3418491348556536
18702. experience	is not seen as it is in classical rationalism as presenting	us initially with clear and distinct objects simply located in space	and	registering their character movements and changes on the tabula	rasa of an uninvolved intellect.	4.908336837717875
18703. neither is primary experience understood	according to the attitude of modern empiricism in which nothing	is thought to be received other than signals of sensory qualities producing	their responses in the appropriate sense organs.	3.557206721252447
18704. primary feelings	of the world come neither as a collection of clearly known objects	nor a collection of isolated and	neutral sensory qualities.	5.3993646783546625
18705. in contrast to all this primary data are	data of a self involved in environing processes and powers.	3.6910853327000175
18706. the	most primitive feelings are rudimentary value feelings both positive	and negative: a desire to appropriate this or that part of the environment	into oneself; a desire to avoid and repel this or that other	part.	5.319610815051028
18707. these desires presuppose a sense of causally efficacious powers	in which one is involved some working for one's good others threatening	ill.	3.6656230892409445
18708. gone is the tabula rasa of the mind.	6.105888876451725
18709. in its place	is a passionate consciousness grasped and molded to feelings of positive	or negative values even as the actions of one's life are determined	by constellations of process in which one is caught.	3.3279042541282897
18710. the principal	defender of this view of primary experience as causal efficacy	is alfred north whitehead.	5.022307935955788
18711. our most elemental and unavoidable	impressions he says are those of being involved in a large arena of	powers which have a longer past than our own which are interrelated	in a vast movement through the present toward the future.	3.543053962546631
18712. we feel the	quality of these powers initially as in some degree wholesome or threatening.	6.231065264134466
18713. later abstractive and rational processes may indicate errors	of judgment in these apprehensions of value but the apprehensions themselves	are the primary stuff of experience.	3.3759970752441304
18714. it takes a great deal	of abstraction to free oneself from the primitive impression of larger	unities of power and influence and to view one's world simply as a	collection of sense data arranged in such and such sequence and pattern	devoid of all power to move the feelings and actions except in so far	as they present themselves for inspection.	4.850392891448725
18715. whitehead is here questioning	david hume's understanding of the nature of experience; he	is questioning also every epistemology which stems from hume's	presupposition	that experience is merely sense data in abstraction from	causal efficacy and that causal efficacy is something intellectually	imputed to the world not directly perceived.	3.3189062988453464
18716. what hume calls sensation	is what whitehead calls perception in the mode of presentational	immediacy which is a sophisticated abstraction from perception	in the mode of causal efficacy.	5.280521654960541
18717. as long as perception is seen as	composed only of isolated sense data most of the quality and interconnectedness	of existence loses its objectivity becomes an invention	of consciousness and the result is a philosophical scepticism.	3.8290058501151174
18718. whitehead	contends that the human way of understanding existence as a unity	of interlocking and interdependent processes which constitute each other	and which cause each other to be and not to be is possible only because	the basic form of such an understanding for all its vagueness and	tendency to mistake the detail is initially given in the way man	feels the world.	5.149783969918688
18719. in this respect experience is broader and full of	a richer variety of potential meanings than the mind of man or any of	his arts or culture are capable of making clear and distinct.	3.5221346960664572

18823. in the following sketch	we shall present a brief outline of his life and let him as much as	possible speak for himself.	4.018774642238736
18824. heidenstam was born in 1859 of	a prosperous family.	7.373063859151278
18825. on his father's side he was of german descent	on his mother's he came of the old swedish nobility.	4.154620019611672
18826. the family	estate was situated near vadstena on lake va^ttern in south central	sweden.	4.661013058758291
18827. it is a lonely rather desolate region but full of legendary	and historic associations.	3.9209800156696253
18828. as a boy in a local school he was shy	and solitary absorbed in his fondness for nature and his visions of	sweden's ancient glory.	5.598617072951098
18829. he liked to fancy himself as a chieftain	and to dress for the part.	4.143908700824109
18830. being somewhat delicate in health at the	age of sixteen he was sent to southern europe for which he at once	developed a passion so that he spent nearly all of the following ten	years abroad at first in italy then in greece egypt asia minor	and palestine.	5.068970640938048
18831. in one of his summers at home he married to the	great disapproval of his father who objected because of his extreme youth.	4.232078175194553
18832. deciding to become a painter he entered the studio of gerome	in paris where he enjoyed the life of the artists but soon found	that whatever talent he might have did not lie in that direction.	5.571553773992182
18833. he gives us an account of this in his lively and humorous poem the	happy artists.	3.9064423945305338
18834. i scanned the world through printed symbol	swart and through the beggar's rags i strove to see the inner man.	5.8687523164950814
18835. i looked unceasingly with my cold mind and with my burning heart.	4.005448972544812
18836. in this final line we have the key to his nature.	8.039949647650397
18837. few writers	have better understood their deepest selves.	4.558855116260103
18838. heidenstam could never be	satisfied by surface.	7.1448440164045275
18839. it may however be noted that his gift for color	and imagery must have been greatly stimulated by his stay in paris.	4.0427166606426574
18840. the first result of heidenstam's long sojourn abroad was	a volume of poems pilgrimage and wander-years	published in 1888.	5.0769452586775214
18841. it was a brilliant debut so much so	indeed that it aroused a new vitality in the younger poets as did byron's	childe harold.	3.648977491241721
18842. professor fredrik bo^o^k sweden's	foremost critic of the period acclaims it as follows: in	this we have the verse of a painter; strongly colorful plastic racy	vivid.	5.355784565331482
18843. in a bold sometimes careless form there is nothing academic;	all is seen and felt and experienced the observation is sharp	and the imagination lively.	3.6178029426362834
18844. the young poet-painter reproduces the french	life of the streets; he tells stories of the thousand and one	nights and conjures up before us the bazaars of damascus.	4.474274035047045
18845. in the	care-free indolence of the east he sees the last reflection of the	old happy existence and for that reason he loves it.	3.7398145683092223
18846. and yet amid all	the gay hedonism in pilgrimage and wander-years is a cycle of	short poems thoughts in loneliness filled with brooding melancholy	and sombre longing.	4.73776055618012
18847. of the longer pieces of the volume	none is so memorable as nameless and immortal which at	once took rank among the finest poems ever written in the swedish language.	3.55060190248491
18848. it celebrates the unknown architect who designed the temple of	neptune at paestum next to the parthenon the noblest example of grecian	classic style now in existence.	5.140939620548047
18849. on the eve of his return to their	native naxos he speaks with his wife of the masterpiece which rises	before them in its completed perfection.	3.9497239135998536
18850. the supreme object of their	lives is now fulfilled says the wife her husband has achieved immortality.	5.214254507390788
18851. not so he answers it is not the architect but the temple	that is immortal.	5.169093477349946
18852. the man's true reputation is his work.	5.336781553834515
18853. the short poems grouped at the end of the volume as thoughts	in loneliness is as professor bo^o^k indicated in sharp contrast	with the others.	3.3912252886927647
18854. it consists of fragmentary personal revelations	such as the spark: there is a spark dwells deep within	my soul.	5.9018262771114705
18855. to get it out into the daylight's glow is my life's	aim both first and last the whole.	4.30315704928437
18856. it slips away it burns and tortures	me.	7.111751802877177
18857. that little spark is all the wealth i know that little spark	is my life's misery.	4.194518055474484
18858. a dominant motive is the poet's longing	for his homeland and its boyhood associations: not men-folk but	the fields where i would stray the stones where as a child i used	to play.	4.4932234974094545
18859. he is utterly disappointed in himself and in the desultory	life he has been leading.	5.034189344995127
18860. what he really wants is to find a	sacred cause to which he can honestly devote himself.	6.579362513208018
18861. this restless	individualism found its answer when he returned to live nearly all	the rest of his life in sweden.	4.070681732269
18862. his cause was to commemorate the glory	of her past and to incite her people to perpetuate it in the present.	5.388255826414048
18863. he did not however find himself at once.	5.236302808106863
18864. his next major	work completed in 1892 was a long fantastic epic in prose entitled	hans alienus which professor bo^o^k describes as a monument	on the grave of his carefree and indolent youth.	4.529714342659421
18865. the hero who is	himself is represented as a pilgrim in the storied lands of the east	a sort of faustus type who to quote from professor bo^o^k again	even in the pleasure gardens of sardanapalus can not cease from	his painful search after the meaning of life.	2.9562976179786813
18866. he is driven back by	his yearning to the wintry homeland of his fathers in the forest of	tiveden.	5.534652632389466
18867. from this time on heidenstam proceeded to find his	deeper self.	4.711623161554298
18868. by the death of his father in 1888 he had come into possession	of the family estate and had re-assumed its traditions.	6.402281196244032
18869. he	did not however settle back into acquiescence with things as they were.	3.817741979540324
18870. like his friend and contemporary august strindberg he had little	patience with collective mediocrity.	6.0037478534545405
18871. he saw sweden as a country of	smug and narrow provincialism indifferent to the heroic spirit of its	former glory.	3.476361667058654
18872. strindberg's remedy for this condition was to tear	down the old structures and build anew from the ground up.	5.484743446599244
18873. heidenstam's	conception on the contrary was to revive the present by the memories	of the past.	3.8928972570502065
18874. whether in prose or poetry all of heidenstam's	later work was concerned with sweden.	6.0837638312029005
18875. with the first of a group	of historical novels the charles men published	in 1897-8 he achieved the masterpiece of his career.	4.3320577811382
18876. in scope	and power it can only be compared to tolstoy's war and peace.	5.885965115344841
18877. about one-third as long it is less intimate and detailed but better	coordinated more concise and more dramatic.	3.7036367478218533
18878. though it centers around	the brilliant and enigmatic figure of charles 12 the true hero	is not finally the king himself.	5.536265077937477
18879. hence the title of the book referring	to the soldiers and subjects of the king; on the fatal battlefield	of poltava to quote from the novel the wreath he twined for	himself slipped down upon his people.	3.4018082790357247
18880. the charles men	consists not of a connected narrative but of a group of short stories	each depicting a special phase of the general subject.	5.345179494583775
18881. somewhat uneven	in interest for an average reader eight or ten of these are among	the finest of their kind in literature.	3.6293552900639994
18882. they comprise a great variety	of scene and interest: grim episodes of war idyllic interludes superb	canvases of world-shaking events and delightfully humorous sketches	of odd characters.	4.523583991436811
18883. the general effect is tragic.	4.670902221004378
18884. almost nothing	is said of charles' spectacular victories the central theme being	the heroic loyalty of the swedish people to their idolized king in misfortune	and defeat.	4.9930558869566735
18885. to carry out this exalted conception the	author has combined the vivid realism and imaginative power we have noticed	in his early poetry and carried them out on a grand scale.	3.51394170410852
18886. his	peculiar gift as had been suggested before is his intensity.	6.036483238166995
18887. george	meredith has said that fervor is the core of style.	4.60123520567475
18888. of few authors	is this more true than of heidenstam.	6.985888025865876
18889. the charles men has a tremendous	range of characters of common folk even more than of major	figures.	3.4641197775174053
18890. the career of charles 12 is obviously very similar to that	of napoleon.	5.484569704245717
18891. his ideal was alexander of macedon as napoleon's	was julius caesar.	3.673374903678972
18892. his purpose however was not to establish an	empire but to assert the principle of divine justice.	6.705709587185648
18893. each aspired	to be a god in human form but with each it was a different kind of god.	4.339365204797514
18894. each failed catastrophically in an invasion of russia and each brought	ruin on the country that worshipped him.	5.652401570347251
18895. each is still glorified	as a national hero.	5.06685654113972
18896. the first half of the charles men	ending on the climax of the battle of poltava in 1709 is more dramatically	coherent than the second.	5.766548311490796
18897. after the collapse of that desperate	and ill-fated campaign the character of the king degenerated for a	time into a futility that was not merely pitiable but often ridiculous.	3.8046810619121483
18898. like napoleon he was the worst of losers.	8.396647179328555
18899. there are however some	wonderful chapters at the beginning of the second part concerning	the reactions of the swedes in adversity.	4.017432051067474
18900. then more than ever before	did they show their fortitude and patient cheerfulness.	6.0688055355411965
18901. this comes	out in when the bells ring which describes the rallying of the	peasants in southern sweden to repel an invasion by the danes.	3.164517168595731
18902. in the king's ride charles breaks out of a long period	of petulance and inertia regains his old self escapes from turkey	and finally reaches his own land after an absence of eighteen years.	4.751256421744837
18903. he finds it in utter misery and desolation.	4.3787836981463135
18904. all his people ask for	is no more war.	6.956354121864664
18905. but he plunges into yet another this time with norway	and is killed in an assault on the fortress of fredrikshall being	only thirty-six years of age when he died.	3.694107169495146
18906. he had become king at fifteen.	7.977881179676322
18907. then suddenly there was a tremendous revulsion of popular	feeling.	4.962672474311353
18908. from being a hated tyrant and madman he was now the symbol	of all that was noblest and best in the history of sweden.	5.8410542661346
18909. this is	brought out in the next to last chapter of the book a hero's	funeral written in the form of an impassioned prose poem.	4.5607540612116715
18910. slowly	the procession of warriors and statesmen passes through the snow beside	the black water and into the brilliantly lighted cathedral the shrine	of so many precious memories.	4.6325071525998744
18911. the guns are fired the hymns are	sung and the body of charles is carried down to the vault and laid beside	the tombs of his ancestors.	3.3549205060796714
18912. as he had longed to be he became the	echo of a saga.	6.859798114357873
18913. heidenstam wrote four other works of fiction	about earlier figures revered in swedish memory.	3.6863014280739295
18914. excellent in their	way they lack the wide appeal of the charles men and need	not detain us here.	5.553205399356955
18915. it is different with his volume the swedes	and their chieftains a history	intended for the general reader and particularly suited for high	school students.	3.421541549207984
18916. admirably written it is a perfect introduction to swedish	history for readers of other countries.	6.194530928302037
18917. some of the earlier episodes	have touches of the supernatural as suited to the legendary background.	4.191005892017725
18918. these are suggestive of selma lagerlo^f.	7.49398818527725
18919. especially touching	is the chapter the little sister about a king's daughter	who became a nun in the convent of st birgitta.	3.3682907154610473
18920. the record	teems with romance and adventure.	5.339447074343718
18921. gustaf vasa is a superb example	and charles 10 the conqueror of denmark hardly less so.	3.27224677287392
18922. of	gustavus adolphus and charles 12 it is unnecessary to speak.	5.708942039589589
18923. today the private detective will also investigate insurance claims or	handle divorce cases but his primary function remains what it has always	been to assist those who have money in their unending struggle with	those who have not.	3.5066090528868354
18924. it is from this unpromising background that the	fictional private detective was recruited.	5.845700208604104
18925. the mythological	private eye differs from his counterpart in real life in two essential	ways.	3.507147853126764
18926. on the one hand he does not work for a large agency but	is almost always self-employed.	7.03793085817909
18927. as a free-lance investigator the fictional	detective is responsible to no one but himself and his client.	4.020874789957458
18928. for this reason he appears as an independent and self-reliant figure	whose rugged individualism need not be pressed into the mold of a	9 to 5 routine.	5.430253646636214
18929. on the other hand the fictional detective does not	break strikes or handle divorce cases; no client would ever think of	asking him to do such things.	3.6280977384009545
18930. whatever his original assignment the	fictional private eye ends up by investigating and solving a crime usually	a murder.	5.342841747562624
18931. operating as a one man police force in fact if not in	name he is at once more independent and more dedicated than the police	themselves.	3.9458470239968926
18932. he catches criminals not merely because he is paid to	do so but because he enjoys	his work because he firmly believes that murder must be punished.	5.141853558665611
18933. thus the fictional detective is much more than a simple businessman.	5.959053709641481
18934. he is first and foremost a defender of public morals a servant of	society.	6.037717519649155
18935. it is this curious blend of rugged individualism and	public service which accounts for the great appeal of the mythological	detective.	3.978783114947882
18936. by virtue of his self-reliance his individualism and	his freedom from external restraint the private eye is a perfect embodiment	of the middle class conception of liberty which amounts to doing	what you please and let the devil take the hindmost.	5.1619173085966406
18937. at the same time	because the personal code of the detective coincides with the legal	dictates of his society because he likes to catch criminals he is	in middle class eyes a virtuous man.	3.379516250354767
18938. in this way the private detective	gets the best of two possible worlds.	7.330750461341754
18939. he is an individualist but	not an anarchist; he is a public servant but not a cop.	4.3237908318332625
18940. in short the	fictional private eye is a specialized version of adam smith's	ideal entrepreneur the man whose private ambitions must always and everywhere	promote the public welfare.	5.172558101984825
18941. in the mystery story as in the	wealth of nations individualism and the social good are two sides	of the same benevolent coin.	3.6417509797601992
18942. there is only one	catch to this idyllic arrangement: adam smith was wrong.	6.274048412846368
18943. not only	did the ideal entrepreneur not produce the greatest good for the greatest	number he ended by destroying himself by giving birth to monopoly	capitalism.	3.595751971130847
18944. the rise of the giant corporations in western europe	and the united states dates from the period 1880-1900.	5.788492788829464
18945. now although	the roots of the mystery story in serious literature go back as far	as balzac dickens and poe it was not until the closing decades	of the 19th century that the private detective became an established	figure in popular fiction.	3.514495987692886
18946. sherlock holmes the ancestor of all private	eyes was born during the 1890s.	5.460782907469894
